PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Directory: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Since the introduction of three (3) regional West Australian telephone directories there has been a constant demand from users to revert to a consolidated country directory which is convenient to all users.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled urge the Minister for Communications to direct Telecom to recognise the requirement of rural West Australians and revert to a single consolidated country telephone directory.

PETITION.TITLE: Five-Dollar Note
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

There is widespread concern in the Australian community about the proposal by the Reserve Bank of Australia to produce a new plastic $5 note that will feature the Queen, and that the present $5 note featuring Caroline Chisholm will be removed from circulation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Reserve Bank to adopt a design for the new note that will promote and identify the unique character of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The speeches read as follows-
SOCIAL WELFARE LEGISLATION PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

The Bill before the Senate amends the National Health Act 1953, the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 to implement a number of substantial reforms to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is one of the Government's major welfare programs and it continues to protect all Australians against the high and increasing cost of drugs and medicinal preparations. The scheme has a proud record. It has secured safe, low cost medications for all Australians. The pharmaceutical industry has estimated that Australian prescription medications are around 55 per cent of average prices in OECD countries. The scheme is an equitable and universal one, financed by all taxpayers under progressive taxation arrangements. The scheme is nonetheless targeted, with lower patient contributions made by those in sections of the community with greater need, and relatively higher contributions from those who can afford to make them.

More than 1,100 drug products are listed on the scheme, ranging from basic medications for common illnesses to the latest advances in drug therapy for cancer, high blood cholesterol levels and heart disease. Under this scheme children with short stature can obtain treatment, without charge, with human growth hormone. People requiring stoma appliances and medication can obtain them under the scheme and diabetics can obtain their supplies as well as their insulin at subsidised prices. The scheme has fulfilled a very important social and health role for over forty years. The government wishes to ensure that it continues to offer this protection in the l990's and beyond.

However, no government could responsibly continue the PBS in its current form in the face of the fact that the cost of the scheme has doubled in the last four years and was to have doubled again over the next three years. The survival of the scheme depended upon action to rein in these escalating costs.

Underlying these cost increases there are several factors. While patient payments are targeted to those most in need, they are not related to drug costs and there is little awareness of or incentive to use lower cost alternative treatments amongst consumers or providers.
No direct contribution at all is made by the significant number of users who are pensioners and therefore there is no incentive to avoid waste or to be more thoughtful about the use of drugs.
There is an ever increasing array of new, high-cost drugs on the market.
And, of course, as the population ages there is an increasing demand for health services of all kinds, including medication.
But pressures on costs are not the only imperative to which the Government has responded with these reform measures.

There is increasing concern amongst health care professionals about the amount of ill-health which, ironically, can and does occur through the inappropriate use of medication. There is evidence that a significant number of hospital admissions of elderly people are for drug-related illness. Ministers for Health have over recent years received correspondence from the relatives of elderly people pointing out cases of hoarding in which sometimes several years' supply of medications have been accumulated in bathroom cupboards. Professional pharmacists can attest to the `success', if this word can appropriately be used in reference to such a sad phenomenon, of medi-dump campaigns which produce large hauls of unused drugs.

There are financial penalties attached to this waste. Australian taxpayers paid for the unused drugs as well as for those which enabled people to get or stay well. In a scheme which costs us as taxpayers more than one billion dollars we should all be interested in minimising waste.
Beyond the waste, and a key objective of these Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme reforms, is the commitment to improvements in health which can result from more appropriate and thoughtful use of drugs.

The Government has responded to both the cost pressures and to the improved health objectives identified by making some fundamental reforms. This Bill is one of two Bills which give effect to these changes. It contains provision for new patient contribution arrangements and offsetting pension supplementation. A second Bill will be introduced into the Senate later in this session.

It is proposed to introduce from 1 November 1990 a charge of $2.50 for all prescriptions previously provided free to pensioners. However the Government proposes to make a compensating adjustment, through an increase to the pension for applicable recipients of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs benefits, of $2.50 per week for those on the single rate and $1.25 per week to the married rate. These additional payments will commence on the first pay period in November. This will mean that in a full calendar year a single pensioner would receive $130 in additional pension and a married couple will also receive $130. In the period from 1 November 1990 to 31 December 1991 single pensioners and pensioner couples will receive $150 in increased pension payments.

Those persons receiving maximum rate Social Security pension, widowed person's, sheltered employment or rehabilitation allowances, service and war widow's pensions will be paid an advance pharmaceutical supplement of $50 or $25 each in the case of pensioner couples. Further advances will be payable up to the safety net limit to a maximum rate pensioner where the pensioner provides a patient record form demonstrating that they have bought a prescribed number of pharmaceutical benefit items in less than specified periods for themselves, their spouse or dependants and they have liquid assets below $1,000 and non-pension income of less than $10 a week.
Advance payments will also be available to those who qualify for maximum rate pension or allowances after 8 November 1990 on similar conditions.

To further protect those pensioners and their families who are large users of drugs, there will be a safety net such that a pensioner or a pensioner family will have an upper limit placed on the amount they need to spend on prescription pharmaceuticals. Free pharmaceutical benefits will be provided to pensioners after the aggregate of their $2.50 Co-payments reaches $150 in the period 1 November 1990 to 31 December 1991. In following years the safety net aggregate co-payment threshold will reduce to $130 in a calendar year. The safety net will be the same for single pensioners and for pensioner families or couples.

All full year pensioners, and social security beneficiaries who currently receive free pharmaceuticals, will be fully protected under the new arrangements, and most will gain. Pensioners use, on average, 27 prescriptions per year. With the safety net in a calendar year set at $130 (equivalent to 52 prescriptions) most will have additional disposable income as a result of the reallocation of Commonwealth subsidies provided for in this Bill.

This same co-payment threshold for safety net purposes of $130 (individual and family) in a calendar year is to be introduced for all persons currently receiving benefits at the concessional rate of $2.50. That co-payment rate remains unchanged. The Bill thus provides for all those who receive Commonwealth income support and those who are on low incomes to make the one contribution to their prescriptions and to be protected by the scheme's safety net.

The second Bill to be introduced later will, from March 1991, provide for the pension supplement to be absorbed within a $2.50 per week pension increase for all pensioners, sickness beneficiaries and other long term beneficiaries.
Veterans receiving benefits under the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will continue to receive drugs free of charge.

The general patient co-payment is to increase from the present maximum of $11.00 to a maximum of $15.00. The present general safety net scheme will be revamped into two levels: an aggregate monetary limit of up to $300 will apply at the first level after which the patient will pay only $2.50 per prescription until the second safety net limit of $50 is reached. After that PBS prescriptions will be free for the remainder of that calendar year.

It is worth noting that the new maximum general patient contribution is just that; a maximum designed to promote awareness of the relative prices of medications. Around two-thirds of the products listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme can be expected to cost consumers less than this $15 maximum. The new cash-based safety net will encourage consumers to be more aware of the costs of their medications as they monitor their progress towards the $300 ceiling and then towards the $50 limit on additional expenditure.

The Government is committed to ensure that no individual or family needs to make aggregate contributions at the general rate which exceed $300. It has therefore been provided in the Bill that where the cost of a prescription at the general rate would take the aggregate of an individual or family's contributions over $300, the individual or family will have to pay only $2.50 for that prescription.

Persons moving from one category of safety net to another will be credited for the expenditure made on a concessional record card or the number of prescriptions already purchased on a general record card so that they are not disadvantaged. Thus, for example, people who begin receiving unemployment benefit during a year will be able to count their general patient contributions towards eligibility for a concessional safety net by having the number of scripts involved multiplied by $2.50 and the resultant amount entered on their concessional record card.

The Bill provides for all co-payments and safety net amounts to be indexed annually in line with the CPI. Safety net limits will of course be indexed from 1 January each year. Patient contributions will be indexed from 1 October each year.

In pursuit of the objective of ensuring an efficient distribution network for pharmaceuticals, the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia have reached agreement about pharmacy industry restructuring. Part of that agreement relates to a new level of pharmacy remuneration for the dispensing of Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme prescriptions.

The Bill amends the legislation related to the operations of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to enable it to give effect to the remuneration aspects of the current agreement and any future agreements which might be made between the Government and a pharmacy organisation representing a majority of approved pharmacists.

In the part year 1990/1991 it is expected that savings of $31.4m will result from the introduction of a higher maximum general patient charge and the new safety nets. This will increase to $245m in a full year.

While no savings are expected in this year as a result of the new arrangements for pensioners and concessionals, including the additional pension payments for pensioners, savings in later years will reach $185m.

These reforms underscore the Government's commitment to responsible financial management, to social justice, to improved health outcomes and to the provision of financial support for those least able to pay.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

This Bill would amend social security and veterans' affairs legislation to implement some of the measures announced in the Budget and in the February Statement earlier this year. The Bill would also provide for increased effectiveness and efficiency in social security and veterans' affairs administration.

Since November 1989 recipients of unemployment benefit, sickness benefit and job search allowance have been required to supply a tax file number as a precondition to payment of benefit. This initiative has proved to be successful, both in terms of increased efficiency in determining claims and in savings to the Social Security budget.
Consistent with that initiative are several others announced in the February Statement and the Budget.

The first of these will be the progressive extension of the requirement to provide a tax file number to most recipients of Commonwealth income support payments. This Bill would commence that process by requiring provision of tax file numbers by sole parent pensioners, recipients of family allowance and family allowance supplement and their spouses as a prerequisite to further payments of these benefits on or after 1 October 1990. The requirement to provide the tax file numbers of the spouse may be waived where the Secretary is satisfied that the person does not know the spouse's tax file number or cannot obtain that number or a declaration or statement relating to that number. Recipients of some veterans' affairs pensions and allowances may also be required to produce his or her tax file number and that of his or her spouse as a prerequisite to payment.

I will shortly be in a position to introduce another Bill which will require the progressive supply of tax file numbers for most social security payments from 1 January 1991. There will be similar legislation in respect of many payments made by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Community Services and Health.

In addition, I will introduce legislation to permit, from 1 January 1991, the matching of client information held by each of these departments and by the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs using equipment in the Department of Social Security. This will help in the detection of incorrect payments by highlighting situations where, for example, a person has provided inconsistent family profiles or income information to different Commonwealth agencies and is consequently receiving mutually inconsistent benefits.

The Government believes that these developments will contribute greatly to enhancing the integrity of the social security system. To enhance it further the Government has decided to offer a limited amnesty to ensure that, as far as possible, the rates of payment made to social security and veterans' affairs recipients on 1 January 1991 are correct. This Bill, therefore, provides for an amnesty which will encourage people who may at present be in receipt of incorrect payments because they have not informed the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs of changes in their circumstances to come forward and correct the situation. Although no overpayments will be raised against these people or prosecutions launched the savings from the correction of ongoing payments will be very substantial in net terms.

In order to limit avoidance of the social security and veterans' affairs assets tests by the disposal of property for either nominal or no consideration, the Bill would provide that income will be deemed to have been received from deprived assets at a minimum rate of 10% a year. However, to mitigate the impact of this measure where the disposition is relatively minor, the annual gifting limit will be significantly increased to $10000 for both single persons and married couples. This compares with the existing annual gifting limits of $2000 for single persons and $4000 for married couples.

This Bill also provides for the assessment of income on loans made by pensioners and beneficiaries assuming a minimum rate of interest. This rate will initially be set at 10% or the actual rate of return, whichever is the higher. The Minister for Social Security will be able from time to time to set a lower minimum interest rate when this is necessary.

For some time, a person living in a retirement village whose entry contribution exceeded a prescribed limit has been considered to be a ``home owner'' for the purposes of the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act. However, if a person's entry contribution is less than the prescribed amount, the person is considered a``non home owner'' and the person's property is taken to include the value of his or her entry contribution.

This Bill would provide for a person who has retained or acquired a life interest in his or her home, for example a person living in a granny flat, to be treated in the same way as a person who has paid to live in a retirement village. As a consequence the deprivation rules in the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act will no longer apply to them.

I will shortly introduce a further initiative in another Bill with the effect that, from 1 March 1991, cash and money in accounts of pensioners and beneficiaries will be assessed as returning yields as follows: for the first $2000 the actual rate of return, even if it is 0; for amounts of over $2000, the first $2000 at the actual rate of return and the remainder at 10% or the actual rate of return, whichever is the higher.

Pensioners and beneficiaries will have about six months to rearrange their cash or accounts. Another 40 FISP (Financial Information Service for Pensioners) officers will be operating from early in October this year to help pensioners arrange their investments.
The provisions will apply both to cash and to money in accounts held by pensioners and beneficiaries.

The free areas (the amounts people can earn before their Social Security payment is affected) provide substantial protection to pensioners with only small amounts to invest. For example, an age pensioner with no income apart from the pension and interest on investments would be able to invest up to $20000 (single pensioner) or up to $36000 (couples) at 10% interest and still receive maximum rate pensions because the interest income is within the pension free areas.
Pensioners and beneficiaries who re-organise their financial affairs will have higher overall disposable incomes than before.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a short statement about the Notice Paper and the business for today. It seems that it would facilitate the Government's difficulty in that it is short of business. Last night the Senate had to adjourn early because it simply ran out of business. Today we are suffering the continuing embarrassment of a Government that, although it has a long and complex program before it, has had to haul Bills out of committees to try to fill the program for today. In addition, the Government seeks that we now debate the Prime Minister's recent travelogue, which was adequately and thoroughly dealt with in the House of Representatives yesterday. This would not be on the Notice Paper for today in the Senate but for the fact that the Government simply has not got its program in order.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday when I complained about the state of business, I mentioned that we were told that for this week the broadcasting Bills would be on the Notice Paper. We were then told the broadcasting Bills would be withdrawn. Last night we were told that the Government wishes the broadcasting Bills to be dealt with today, at least in the second reading stage. We wish, of course, to be reasonable in these matters, but clearly this is not the way the Government should be conducting its program.

I remind the Senate of what I said yesterday, that the Senate has sat for very few days this year. There is an enormous backlog of work to be done. The Christmas bulge that we traditionally suffer and which results in poor quality legislation is clearly going to be worse this year than it has ever been before. Now that the Acting Manager of Government Business is in the chamber when I wish to address these matters to him-yesterday he had left-perhaps he will take this opportunity to explain to the Senate exactly what the Government is planning to do in relation to the program in the Senate, so that we all might be better informed and better prepared for the business and our responsibilities in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to respond to Senator Hill's statement. I have the real pleasure of being the Acting Manager of Government Business this week at a time when, I would have to concede, we are clearly having problems with the listing of Government Business on the Notice Paper. In order to ensure that the Senate had something productive to do during the next few days, the broadcasting Bills-which did not come into this place only yesterday; they have been around for a long time-have been listed. I would have thought the Opposition would have welcomed the opportunity to have them brought forward.
—Well, make up your mind.

—Senator Hill, you say, `Make up your mind'. I returned to Australia yesterday morning and took up this job. I have not had a chance to unmake my mind, but when confronted with what we ought to do in the next few days that seemed to me to be a reasonable thing to do. So far as the rest of the program today is concerned, there are in fact three lots of legislation-maritime safety and Customs as well as broadcasting amendments. The parliamentary zone is a matter that has been around for a long time and one in which Senator Reid in particular has shown an interest. I would be surprised if Opposition senators felt that it was inappropriate to deal with it.

SPEECH.PARA: In looking at the program for the next few days beyond today, however, there are a number of things which I can draw to the Senate's attention. We will, I hope, have the tax package out of the House of Representatives by tonight. If that is the case, then Opposition senators will have an opportunity to look at that tomorrow. That is major legislation which I am sure will take up some time, and Senator Watson would be pleased, I am sure, that it will be brought on.

However, as all of us feel our way through our new system of referring legislation to committees, we have to understand that that in itself is creating some difficulties for the Government in bringing business before the Senate. The reality is that the two pieces of legislation dealing with social security-that is, the legislation on pharmaceutical benefits and the legislation covering tax file numbers-which we hoped to have debated in the Senate next week, probably will not be brought on next week. We will find it almost impossible to bring them on next week, given that both will be referred to committees to be dealt with on Friday. I am led to believe from both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that they wish to have outside witnesses called before these committees, as well as having departmental officers there to explain through the Minister what is in the Bills.

Now if, as I suspect, that means the committees cannot finish with those Bills on Friday, then we will certainly be in the situation in which that social security legislation will not come in next week and we will have to wait another few weeks. I believe that it is in the interests of every senator to have a careful look at the way in which these committees are going to develop. Obviously, given that the committee system is new, we will all have to feel our way through the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have known that the tax file system was going to be referred to a committee all along. That is nothing new.
—One would have hoped it could have been done in a day.
—What do you mean `in a day'? It is on the day that is set aside for it, this Friday.
—But it is going to go beyond that; that is what you are not understanding. It will not finish on Friday.
—Why do you say that?

—Senator Hill, I have had some experience in dealing with Opposition senators. I will be very surprised if questions such as the payment of the $2.50 and the tax file numbers of themselves take only a short time, quite apart from interviews with an unspecified number of outside witnesses.
—But you knew about that. That does not explain why there is no business today.

—Senator Hill, I wish you were listening to what I was saying earlier in which I was trying to explain the problems that we may have for next week. I will endeavour tomorrow, because I do not wish to keep the Senate in the dark on what might happen next week, to outline a program for next week as well, at least informally, so that every senator will know where we are going.

SPEECH.PARA: It has got to be understood that in trying to get legislation before the Senate, it will have to get through the committees first, and it is not going to be easy to get all the pieces of legislation through the committees. If the experience that we had in the last sitting week with the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill was any indication, the time of the Senate is going to be taken up unnecessarily too often with repetitive debate, and that is not in the interests of anyone here. Nonetheless, I think that on the program for today there is more than enough to get through today. With the tax package there will be more than enough to get through tomorrow. Before the end of tomorrow I hope to indicate to the Opposition the kind of program we will have available for next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There are two aspects to this matter. One relates to the broadcasting Bills, and there are two of them. As I understand it, the reason they were taken off the program in the first instance was that the Government had amendments to those Bills. I notice that Senator Richardson has studiously avoided indicating whether there are to be amendments, given that these Bills have miraculously reappeared at such short notice. It simply would not be a proper manner of handling business to expect the Senate to debate amendments virtually unseen. I invite him to indicate whether there are to be amendments and, if so, what period we will have in which to consider those amendments, which presumably have been on the drawing board for some weeks now.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that particularly concerns me is the Minister's suggestion that somehow he has been taken by surprise in relation to the social security legislation. It has been perfectly clear to him, even though he might have been swanning around the world, that the Opposition has indicated publicly on several occasions that it intended to have this legislation, particularly the legislation on the question of the tax file number, thoroughly investigated by way of a public inquiry. We have adhered to that position and, of course, the Australian Democrats have also agreed with that course of action.

As I understand it, the most that the Minister has contributed to the discussions to date is an attempt to play off the Democrats and the Opposition parties against one another by suggesting that somehow they were both prepared to proceed with the second reading debate. That is not the situation and we have made that clear to the Minister. I cannot for the life of me understand why he is somehow pretending that the program has been interrupted by the course of action that we are intending to pursue. It has been made plain at all times that these are very serious matters which deserve fundamental examination.

Senator Richardson would know as well as anyone that there are a whole range of groups concerned about the privacy implications, because he chose not to allow the Privacy Commissioner even to address these matters in public or to attend a summit council organised by the Privacy Foundation, or to contribute in any way. He chose simply to have departmental officers there to take notes, to vet what was going on, but otherwise he chose to be particularly unhelpful.

I regard it as a very specious explanation for the Government to be suggesting that somehow we are at fault at the present time. The Government is well aware of the great concerns about privacy in the community. Until Senator Richardson is prepared to play the privacy game and allow the Privacy Commissioner to make some sensible statements on the issue so that we can understand the real concerns and then explore them in the committee, we will continue to decline to proceed further with the second reading debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: VISITS BY THE PRIME MINISTER TO NEW CALEDONIA, THE SOUTH PACIFIC FORUM, PAPUA NEW GUINEA AND JAPAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, I seek leave to make a statement relating to the recent overseas visits of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Mr President

I report to the Senate on four important visits the Prime Minister has undertaken recently within the Asia-Pacific region: to New Caledonia between 27 and 29 July; to the South Pacific Forum held in Port Vila, Vanuatu from 30 July to 1 August; to Papua New Guinea between 2 and 6 September; and to Japan between 16 and 20 September.

The South Pacific Forum is the pre-eminent regional body which brings together each year leaders from Australia, New Zealand and the Pacific Island countries. New Caledonia lies within our immediate region, while Papua New Guinea not only Australia's closest neighbour, but is a country with which we share important historical, economic and strategic interests. Japan is, of course, one of the world's great economic powers and our relationship with is one of Australia's most vital.
While each visit raised important issues of its own, a number of recurring and complementary themes emerged from this intensive period of regional contact.

For instance, in Tokyo the Prime Minister pursued with Prime Minister Kaifu and his Ministers Australia's concern to see decisive movement in the Uruguay Round negotiations, which are about to enter their final stage. The Prime Minister urged Japan to show true leadership, and thus exert pressure on the other majors-the EC and the United States-by further liberalising import controls on agricultural products, especially rice-not because Australia itself is a significant rice producer on a world scale, but because such a step would have far-reaching symbolic importance at this vital stage of the Uruguay Round negotiations.
These negotiations are of real importance to all countries around the world, especially to those of our South Pacific and South East Asian neighbours belonging to the Cairns Group.

Japan acknowledges the fact that the Uruguay Round negotiations will fail unless vital matters relating to agriculture are sensibly addressed. Similarly, leaders at the South Pacific Forum expressed satisfaction with the progress made over the past twelve months in mobilising support against the obnoxious practice of drift-net fishing and urged other countries to become party to the Wellington Convention. The Prime Minister was able to take that message personally to Japan, which has suspended drift-net fishing operations in the South Pacific. He told Japan's leaders that the suspension was welcome in the region but that our goal remained-and rightly so-a world-wide ban.

Also against the background of the Prime Minister's attendance at the South Pacific Forum and of his visit to Papua New Guinea, the Prime Minister was able to urge Japan to expand its constructive investment and development assistance in the region; the Island economies are in need of it, and it is important that major donors such as Australia and Japan maintain close and continuing dialogue.
Let me now report in turn on each of the Prime Minister's visits.
New Caledonia
The visit to New Caledonia at the invitation of Prime Minister Rocard was the first to the territory by an Australian Prime Minister since Mr Robert Menzies in 1941.

The program included meetings with Mr Louis Le Pensec, the French Minister for Overseas Departments and Territories, and with New Caledonian political leaders, including the President of the Territorial Congress, and leaders of the Southern, Northern and Loyalty Islands provinces. The Prime Minister also had discussions with the Mayor of Noumea, with the President of the FLNKS, Mr Neaoutyine, and the widow of the assassinated former President of the FLNKS, Madam Tjibaou. He was thus able to have discussions with a very wide range of New Caledonian leaders, representative of the political spectrum.

The Prime Minister was greatly impressed by the positive and constructive change in New Caledonia that has followed the signing of the Matignon Accords. All those involved in the Matignon process-President Mitterrand and Prime Minister Rocard, the independentist groups, and those who want a continuing constitutional link with France-deserve great credit for the way in which they have set aside old animosities and are working together to broaden New Caledonia's economic and political base. This will allow a genuine act of self determination to be made in 1998, leading to a viable long-term political status for the territory.

The Prime Minister offered Australia's continuing help in this process, including assistance in training young New Caledonians, broadening our economic links and encouraging, where we can, New Caledonia's links with the wider Pacific community.

He made it clear that, notwithstanding differences of policy over French nuclear testing and over the EC's agricultural policies-differences which the Prime Minister restated-and whatever the outcome in New Caledonia, Australia believes that France has a constructive and welcome political, cultural and economic role to play in this part of the world.

At the South Pacific Forum he was able to brief other leaders about his visit to New Caledonia. This was very much welcomed because, as Honourable Members will know, it remains an issue of great interest throughout the region.

As is the Prime Minister's practice at Forum meetings, he was able to have valuable bilateral discussions with a range of South Pacific leaders, including with Prime Minister Lini of Vanuatu and Ratu Mara of Fiji.

The Forum demonstrated again its practical relevance to the needs and concerns of the Pacific states. A wide range of regional issues was discussed in the usual frank and informal way, including matters relating to the environment, fisheries and regional multilateral organisations.

In particular, the United States Government's plans to dispose of chemical weapons stocks at the facility it has constructed on Johnston Atoll was the subject of understandably lively debate. Some Island leaders expressed concern for the safety aspects of the project. Others were concerned that the Pacific was coming to be seen as a dumping ground for the industrial waste of developed countries.

The Prime Minister put to his colleagues Australia's view that the Johnston facility would help to resolve a serious existing environmental problem-the deterioration of the stock of chemical weapons on Johnston Atoll-and would also help rid the world of these devastating weapons by making more possible the comprehensive global ban on their construction and use, for which Australia has worked so hard.

Let me say that the Prime Minister rejected totally the absurd notion being peddled by some that the destruction of chemical weapons on Johnston Atoll is somehow akin to the testing of nuclear devices at Mururoa.

He agreed fully with all Forum leaders that the Pacific should not become a waste dump, and that once the weapons at present on the island, those that may be found elsewhere in the region, and those being transhipped from Europe were destroyed, the facility should be closed down. Forum leaders welcomed, therefore, the United States Government assurance that it had no plans to extend the life of the facility beyond its current program. They also welcomed the United States' offer to discuss the facility in detail with Forum leaders and a delegation has since held useful talks in Washington.
Papua New Guinea

The visit, which included discussions with Prime Minister Namaliu and his Ministers, Opposition Leader Wingti and with a range of Provincial and business leaders, was the most extensive undertaken to Papua New Guinea by an Australian Prime Minister since 1976. As well as Port Moresby, the Prime Minister visited Mount Hagen, Madang and Rabaul. The welcome at each of those provincial centres was nothing short of overwhelming, and symbolised in the most dramatic and colourful of ways the great depth of the relationship between our two countries.

The relationship with Papua New Guinea remains one of our most important. Papua New Guinea is the largest recipient of Australia's bilateral aid; it is the fourth largest export market for Australia's manufactured products; it is our sixth largest overseas investment destination, with total net investments of about $1.8 billion, a figure which could exceed well in excess of $4 billion if major resource projects in Papua New Guinea proceed as planned. Over 11,000 Australians reside in Papua New Guinea and, over the past decade, some 2,000 Papua New Guineans have studied here under Australian Government scholarships and training awards.

Since 1983 the Government has worked hard to develop constructively and positively the relationship with our nearest neighbour. In December 1987 the Prime Minister signed with then Prime Minister Wingti the landmark Joint Declaration of Principles. In May last year he signed with Prime Minister Namaliu a Five Year Development Assistance Agreement. During his visit to Port Moresby an Agreement for the Protection and Promotion of Investment was signed.

The Joint Declaration of Principles spelled out that the relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea is one between two independent nations each responsible for its own destiny. A fundamental purpose of the visit to Papua New Guinea at this time was to underline this simple but vital fact, the significance of which is still sometimes not fully grasped and understood in parts of Papua New Guinea, Australia and elsewhere.

Throughout the visit, the Prime Minister stressed that Australia had no wish to intervene in solving Papua New Guinea's problems. If effective solutions are to be found, they must be solutions which emerge from within Papua New Guinea and are implemented by Papua New Guineans. It is neither possible nor desirable to turn the clock back. The Prime Minister also said it was important that the relationship between the two countries be taken forward very much within the context of the economic dynamism of the Asia-Pacific region and that Australia looked forward to the time when Papua New Guinea could itself become a member of APEC.

The totality of the Prime Minister's message was well understood and, indeed, welcomed by Papua New Guinea's leadership. For his part, Prime Minister Namaliu said that his Government wanted to speed up the shift in the balance of our aid program away from budget support and towards the more usual project support, with a view to the former being phased out by the end of this decade. The Prime Minister welcomed that goal and officials from the two countries will be taking the matter forward in the lead-up to the scheduled 1992 review of the current Development Assistance Agreement.

None of this means that Australia is walking away from Papua New Guinea. Both countries are too important to each other for that to be allowed to happen, and it is clear from the Government's actions over the past seven years that is not our policy. Australia and Papua New Guinea remain enduring friends and committed partners.

Honourable Senators will be aware of the enormous problems faced by Papua New Guinea over the past 18 months, the most significant of which have, of course, been those on Bougainville and the subsequent closure of the BCL Mine at Panguna.

That closure led, in one blow, to Papua New Guinea losing 37% of its export income and 17% of its budget revenue. The requirement for fundamental adjustment on the part of the Papua New Guinean Government and its people was obvious. Throughout the visit the Prime Minister was struck by the realistic appreciation and acceptance of the challenge. There was no attempt to turn away from it or to pretend that it was not there. And, to date, this attitude has been reflected in the implementation by the Papua New Guinean Government of the Structural Adjustment Program agreed with the World Bank and the IMF, and in which Australia has played a significant role. Prime Minister Namaliu and his Ministers and the people of Papua New Guinea are to be congratulated for this realistic commitment.

The problem of Bougainville does, of course, remain. In discussions in Port Moresby, the Prime Minister reiterated the Australian Government's position that Bougainville should remain an integral part of Papua New Guinea and that we fully support the Papua New Guinean Government's commitment to a political solution. He also reiterated our willingness to assist in the rehabilitation of Bougainville once an agreement has been worked out.

The Prime Minister raised again the Australian Government's concern about reported human rights abuses, both by the Papua New Guinean authorities and the Bougainville Revolutionary Army. In this context, he was disappointed that Bougainville leaders have, to date, declined the offer by the Papua New Guinean Government to invite an outside body to investigate allegations involving both sides.

Prime Minister Namaliu and his Ministers outlined frankly the problem confronting Papua New Guinea in law and order, a problem impinging on Australians themselves living in Papua New Guinea and a problem which, if left unchecked, would complicate the task of attracting much needed foreign investment. It was agreed to examine the challenges confronting Papua New Guinea in the l990s, with a view to determining how best the authorities there might meet the challenges and how Australia might best assist. It is planned that both sides will be in a position to pursue discussions further once the initial studies have been completed by the end of October.

Lastly, the Prime Minister discussed with Prime Minister Namaliu the heartening progress which has been made on the vital work of reforming Papua New Guinea's Constitution to allow the maintenance of more stable parliamentary majorities between elections.

Mr President, we should not forget that, while Papua New Guinea faces a complicated mix of problems, it is also a country rich in resources, both material and human. The Prime Minister's visit to the Porgera gold mine and his talks with many Papua New Guineans from all walks of life around the provinces, gave him ample evidence of that. With determined leadership and with continued assistance, from Australia and its other friends, there is no reason to believe that Papua New Guinea cannot realise its significant potential.

Melbourne's bid for the 1996 Olympics occupied the first two days of the Prime Minister's visit to Japan. Honourable Senators are, of course, aware of the outcome of that bid. Atlanta is to be congratulated and the Government is sure its people will stage a most successful Games to mark the centenary of the modern Olympics. At the same time, all Australians should feel immensely proud with the effort made on their behalf by the Melbourne Olympic Committee and by the many people, including the Leader of the Opposition, who put in so much effort to secure the Games. That the bid was not successful was not, in any way, a reflection on their effort and dedication or on the excellence of the bid itself.

The Prime Minister's two days of discussions in Tokyo encompassed talks with Prime Minister Kaifu and, separately, his Ministers for Foreign Affairs, Finance, International Trade and Industry, and Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries. He also met with former Prime Minister Takeshita and with the Chairperson of the Japan Socialist Party, Ms Doi. He addressed a meeting of the Australia-Japan Dietmembers' League, and 600 senior Japanese businessmen who were attending the annual All Japan Chambers of Commerce. He met separately with a dozen or so of Japan's foremost business leaders.

Mr President, the relationship with Japan is of the highest priority for Australia. Not only is Japan's economy of global importance but, during the course of this decade we will see Japan assume an increasingly important political role in world affairs, something which the Government welcomes and to which I shall return to later.But over and above our many shared global and regional interests, the bilateral relationship with Japan stands in its own right
- Two-way trade with Japan is now worth over $23 billion a year, with Japan being Australia's largest trading partner and Australia being Japan's sixth largest trading partner
- Japanese investment in Australia is worth over $36 billion or about 15% of total foreign investment in Australia and has increased by over 70% since 1986/87
- Japan is an important source of tourism for Australia,with visitors numbering about 350,000 in 1989

Impressive as these figures are, we aspire to an even more diversified and rich relationship with Japan. For instance, as the Prime Minister pointed out in Japan, of the $9 billion invested by Japan in Australia in 1988-89, some 92% is invested in tourism and real estate. Tourism is a major growth industry for us. But we do not see ourselves solely as a purveyor of leisure services; nor do we see particular economic advantage in selling real estate as an end in itself.
It is time, in short, for Japan to be more creative in its approach to investment in Australia and to joint ventures with us.

The bilateral relationship is well managed within the framework of the Australia-Japan Ministerial Committee and the Prime Minister's visit provided an opportunity to promote a further broadening and deepening. Mr Kaifu shared this objective, and it has been agreed that the existing Science and Technology Agreement will be revised so that cooperation under it can encompass not only pure research but also important areas of applied science. It was also agreed that officials would explore areas of further cooperation in clean coal technologies-the Brown Coal Liquefaction Project at Morwell in Victoria being a good example of what is possible.

Against the background of the fundamental changes made to the Australian economy since 1983, the Prime Minister discussed with Mr Kaifu, his economic Ministers and with Japanese business leaders, the mutual benefits to be gained through increased investment in the Australian manufacturing sector. In this context, he was pleased to be able to report that the Japanese Government and business leaders continue to take a very positive approach to the further development of the multifunction polis or MFP, as made clear through their:
- Welcoming of Adelaide as the location for the MFP;

- Agreement to nominate, as Co-Chairman of the International Advisory Group to report to me, its foremost business leader, Mr Eishiro Saito, Chairman of Japan's private sector umbrella group, Keidanren; and
- Agreement to send an investment mission to Australia in connection with the MFP

The Prime Minister assured both the Japanese Government and business leaders that the prejudices within Australia which, at one point, put the MFP at needless risk, represented very much minority views.

Mr President, as suggested earlier, the Prime Minister told Mr Kaifu-and he stated clearly in public speeches-that Australia wanted to give positive encouragement to Japan to play a wider role in global affairs, more commensurate with its economic standing. The Prime Minister wants to state clearly that he believes such a trend is inevitable and that it is in our interests.

It is self-evident that the world today, as it embarks upon its post-Cold War era, is very different to the world of the 1940s, when post-war global institutions were put in place. The time has clearly come for thought to be given about how those institutions, including the United Nations, might accommodate Japan's new role. Within the United Nations, for instance, there is obviously a range of possibilities, up to and including permanent membership of the Security Council. The question is a delicate one and involves a range of complex issues in which many countries have a legitimate interest. For that reason, the Prime Minister did not in any way seek to be prescriptive, but sought to highlight an important question which needs to be addressed.

Mr Kaifu was appreciative of the Prime Minister's comments and said he felt honoured that the Prime Minister had chosen to raise the issue. It was emphasised to the Prime Minister that while Japan wished to play a greater political role in world affairs, the terms of Japan's Constitution do not permit the deployment of Japan's armed forces abroad for combat operations. Japan is not contemplating any change to its Constitution, but this is, of course, a different matter from the foreshadowed change to Japanese legislation which will enable Japan to play a fuller and more active role within the framework of United Nations peacekeeping operations. The Government would welcome that.

Amongst the global issues discussed with Mr Kaifu and his Ministers, the most significant was the situation in the Gulf and its implications, both politically and economically. The Prime Ministers confirmed their respective support for the relevant UN Security Council Resolutions. Mr Kaifu outlined Japan's contribution to the multi-national effort in the Gulf and said that, within the framework of its Constitution, Japan was examining what else it might be able to do. He applauded Australia's resolute and quick action in meeting the crisis by dispatching naval vessels.

The Prime Minister expressed appreciation for Japan's contribution and said that, while it was clearly a matter for Japan itself to determine, any decision to do more would be understood by Australia.

In exchanging views about developments in the Soviet Union, both Mr Kaifu and Foreign Minister Nakayama outlined the current state of Japan-Soviet relations, including the outstanding question of the Northern Territories. The Prime Minister expressed the Government's hope that the issue would be resolved in a way acceptable to Japan, as Japan-Soviet relations were a matter of importance to all countries in the Asia-Pacific region.
Other issues covered in the Prime Minister's discussions included Antarctica, APEC, China, the Korean Peninsula and Cambodia:

- He outlined to Mr Kaifu the Australian-French initiative to preserve the unique Antarctic environment and the importance of the forthcoming Santiago Conference. Mr Kaifu expressed his hope for a satisfactory outcome at Santiago and agreed that our officials should continue to consult the lead-up to the Conference

- Mr Kaifu and his Ministers were especially supportive of the APEC initiative which the Prime Minister launched early last year. It was agreed that the two countries would continue to work together closely on this and other regional issues such as Cambodia

- On the Korean Peninsula, both Prime Ministers expressed concern about the failure, to date, of the DPRK to enter into its Safeguards Agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency, a matter of great importance in the context of proliferation.
Mr President,

As is obvious from this report, the Prime Minister's visits have, in each case, advanced concrete Australian interests and have, once again, demonstrated Australia's continued high standing in the region.

It is therefore a matter for regret that while the Prime Minister was in Japan, the Opposition Leader, Dr Hewson, delivered an address on foreign policy in which he made clear his belief that Australian influence in the region had become, in his word,``marginalised'', and that Australia's foreign policy was, again in his words,``in disarray''.

``Let me put this point quite bluntly,'' Dr Hewson said.``We are no longer the diplomatic and economic force we were in the Asia-Pacific region, because our relative economic situation has declined considerably . . . ''

Mr President, everything that emerged from the regional visits that are the subject of this report reveals this statement for what it is: the uninformed and opportunistic posturing of this apprentice.

Quite simply, Australia now stands at a high point of its constructive regional influence, and you need look no further than Cambodia on the political side and APEC on the economic, for proof of that.
Dr Hewson implies there was a lost golden era when Australia enjoyed greater positive influence in the region.
Is this successor to the Liberal Leaders who sent Australian troops into Vietnam referring to that sort of regional influence?
Is he talking about the wasted years of hypocrisy on trade under Malcolm Fraser, when this country preached reform but practiced inflexible selfcentred protectionism?
Does he suggest that Australia's influence was greater before this Government took the internationally recognised and applauded lead in the establishment of
- the Cairns Group?
- the new forum for Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation?
- the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone?
- the framework embraced by the UN Security Council for advancing the restoration of peace in Cambodia?

Mr President, Australia is a nation that has spoken for a long time about being part of the Asia-Pacific region. But it is only under this Government that real effect has been given to those words; it is only this Government which has defined economic enmeshment with the region as a key objective for this country for the coming decade; it is only this Government, and this party, that has never wavered in its unequivocal commitment to non-racial principles of immigration; and it is only under this Government that Australia's potential as an active, respected and positive partner in the region has started to be fulfilled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said a little while ago, this statement was put down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives yesterday and was debated there. It was not the Government's intention to put it down in the Senate at all, or else we would have had it on the Notice Paper for yesterday. But now that it is here-in an effort to fill the program-there are a few comments that I wish to make. In particular, I would like to take up the gratuitous criticisms that we found within the document by the Prime Minister of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). There is no doubt that Dr Hewson has got under the skin of the Prime Minister on foreign policy issues. There are a few matters that I believe, therefore, could be pursued in a little more detail in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I refer to the trip that the Prime Minister did not make, and that was the trip to the World Summit for Children, which has just recently been held in New York. This was a unique summit. It was an occasion that brought together some 71 world leaders-heads of state, heads of government-and it was so structured that to get a place at the table a country had to send either its head of state or its head of government. It could not send someone of lesser authority to take the chair. The summit had been purposely structured in that way as a test to see which of the world's leaders were prepared to put other priorities aside for one day and put the issue of children as the number one priority. Our Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, decided that he would not attend. He clearly put other priorities ahead of the issue of the welfare of the world's children.

It is an important issue because it is not well appreciated that 40,000 children in the world still die every single day of preventable causes-either diseases that are preventable through simple medicinal treatment or, alternatively, through malnutrition. I do not need to add those numbers up on a monthly or yearly basis but it comes to a staggering number of children of the world's community who are unnecessarily suffering. One must also remember that the world now contains, it is estimated, some 150 million children under the age of five who are malnourished. Some 250 million children of the world's community are still out of primary or secondary schools. Even the figure for primary schools alone is over 100 million. Therefore, it was considered, particularly by such bodies as the United Nations Children's Fund and by a number of world leaders, that there was a need to bring together the international community to address this issue and to look for ways in which as an international community we could make efforts to improve the lot of these suffering children.

Whilst I have referred to the costs to children in the Third World, it is important to remember that this is not simply a Third World problem. Many children are unnecessarily suffering within the First World, within the developed world. We are only too well aware, even in our own country, of children who are living in poverty. We continually remember the shallow promise of the Prime Minister in relation to poverty-that no child in Australia will live in poverty-when in fact more children are living in poverty than perhaps ever before. We have got to be made aware of and to remember the circumstances of child homelessness, of child abuse, of the consequences of family breakdown, the trauma suffered by children and, sadly, the increasing levels of youth suicide in our society.

The international community wanted to make it clear that when we address the lot of children, although we tend to concentrate on those who are dying and those who are malnourished in the Third World, we should not forget the issue of children in the developed world. The conference was held in New York. It was said by some that despite the enormous wealth of the United States, there are still one million children in the United States who are hungry. Anyone who was privileged enough to attend the conference in New York and therefore to walk the streets of New York could see the horrifying sights of children suffering in the most wealthy country in the world. So it was a responsibility, we believe, that went well beyond the Third World and one that was worthy of international debate.

It was staggering that 71 of the world leaders were prepared to join on this occasion. It was my privilege to be at least an observer member of the Australian delegation, and it has enabled me to come back and put to the Parliament and to other fora in this country some observations that I think we should take into account.

Perhaps I could do that by referring to the views that were put by some of the world leaders which, no doubt, would have been edifying to our Prime Minister if he had put this conference ahead of attending the football grand final or whatever was his higher priority. For example, we were reminded by President Chisano of Mozambique that in his country 45 per cent of primary schools were closed as a result of the civil war. Over half a million children in his country lost their lives as a result of that civil war.

I suppose that is the most primary application of an abuse of children that we could think of, where adults engage in conflict within a nation to serve their political objectives at the cost of suffering and death to so many children and at the cost of education to so many children, which will never be recovered. He wanted to stress to other world leaders the consequences that his nation had suffered from that sort of issue. The leader of Colombia, who was present, not surprisingly spoke of the issue of drug trafficking within his country and how the children of his country have suffered as a result of that both directly and, of course, indirectly. The abuse of children through drug trafficking is in many ways destroying the society of Colombia.

The presentation of the Prime Minister of Japan, Mr Kaifu, was interesting. It is interesting in itself that Mr Kaifu found time to travel to New York for this purpose. He stressed that the experience of Japan is that the education of children has been the key to the development and success of Japan since the Meiji restoration at the start of this century and urged other world leaders, therefore, to lift the priority of education within their own domestic programs.

The new President of Brazil, not surprisingly, addressed the environmental destruction that was occurring in his country and how that was causing suffering and detrimental consequences to children. President Havel of Czechoslovakia, in perhaps the most moving contribution to this summit, told how for generations the truth had been kept from the children of Czechoslovakia and how the subtle means of deprivation of information to children can so affect them in their adult lives. He said that parents felt that they had no alternative under the totalitarian regime in Czechoslovakia than not to tell their children the truth. But by parents not telling their children the truth, not only did the totalitarian regime and the suffering that resulted from it continue longer than was necessary, but also the whole development of the children was inhibited by that lack of information.

In fact, it was President Havel's argument that totalitarianism was overthrown when the children, the younger generation, revolted against this lack of information, demanded the truth, got the truth, and took action. For 71 of the world leaders, listening to this address was no doubt enlightening to them and it was uplifting to everyone else who was in the United Nations (UN) chamber listening to it. Similarly, the new Democratic President of Bulgaria drew the linkage of democracy to the rights of children and how children had suffered under the previous communist regime in Bulgaria.

Prime Minister Thatcher took a different point of view and again, interestingly, brought the debate back to the First World. She lay emphasis upon the responsibility of parents towards their children. Not surprisingly, a lot of the time of this conference was concerned with how States can help the lot of children by reallocating funding, reallocating priorities and so forth. Mrs Thatcher made the point that, even with those reallocations of moneys, we must not forget that the well-being of children largely is the responsibility of parents and, too often, parents do not meet that responsibility.

Mrs Thatcher spoke of children being deserted by their families, particularly by their fathers. It was interesting that she received a round of applause from the audience, and largely from the African women in the audience. It was interesting to see the African audience present applauding Margaret Thatcher for bringing to the attention of world leaders that, when they consider these priorities, they should not forget the responsibilities of parents towards their children that are too often forgotten.

The Tunisian leader spoke, not surprisingly, about the children who have been suffering in the occupied territories and told world leaders not to forget the suffering of Palestinian children through the ongoing conflict in the Middle East. We had a very interesting contribution from the leader of the Maldives, who spoke of the rising sea levels of the Maldives and how the children of his country had actually made presentations to him to take to New York and wanted him to communicate to other world leaders that unless we solve some of our environmental problems and, in his instance, the climatic problems that are resulting in rising sea levels, his coral atolls will be submerged and his children will suffer.

What I have tried to do, therefore, in a brief time is to bring to this place some of the diversity of ideas that came out of a conference of world leaders communicating with each other on the issue of children who are suffering and how the world community might address that issue. Certainly what came through the conference, to my mind, was the linkage between international development and child suffering and environmental development and child suffering.

In re-establishing that linkage it reminded us all that as we address the economic inequities and the suffering that follows from environmental abuse we are addressing to some extent the issue of children. What also came through was the cost of unprecedented population growth in the world and the need for that to be addressed if we are to give children the good health and opportunities which they deserve.

I made the point some time ago that what was stressed was the importance of education, in not just looking to a child's physical and material well-being during childhood but in understanding our responsibility to give that child the best possible education within the resources that are available.

It was disappointing that the Prime Minister was not prepared to make the trip to New York. I know that it is a long trip but Prime Minister Namaliu from Papua New Guinea was there and he was prepared to make the long trip for this purpose. The Prime Minister of Vanuatu, Father Lini, was there. He chose it as a high priority, despite the long distance. As an Australian, therefore, I very much regret that Mr Hawke was not there, not only to listen to what other leaders had to say but also, hopefully, to put a point of view on behalf of Australia.

I am pleased to have been able to bring that matter to the attention of the Senate. In concluding, although it was a little disappointing that not too many world leaders made concrete pledges that we could see would be clearly implemented in ways that would benefit children, there were some positive signs. For example, the conference was advised that the World Bank had stated its intention to increase primary health care lending from 3 per cent to 5 per cent. We might say that is still a very low percentage; nevertheless it is a step in the right direction and it has been clearly stimulated by conferences such as this.

The last point I make before I move on to the next subject matter is that we should be reminded that, incredibly, in the last decade that part of international ODA, official development aid, that has been earmarked for education and health within the world community has in fact dropped from 17 per cent to 10 per cent. I think this further demonstrates why we should be facing up to these issues, addressing them and making the right decisions.
I will make a few comments on two other matters. I want to mention the issue of Cambodia, which is referred to in the Prime Minister's statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a glorious record on this one-getting it wrong every time.

—If Senator Schacht had the courtesy to listen, he might be better educated on this important issue. I bring to the Senate's attention the fact that, despite the efforts of the world community to find a solution, a comprehensive settlement, to the Cambodian conflict-and they are efforts which we of course applaud and encourage-violence in Cambodia is increasing.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Schacht was interested in this debate he would have no doubt noted that in the last few days the Khmer Rouge, which the Australian Government now appears to be indirectly supporting, has been bolstered by its first shipment of Chinese tanks-we are told that this is in an environment of a settlement-and is preparing a major attack to seize the north-western province of Svay Rieng, which is considered to be one of Cambodia's most important cultural and historic regions. The violence and death is continuing on the ground in Cambodia. Therefore, before we start congratulating ourselves on the achievements towards a settlement, perhaps we should recognise that Cambodians are suffering and dying every day as the civil war continues.

We should also recognise that many steps remain, even if a settlement can be ultimately achieved between the Khmer factions as endorsed by the international community, particularly through the Permanent Five and the Paris process. At the moment the United Nations has no idea of the sort of administrative or military role it will have to meet and the sort of military force and administrative grouping it will have to apply. Under the Permanent Five agreement, the UN force would have to contain and disarm the Khmer factions, but as yet none of the four Khmer factions has been prepared to give information to the UN as to the size of their forces, what armaments they have-and we now see that the Khmer Rouge is bringing tanks into the conflict for the first time-and where their troops are dispersed. Therefore, at the moment the United Nations-and this information comes from the Under Secretary-General responsible in this area, Mr Ahmed-has no idea of the size or composition of the force it will have to contribute.

Therefore, if a settlement can be concluded through the Paris conference, when that is eventually held, the United Nations will then have to send a military mission to Cambodia and again ask the Khmer factions whether they are prepared to give that required information. Only then can it start assessing the size of the force that will be necessary to meet that first phase of its responsibility, and only then can we in this country start assessing what sort of force will be expected of Australia as a contribution to the United Nations.

Major developments of infrastructure, which seem to have been completely overlooked by this Government, will then have to occur. The United Nations advises me that before it can take the next step, before the military function starts, major work will have to be done on ports, roads, airfields and communications. Of course, the question then is who will pay for this, how much time will it take, and how will these infrastructure works be completed.

After that, which is a massive task in itself, comes the responsibility of returning all the 300,000-odd refugees and displaced persons. Before they return an atmosphere of confidence has to be created. Apart from that, the logistics and administration of their return to Cambodia, you would appreciate, Madam Deputy President, is an enormous task. Also, before they can be returned, the country must be cleared of mines and other security mechanisms put in place to ensure their safety. Anyone who has studied this subject at all will recognise the extent to which Cambodia has been mined in the most horrific way and the enormity of the task of de-mining the Cambodian countryside.

After all that has been achieved, the UN Administration will be required to take over the functions of the government, including internal security, which will require a large international police force. No real thought has yet been given as to the size of that force, who will constitute that force and what responsibility will fall to Australia in that regard. It will also be required to take over the administrative responsibility for communications, finance, foreign affairs and defence. Never before has the UN been given such a mandate. Never before has the UN attempted to take over such widespread responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you want them ever to try?

—Senator Schacht should debate what is really ahead rather than try to camouflage it in a shallow, simplistic way, as has been continually promoted in this chamber by the Minister. Let us address the real issues that lie ahead. We can then have a real debate about what needs to be done to meet those issues and what contribution Australia should be making in that regard. Just consider for a moment what is needed in the United Nations taking over the responsibility of finance and all its functions, a central bank and so forth for Cambodia, which it has never done before. The administrative arm of the United Nations will also have to devise an electoral system; supervise the registration of parties and voters; provide an electoral commission; and conduct, supervise and ensure free and fair elections.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the UN can succeed in these objectives will depend not only on the goodwill and material support of countries such as ours but also on the good faith and cooperation of the four Khmer factions, very little positive evidence of which we have seen so far.

What I have said recently-and I take this opportunity to reiterate it-is that if the factions were genuine in being prepared to move to this next phase of a settlement, they could demonstrate that goodwill and good faith by now agreeing to a cease-fire. Until they have agreed to a ceasefire, the UN cannot properly start the massive task that lies before it, which I have sought to outline briefly today.

When an attempt at a cease-fire was last made at the Tokyo talks some months ago, the Khmer Rouge, as honourable senators will recall, boycotted those talks: it was not even prepared to discuss the issue of a cease-fire. I have to concede that those of us who remain-unlike Senator Schacht-sceptical about the goodwill of the Khmer Rouge in this settlement process still wonder whether we will actually see it being prepared to enter into a cease-fire, put down its arms, cooperate with the United Nations in the enormous and complex task that lies ahead and enter into a democratic election process, which the optimists believe that it will. Nevertheless, for the sake of Cambodia, one must retain not only hope but also a willingness to get in there and make our modest contribution as a country that has recognised the suffering endured by the innocent Cambodian people for so long and recognised that they deserve so much better.

If I had time, I would have liked to talk also about the issue of China and the gratuitous comments of the Prime Minister in relation to the very successful trip of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to China, a trip that the leaders of the Labor Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —We will give you leave.

—I am very tempted to take it, but I think it would incur the wrath of Senator Schacht, who wants an opportunity to contribute. The honourable senator has invited me to seek an extension of time because of the disastrous state of the Notice Paper and the Government's longing on this occasion for those who are prepared to fill the day's business. It is regrettable that the Australian Government has not been prepared to take to China's leaders the concerns that we all feel about the ongoing human rights abuses that are occurring in China, and to make it clear to China's leaders that a normal relationship is desirable, which includes participation in celebrations such as the Asian games, looking to the Australian taxpayers to help through aid in the development of China, and contributing in our modest way in defence cooperation, which I think we do principally through goodwill visits such as ship visits. It is simply not possible to have that type of normal relationship with China when it is not prepared to accept the universally accepted minimum standards of human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the message that we took to China's leaders. Although they might refer to these matters of human rights as internal matters, they are not internal matters any longer, they have been accepted as a norm by the international community. If China is to take its place as a leader of the international community, and we have given it leadership responsibilities as a member of the Permanent Five in Security Council, then it should be playing a leadership role in meeting reasonable human rights standards rather than abusing the internationally accepted minimum standards.

Dr Hewson took these concerns to the Chinese leaders direct, and at first hand. We remind the Australian Government that that is the correct approach and that isolation is not going to change China. The Government is not going to change attitudes unless it is prepared to communicate. I certainly commend Dr Hewson for his courage. I regret that the Prime Minister has had to degrade the debate by personal attacks upon him rather than be prepared to debate the issues at the level which they deserve.

Under the head of this travelogue of the Prime Minister, I am at least pleased that I have been able to bring to attention three important matters: the International Summit on Children and our disappointment that Prime Minister Hawke let Australia down in the way that he did; the issue of Cambodia, which is so important but which requires so much more work and effort; and the ongoing issue of human rights in China, which requires the attention of all of us, and ongoing pressure from all of us, until that situation is improved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, in his introductory remarks to this debate on the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), said that no warning was given yesterday that this debate would come on. I am informed that at the Whips meeting yesterday it was indicated by the Government Whips that this debate would be listed for today and that there would be a full debate on the Prime Minister's statement. I think we should clear that matter up.
—The Prime Minister's statement was not available until this morning.

—Senator Hill said in his opening remarks that no indication was given yesterday that there would be a debate today. I just wanted to clear that matter up. The Government Whips did indicate yesterday at the Whips meeting that there would be a debate today on the Prime Minister's statement, and warning was given.

SPEECH.PARA: After hearing Senator Hill's remarks, I am not surprised that he spent most of his time talking about everything else other than what was in the statement, because the Opposition's record on foreign affairs matters over the last few years has been abysmal, to say the least.
