It has lacked consistency, and it has been episodic. As most commentators have said, the Government has turned foreign affairs into a real plus in its achievements during its period in office. I will come back to that matter later in my remarks.

First of all, the Prime Minister's statement deals with a number of countries which he visited as part of Australia's relations: a visit to New Caledonia, a visit to Papua New Guinea (PNG), attendance at the South Pacific Forum meeting and a visit to Japan. I would like to comment on a number of the remarks that the Prime Minister has made which I believe add to the Australian Government's policy of having a constructive relationship with the countries of our immediate region, as well as with Japan, our most important economic trading partner.

I will deal, first of all, with New Caledonia. I know that Senator Hill did not mention New Caledonia in his remarks. I am disappointed that he did not, since long before he was a shadow spokesman on foreign affairs he has been a consistent advocate of a peaceful settlement and supporter of the rights of the Kanak people to self-determination in New Caledonia. I congratulate him on his role in that area.

I think that the developments in New Caledonia over the last couple of years since the Rocard Government came to power in France have been very encouraging. Though I have been a great critic of French foreign policy in the South Pacific over many years, I give credit to the French Government, particularly to Prime Minister Rocard, for what he has achieved in discussion with the Kanak people and the Caldoches, or the French settlers in New Caledonia, and in reaching an accord, called the Matigon Accord, which is a way forward for a peaceful resolution to an act of self-determination in 1998. All this has been affected by the tragic assassination of Jean-Marie Tijbaou and Yeweine Yeweine in May of last year. Senator Hill and I attended the funeral of those two outstanding leaders with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. It was an emotional moment for anybody in attendance at that funeral service. The attendance of the Prime Minister of France, Mr Rocard, and the way he conducted himself through those funeral ceremonies, meant that the potential for an outbreak of violence was greatly reduced. I think that Prime Minister Rocard--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a great credit to his country.

—He was a great credit to himself and his country. The fact that there was no outbreak of violence was due to the way Prime Minister Rocard conducted himself. Since then, the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front (FLNKS) has elected new leaders. Francois Burk was elected to be leader of the Union Caledonienne, the largest party in the FLNKS, and Mr Niotene was elected as the leader of the FLNKS. The constructive discussion that has gone on with the French Government and the RPCR, the main French settler party, still gives one considerable hope that a peaceful settlement will be reached leading up to the referendum to be held in 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has played a constructive role. I think we have been correct through the 1980s in insisting that there be a process in which the Kanak people have the right to self-determination rather than the sterile policies of the Chirac Government, which in many ways contributed to the violence that occurred, including the massacre at Ouvea. I excuse neither side from violence. No-one should support violence in any form.

The provocative policies of the previous Chirac Government, as they were implemented in New Caledonia, contributed to the violence and, ultimately, to the deaths of a number of people. Without going into the details of it, I believe that the assassination of Tjibaou by Djubelly Wea can be traced back to the incidents at Ouvea in 1988.

I believe the Australian Government and the Australian people can take credit for following a consistent line on New Caledonia which will, I hope, lead to a peaceful settlement in which the people of New Caledonia determine whether they will have independence or a different association with the French Government. It is a matter for them to determine, not for us or for other countries.

The visit of the Prime Minister to New Caledonia was the first of a Prime Minister from Australia since 1941, when the then Prime Minister, Robert Menzies, visited. I think that visit took place as a result of wartime measures, when the Australian Government intervened to overthrow the Vichy French Administration that had control of New Caledonia, for Australia's security purposes during the Second World War. Also, I had the great honour to lead the first parliamentary delegation to New Caledonia in April 1988.

In his report to the Parliament the Prime Minister mentioned his visit to PNG. No doubt, at the moment, the most important relationship that we have to deal with in Australia is our relationship with PNG. There has been plenty of publicity about the very difficult situation in Bougainville. There has been criticism of the Australian Government's response in providing assistance to the PNG Government-helicopters, et cetera. I should point out to those critics that this was a response of the Australian Government to a democratically elected sovereign government of PNG asking for assistance. I do not believe there is anything wrong with an Australian government providing assistance to a democratically elected government.

It should not be forgotten that since 1975, no matter what the problems of PNG have been-economic or social-there have been a number of peaceful changes of government in PNG. Whether we agree or disagree with the structure of the PNG Constitution that creates some instability in the arrangements for government, the thing is that the Constitution has survived, that governments have been defeated on the floor of the PNG Parliament, and that the losers have accepted the decision of the Parliament that they go out of office and another party comes into office. There have been several changes of government since 1975. When one looks at the rest of the developing world, one sees that that is not a record that many other countries can match.

Those people in Australia and elsewhere who may be pessimistic about the future opportunities in PNG for peaceful settlement should also weigh up the fact that, despite all of those difficulties, PNG has a vibrant democracy that is working: it is accepted that the Parliament is the supreme body in the government of the country. And that is something which we should give credit for and which should not be ignored.

Of course, Australia, as the major aid donor to PNG, is called upon to play a critical role. At the moment we are giving approximately $250m in untied aid to the Budget of PNG. As a percentage of the Budget expenditures it is declining, and I think we would all welcome that because any country that has to rely on one other country for a large percentage of its Budget obviously is going to have some problems. The big debate that has been conducted in some areas of Australia is whether that untied aid should become tied aid. I know-as a member of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which is presently conducting an inquiry into Australia's relations with PNG-that it is a debate as to whether this untied aid should become more tied.

It is a very difficult question to resolve. We can say that with tied aid we can make sure that the money we give is directly tied to specific projects and spent in accordance with the wishes of the donor country to ensure, from our perspective, that the money is wisely spent; conversely, if we do that we can then be accused of being neo-colonialist and paternalistic and interfering with the rights of a sovereign country. I have to say I do not think there is a conclusive way to resolve that argument on either side. It is a matter of discrete judgment, from time to time, as to how we judge those issues.

We have a special relationship with PNG as the ex-colonial power and, therefore, we have to accept some responsibility for providing Budget assistance. But I believe that in the longer run it probably is in our interests as well as, above all else, in PNG's interest that more of that aid money be given as tied aid for specific development programs. I think that will be a major issue that the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee will deal with.

The last thing which should be mentioned about PNG-again returning to the need for constitutional change-is that many people in Australia have been recommending to PNG that its Constitution be changed so that the six-monthly motion of no confidence can be removed and there is more stability. I think it is a bit paternalistic for Australia to suggest to other countries how to go about constitutional change when, for nearly 100 years, we have been almost singularly unsuccessful in Australia in being able to change our own Constitution through referendum and when, on any rational judgment, it should have been updated on a number of occasions from what was written in the 1890s. We should be a little careful in moralising to the people of PNG about their Constitution, which, in fact, we helped impose on them as part of independence in 1975. Obviously, there has to be some adjustment and there is some indication that more of the politicians of PNG recognise the need for that.

The Prime Minister attended the South Pacific Forum. The thing that ought to be noted about the South Pacific Forum is that it is one of the few forums in the world that has present a majority of developing countries which have democratically elected governments. The countries that are represented in the South Pacific Forum include-and I hope I have got the full list here-PNG, Australia, New Zealand, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Kiribati, the Federated States of Micronesia, who were recently added, Western Samoa, the Cook Islands, Tonga, Niue, Nauru and Vanuatu.

There is also Fiji, but I would exclude that from this list because the countries I have just read out have democratic forms of government. It should be a matter of considerable pride that in this region of the world there is an overwhelming acceptance of the democratic system of government-of election of governments into parliaments with the rights of dissent and argument.

Of course, it has been a great tragedy of the 1980s that Fiji, one of the major countries in the region, has had a military coup and has now adopted a new Constitution that by no stretch of the imagination can be called democratic. It has a number of features about it which are well known in Australia and which we object to. It is racist and the electoral system is gerrymandered to ensure that one group of people-not just one race, but one group of people within that race-can dominate the government for the foreseeable future. That is unfortunate, and the Australian Government has made it clear that, although we do not want to interfere with the internal affairs of countries, we do not accept the Constitution.

Of course, there are other countries in the South Pacific which, hopefully, one day will be represented as independent-that is, New Caledonia and Tahiti. I think that, in any consideration of our region, our role in the South Pacific Forum is to encourage further development and, as we now enter the second decade of independence for most of those countries, to ensure that that continues. It is a matter of considerable pride that I do not think there is any other area in the world with as many developing countries that have accepted a democratic form of government.

That is not to say that there will not be strains. For example, only recently in Tonga, which has a peculiar Constitution, to say the least-a mixture of monarchy, autocracy and democracy-there have been pressures for a more democratic form of government. It is interesting to note that the people have been voting to support the election of members of parliament who want a more open and representative form of government. I believe the Australian Government should make it clear to the Government of Tonga that we support those developments because it means a more democratic form of government will emerge.

The Prime Minister's visit to Japan dealt with a number of issues which I think are important to Australia. One of them does not seem to be very important, but anybody who has been to Japan would find it most important as it affects Japan's attitudes in foreign affairs, and that is the question of the so-called northern territories. A number of very small islands off the immediate north coast of Hokkaido used to be Japanese but, as a result of the Second World War, they were taken by the Soviet Union and have not been handed back. If one visits Japan, it is one foreign affairs issue that is raised consistently by the Japanese. Unless it is resolved I suspect the relationship between Japan and the Soviet Union will always be cool. There are indications now that the Soviet Union may be at least willing to hand back a couple of those islands. I welcome that move because I believe it will mean that the Soviet Union and the Japanese Government will be able to adopt a much more mature relationship that will lead to economic advantages for the region.

The Prime Minister pointed out in his statement that he had discussions with the Japanese Government and business people about the establishment of the MFP-the multifunction polis-in South Australia. As a South Australian senator, I welcome that. I note with considerable interest that the Japanese have appointed a Mr Saito, one of Japan's leading businessmen, to chair the Japanese committee to work for the establishment of the MFP and that an investment mission from Japan will shortly visit Australia looking at investment opportunities in the MFP.

I also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that recently the Premier of South Australia was in western Europe talking to the French, the British Government and other European governments about European investment in the MFP and he was encouraged by the response. As Japan is our major trading partner, it is quite clear that Japan will be central to Australia's economic interests in the foreseeable future. We are, I think, the sixth largest trading partner for Japan. With those statistics, whether people like it or not, Australia has to have a very detailed, mature and sensible relationship.

It has been very unfortunate that in the last few years some elements in Australian politics have been willing to play what I would call the racist card and, in an underlying way, to create some xenophobia in Australia about the role of Japanese investment in Australia and Japanese tourists visiting Australia. We cannot have it both ways. We cannot have our economy and our standard of living overwhelmingly reliant on Japanese trade and sell large amounts of raw materials to Japan and import cars, et cetera, from Japan, which everybody has no difficulty in purchasing, and then go round saying something nasty about the Japanese involvement in this country. That sort of underlying racist issue has to be put down without equivocation.

The Prime Minister in his speech to the Parliament yesterday drew attention to what I would not say was a policy on foreign affairs, because I do not think it stands up as a coherent policy, but a number of difficulties the Opposition has with foreign affairs. The first thing I want to draw attention to is Cambodia. Senator Hill referred at length to Cambodia. I do not think that Senator Hill can talk with any credibility about Cambodia as he has been consistently wrong on Cambodia. The Opposition, when in government, was consistently wrong and it has been consistently wrong in opposition. One of the classic statements of all time was that by Senator Hill in an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's radio program the World Today on 18 July 1990 from Phnom Penh. In response to a question Senator Hill said:

I think the prospect of any comprehensive settlement, any settlement that involves a role for the Khmer Rouge, is really not going to succeed. The sooner we recognise that a political settlement that involves one party that simply won't participate in a political resolution of the problem, the better off we're going to be because we can then move to alternative possibilities.

That was at 12 o'clock on 18 July on radio. At 3 o'clock, just three hours later, it was announced that the P5-the permanent five members of the Security Council-had reached agreement on two of the critical matters to get a comprehensive settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—On 18 July. Senator Hill was in Cambodia. Fortunately I was in Australia listening to his remarks. Then, three hours later, I heard the announcement from Paris of the P5 decision on two areas out of five-that is, a military solution and administrative arrangements. This was overwhelmingly based on the Australian comprehensive peace program called `the red book'.
—Do you think that was blooper of the year?

—We ought to put it on Graham Kennedy's home movies as blooper of the year. Two days after the P5 reached that agreement, the Americans announced that they would have dialogue with the Vietnamese for the first time in 15 years. That dialogue has now started. The P5 has now reached agreement on all areas in dispute, including China. China has made it quite clear to the Khmer Rouge that it either agrees to a comprehensive settlement or it is on its own. The Supreme National Council, despite all the arguments, backtracking and disputes between the Cambodian factions, has started to meet. There will be a meeting before the end of this year of all the parties, which will lead to a settlement. That is a much more optimistic attitude than the Opposition ever expressed. Above all else, the ultimate hypocrisy of the Opposition is that when it was in government from 1979 to 1982, it supported the Khmer Rouge being represented in the United Nations (UN) as part of the government of Cambodia. Andrew Peacock resigned because he could not stomach the hypocrisy of the Malcolm Fraser position. So, for the Opposition to accuse us of getting into bed with the Khmer Rouge is rank hypocrisy when for three years, when it was fully known about the genocide of the Khmer Rouge, Senator Hill and his Party supported in the UN its right to be recognised as the legitimate government of Cambodia. Now they say that the Khmer Rouge is not going to take part in this process.

SPEECH.PARA: At any time during the last 10 years did the Opposition support the Heng Samrin Government or the Hun Sen Government in its attempts to fight the Khmer Rouge? No, it did not. It has not done one thing to support the Phnom Penh Government in its fight against the Khmer Rouge. The Opposition has washed its hands of it all the time and now it says that we cannot trust the Khmer Rouge. The Opposition has done nothing to support the Phnom Penh Government in its 10-year fight against the Khmer Rouge. It has tried to have it both ways and in the end it has blood on both sides of its hands.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what are you doing now? You are embracing the Khmer Rouge.

—We have put forward a comprehensive peace settlement that has been adopted by the P5 and recognised by the countries of South East Asia, particularly Indonesia, as the basis of a peace settlement for Cambodia. What really must get up Senator Hill's nose is the fact that the Labor Government in Australia-not a part of South East Asia-has come forward with a plan that has been the breakthrough for a peace settlement in Cambodia, the most intractable foreign affairs problem in the world in the last 30 years. We have put forward a policy that will mean that the 50-year war for Indo-China will probably come to an end in the next 12 months. What have those opposite done, expect recognise the Khmer Rouge to be the official government in the UN? The Opposition has no credibility at all on the issue of Cambodia. It is almost painful to hear it try to explain and be pessimistic and do everything possible to talk down the Australian Government's comprehensive peace settlement. It has been doing that for 12 months and has been wrong every time. It will be consistently wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer to another area of foreign policy. Last year Senator Hill was downplaying the Prime Minister's initiative for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) group. Senator Hill went so far in this chamber as to have an inquiry referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade based on the view that once an inquiry was under way the evidence would come forward to show that APEC was a myth, that it was not going to happen, that it would not work. Well, he has been disproved on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you say that? Why do you say that the reference was how to make it work?
—Senator Hill--
—When you are on your feet, you might start telling us about the achievements of APEC.
—Let us make it quite clear--
—Order! Debates in the chamber should not be conversations between interjectors and senators with the call. Honourable senators should address the Chair.

—The Opposition was hoping that the APEC initiative would fail. That is why it wanted a reference to be put to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It wanted that evidence to come forward. Of course, the Opposition has dropped right off it now because APEC has proved to be a success. The countries of the region are involved in it and have taken it up. It now provides us with a considerable opportunity to develop economic relations within our region to the advantage of the region and this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We have Senator Hill going on about Dr Hewson's wonderful record in terms of the human rights issue in China. Yet he fails to mention something which is quoted today in an article by Greg Sheridan in the Australian, which is that Dr Hewson has previously said that Australia should have a foreign policy that is selfish and more in the interests of Australia and that we should ignore the human rights issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hewson has not said that, has he? Where has Hewson said that?

—I want to bring to the attention of Senator Hill the fact that in the last 12 months to 30 June the Australian Government has taken up human rights abuses with 87 different countries, including such countries as the United States of America and the People's Republic of China. We have without fear or favour taken up human rights activities. No previous government has ever undertaken the range of human rights activities that have been addressed by the present Government. This was certainly not done by the Opposition when it was in government. This is a record that we are proud of and that stands alone from that of any previous government. It is a record that certainly gives us credibility to raise with any country human rights issues and human rights violations. I am very proud to be part of a government that is now one of the leading human rights exponents of any country and which addresses this matter without fear or favour.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I want to draw the Senate's attention to the remarks in the article by Greg Sheridan in today's Australian. Greg Sheridan is by no means a left wing supporter of the Australian Labor Party. I think he would not object to being described as a radical right winger in the emphasis he puts on issues dealing with politics, foreign affairs, economics and so on. In an article which appeared in the Australian today under the headline `How Labor stole the foreign policy show' he said that the coalition has been left with virtually nothing to say. He went on:
It is fairly lame for the Opposition to argue that the Government is not pursuing Australia's interests with sufficient vigour given the creation of APEC.
He criticises the Opposition over its `tawdry' performance on Cambodia. He does say something about Senator Hill, which I want to put on record. He states:

Senator Hill is universally regarded as intelligent, well informed and well motivated. But he is no match for a workaholic foreign minister constantly briefed by hundreds of foreign policy specialists.
I think that article sums up the fact that the Opposition is incapable of a coherent foreign policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose those who are listening to this debate could be forgiven for wondering what it is we are debating. I should remind the Senate that we are debating the parliamentary statement dated Tuesday, 9 October 1990, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to visits to New Caledonia, the South Pacific Forum, Papua New Guinea and Japan.

SPEECH.PARA: While the two previous speakers in this debate have used the opportunity to range far and wide on matters of foreign policy, I would like to draw from what the Prime Minister has said a conclusion about where this Government stands in relation both to internal policy and external policy. The manner in which the Prime Minister has approached other countries, the attitudes that he has carried to those other countries, the requests that he has made of those other countries and the way in which he has reported back to this Senate indicate a great deal about the attitudes of the Government and the way in which it places emphases and priorities in certain areas and not in other areas.

I would like to pick up on particular things which the Prime Minister has said in this statement. I want to indicate where I believe the emphases are wrong and where I believe the Government has taken us in a wrong direction with respect to this statement in our relationship with other countries and, by implication, also with respect to its policies within this country. I also want to indicate how the Australian Democrats would approach many of these situations in a different way.

Let me begin by saying that I believe that in a very fundamental way the Prime Minister, this Government and, indeed, the Opposition, are totally misreading the portents of current history. We have in place a number of developments and trends which are being pointed out to governments, which need to be addressed urgently in relation to where we need to go in 10, 15 or 20 years time and which are being ignored by this Government and this Opposition.

I raised with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) just in the last sitting week the Government's attitude, for example, to the intergovernment panel on climate change (IPCC). I would remind the Senate that the IPCC, composed of some 300 leading scientists on climate change from over 20 countries, has recently recommended that as a matter of urgency the world needs to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by between 60 and 80 per cent. Although the Senate chamber is not particularly full at the moment, I am sure that those senators who were present on that occasion will recall that the chamber almost broke up in loud guffaws. The Minister concerned dealt with the question as though it was trivial and somewhat of a joke. Quite clearly, the Government has not even begun to address that question which impacts not only on this country but on every country.

Indeed, by extension, let me say that I am a member of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which has before it at the moment a reference on greenhouse. That Committee has had a number of government departments before it. It has had Treasury, Land Transport, and Primary Industries and Energy. Specifically, it has had before it the people from those departments who are charged with the responsibility of formulating and advising government on policy in relation to greenhouse. Not one of those departments would indicate that the Government has any policy whatsoever in relation to what the Government itself in its own paper on sustainable development has recognised as the most important matter which will determine both internal and external policy well into the future-into the next century.

When those witnesses who appeared before the Industry, Science and Technology Committee were asked when they would have a policy in place in relation to the limitation of greenhouse gas emissions, not one of them could state a time. And yet, my understanding is that by as soon as February next year this Government will have to have in place its position which it will take to the international forum, which throughout 1991 will formulate the international agreement on the reduction and limitation of greenhouse gas emissions in the future in a similar way to the international agreement on ozone depleting emissions under the Montreal Protocol.

It is in the context of the decision announced just in the past couple of days in relation to the south-east forests that the Government has attempted yet again to compromise very important environmental considerations for perceived short term economic gain. In that context Mr Hawke has gone forth to the South Pacific Forum and to these other nations with certain attitudes and priorities which we believe to be totally wrong.

Senator Schacht in his address a moment ago mentioned a number of nations in the South Pacific Forum and indicated that, fortunately, many of them have some form of democratic government. I share with him the view that that is to be highly commended, and to the extent that we have played some part historically in that process we should be quite proud. However, he mentioned that Fiji was not one of those nations.

I remind the Senate that, as the consequence of an act which occurred over 100 years ago, Fiji today does not have a democratic government. The attempt by Britain to solve the short term economic problem of labour supplies in the sugar industry by bringing Indian indentured labour into Fiji can be pointed to fairly and squarely as the cause of the present strife in Fiji, with the enormous racial conflict between indigenous Fijians and the descendants of the Indian people who were brought in over 100 years ago. It should be an object lesson to us that, in attempting to address economic problems, we need to take a much longer term view than that which this Government is taking.

On the first page of the Prime Minister's speech, he mentions that he went to Tokyo and spoke with the Prime Minister and various other Ministers in relation to trade relations in an attempt to gain greater access for Australia's agricultural products on the Japanese market. He says specifically on page 11:
. . . it is only this Government which has defined economic enmeshment with the region as a key objective for this country for the coming decade . . .

The Australian Democrats are committed to developing a sustainable economy. One of the characteristics of a sustainable economy will be that each person, each group of people and each nation will be as self-sufficient as possible.

One need only look at the situation which has developed over the conflict in the Middle East to see one of the immediate consequences of pursuing a policy of enmeshment. Iraq had become one of the principal importers of Australian grain, and we were in the position of importing considerable amounts of petroleum from Middle Eastern countries. As a consequence of what has happened we have lost significant sales to Iraq and our petroleum imports from that country have been jeopardised.

Had we pursued the sorts of policies that I have been urging on Senator Button for the past three years in relation to the much-vaunted Button car plan-in other words, if we had developed much greater self-sufficiency in petroleum in this country by using the technologies which were already available to have a much more efficient transport industry, much more fuel efficient vehicles-we would now be in a much less vulnerable position with respect to what is happening in the Middle East.

I understand that when the Prime Minister was in Japan he was made aware of the fact that the Japanese were self-sufficient in rice, but that they grew their rice at a much higher cost than the cost at which Australia could export rice to Japan. He was urging the Japanese to give away their self-sufficiency and become dependent on Australian rice. Provided that the Japanese are growing their rice under sustainable conditions, that was a most stupid suggestion by the Prime Minister. It is far wiser for the Japanese to maintain self-sufficiency in rice production and not become dependent on another country. To seek deliberately to lock one country's economy into dependence on the economy, the environmental conditions and the politics of another country and on long and tenuous trade routes, with little control over the methods of manufacture, production and so on in those other countries, is not a sensible way to go.

On page 2 of the Prime Minister's speech he talks about various other aspects of Japanese practices with respect to the environment, and he refers to driftnet fishing. It is certainly to be noted with a great deal of joy that the Japanese have agreed to give up driftnet fishing in the South Pacific. However, the very fact that the Japanese have chosen such an environmentally destructive method of fishing at all should give us some concern about attempting to lock our economy inextricably in with that of the Japanese.

The Japanese have an atrocious record in regard to the exploitation of tropical rainforests. Some 90 per cent of the rainforest logging going on around the world is being conducted by Japanese companies-and not for high quality products but largely to produce plywood for concrete on Japanese building sites, to be used once and then thrown away. Prime forest timbers that have taken hundreds of years to grow are being used for a trivial purpose, leading to massive destruction, massive displacement of indigenous people, and very significant additions to greenhouse gas emissions because of the forest destruction. We need to look very carefully at a policy which, for short term economic reasons, specifically stated in the Prime Ministerial statement, seeks to lock us into an enmeshment-the word used by the Prime Minister-with an economy which is predicated on such environmental destruction.

The question is also raised in the Prime Minister's statement of the high temperature incinerator on Johnston Atoll. This is relevant to the matter now being debated in Australia relating to the placement of a high temperature incinerator at Corowa. I have been strongly promoting for many years through various conservation bodies the idea that Australia should build a high temperature incinerator. We have tens of thousands of tonnes of toxic and environmentally very destructive waste in this country-the majority of it being generated and stored at the ICI plant at Botany Bay in New South Wales. Unfortunately, the former New South Wales Government totally mishandled the placement of a high temperature incinerator when it proposed to build such a facility right in the middle of the ICI plant in Botany Bay in Sydney, and mishandled the public relations side of that arrangement.

Since then we have been casting about all over the country for a position in which to place a high temperature incinerator. The decision to go to Broken Hill in New South Wales some years ago was met by the people of Broken Hill with the obvious logic. If one wants to place this facility so far out in the countryside then it cannot possibly be safe, and therefore we do not need it. If it is safe, why do we not place it exactly where the waste is being generated? Of course, as we know from this morning's paper, the people of Corowa have reacted in precisely the same way.

Turning to the matter before us here, the burning of nerve gas and other residues on Johnston Atoll, the same logical conclusion is being drawn by the people of the South Pacific. The far greater danger associated with this practice is in the movement and the transport of these highly toxic and dangerous substances; a factor which was well and truly canvassed in a Four Corners program a couple of weeks ago. Quite clearly, the United States Government should be forced to destroy stocks of these materials as close as possible to the point at which they now lie. I am one who believes that properly conducted-I stress that-a high temperature incinerator is the best technology we have at the present time to get rid of these sorts of materials. But we should certainly not be countenancing, as the Prime Minister has, the transport of these things halfway around the world to be disposed of on a Pacific atoll with all the attendant problems of not only transport but also transference from one mode of transport to the other, and the loading of these things eventually into the high temperature incinerator. The Prime Minister says in relation to Papua New Guinea:
. . . that Australia had no wish to intervene in solving Papua New Guinea's problems.

However, this Government is countenancing, in the form of a number of Australian companies, practices in Papua New Guinea which are adding to Papua New Guinea's environmental problems. It is distressing that this Government has not been more forthright in condemning the very environmentally destructive practices of some Australian companies in relation to Papua New Guinea. Many of those practices will leave behind very long term, intractable and insoluble problems in the form of environmental destruction. I cite the massive problems of contamination of the Fly River as a consequence of the Ok Tedi operation-the silting, the loss of dam structure and material into that river, and the massive loss of cyanide which destroyed much of the wildlife some years ago. While I do not think Australia should be intervening to tell the Papua New Guineans what to do, we should certainly be helping them by not imposing on them practices which make their problems even more insoluble.

Senator Hill mentioned in his speech that in attending the conference in New York, the delegates from the Maldives islands-not in this particular area of the world but relevant to what I am about to say-expressed concern about greenhouse gas emissions and the fact that many of those low-lying islands will disappear under water should the sea level rise as a consequence of present practices. Of course, this will lead to massive environmental problems and massive problems of displacement of vast numbers of people. The Maldives islands are relatively unpopulated, but Bangladesh is a country with large parts which may well become uninhabitable.

Yet this Government, as I indicated in my opening remarks, has done nothing and apparently intends to do very little, if anything, in relation to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, even though the advice is that we need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60 to 80 per cent, that the technology for doing this is available, and that it will not have the economically disastrous consequences which the limited policy advisers with which this Government has surrounded itself might have predicted.

It is a matter of obvious fact that many of the less developed countries in the Pacific region are not the ones that are creating this massive greenhouse problem; rather it is the developed countries like Australia. Indeed, on various assessments, Australia is somewhere between third and fifth in terms of the per capita contribution to greenhouse gas emissions. We are one of the worst offenders on this fundamental question, which within the next 20 to 30 years will very significantly impact on a number of these nations and indeed, in the case of some of the low-lying ones, may totally obliterate them. We do not find anything at all about this in the Prime Minister's statement.

The Prime Minister then goes on and develops at some length his discussions in Japan. He talks about the desirability of increased Japanese investment. Senator Schacht talked about xenophobia and racism. In answer to Senator Schacht and in relation to the Japanese, I would simply observe that it is my understanding that there are Koreans living in Japan who have been living there for several generations and who are not granted Japanese citizenship, but it would not be possible for Australians to go to Japan and buy real estate. I just wonder why, if the Japanese behave in this way, we should lay ourselves open to foreign ownership of real estate in this country by a nation which has demonstrated-and I am not making a racist remark here-a very damaging attitude to the global environment. Why should we import those attitudes? It is not so much the Japanese people as the attitudes. Why should we import those attitudes, give them a prominence and give them a respected place in our society for economic reasons? It seems to me that we would be well advised--

TALK.START.PARA: —So you would let the West Germans make those sort of foreign ownerships because they are environmentally good?

—I am not saying anything about the West Germans. I would point out to Minister Tate that we are discussing the Prime Minister's parliamentary statement on visits to the South Pacific region, and he has specifically talked about Japan. He has not talked about West Germany. I am making the point that the Japanese have an abysmal record with respect to environmental vandalism in countries other than Japan. This Prime Minister's statement says that we should lock-or, to use his word, `enmesh'-our economy more inextricably with that of Japan. I believe that is not the correct course to follow and that a sustainable economy will be one which will exhibit large levels of independence and self-sufficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister in dealing with this linking with Japan specifically mentions, for example, the brown coal liquefaction project in Morwell. If this is an example of the sorts of projects which are we are likely to see under the multifunction polis (MFP) and other close and enmeshed Japanese relationships, let me say that that brown coal liquefaction research and development project was an Australian disaster.

It has been an Australian disaster in terms of its environmental impact and its impact on the occupational health of the Australians who work there. The Japanese, to the extent that they have discovered new technology-we do not know whether they have-have taken that technology back to Japan. There has been no sharing whatsoever of the technology discovered in relation to the liquefaction of our brown coal. More than that, the turning of brown coal into petroleum for use in vehicles which must rapidly disappear from our streets anyway is not the way we need to go.
Let me point out that the Prime Minister in his statement also takes a sideswipe at those of us who have been critical of the multifunction polis. He states:
I assured both the Japanese Government and business leaders that the prejudices within Australia which, at one point, put the MFP at needless risk, represented very much minority views.

Let me put it on record that it is not a prejudice to point out that this area in South Australia, which has the unwelcomed MFP being placed at Gillman, is very heavily polluted and that advice has been given by a number of expert advisers to government that that area should not be developed.

Let me also put on record that in the past week it has come to my notice that there are eight reports to government on the Gillman site which the Government has said cannot be released to the public. I remind the Senate that this is the time when there is supposed to be public discussion and public consultation on the MFP site. There are eight reports to government which the South Australian Government has said contain intellectual property and, therefore, cannot be released to the public.

It just so happens that I have in my possession by various means six of those eight reports. Let me tell the Senate that not one of those contains any intellectual property whatsoever, but all of them say things which are detrimental to the MFP site at Gillman in relation to environmental problems of pollution and the siting of an MFP in that very heavily polluted area.

For the Prime Minister to go to Japan and advise, as he tells us, the Japanese Government and business leaders that my attitude and presumably the attitude of others like me-that attitude being that in a period of public review the information on which the public needs to make a judgment should be available but is not available and that the South Australian Government has lied to the public in relation to holding that information back-is a prejudice, I find personally very offensive; and I am sure that many other people would also find it extremely offensive.

Let me summarise: I find the statement of the Prime Minister interesting, but interesting from the point of view that it describes the Government's attitudes and priorities as those with which the Democrats totally disagree. Mostly, they are attitudes and priorities with which the Opposition, I am sure, would agree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the parliamentary statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with regard to his visits to New Caledonia, the South Pacific Forum, Papua New Guinea and Japan. The report, when examined in detail, is really but part of a picture of what was a very important visit, a visit which placed us securely in our own region in terms of, first of all, letting Australia's principal attitudes be known on a number of important issues in a number of countries and, secondly, in ensuring that Australians are aware of the importance that this region to our near north plays in the life of every Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: A comment appearing in the Canberra Times by its correspondent Tony Wright with regard to my second point-the question of how much coverage there usually is of Australia's relationship with the region nearest to us-indicated that as far as he was concerned this extremely important visit by the Prime Minister hardly raised a ripple in the Australian media. To a large extent I must agree with him. It is beyond my understanding as to why the Australian press, in particular, did not discuss in any real detail some of the major issues raised by the Prime Minister, especially with regard to his visit to Japan. It is that question of our relationship with Japan which I want to discuss primarily today.

Japan has a special relationship with Australia. It is a political relationship. It is a relationship based upon mutual economical benefits. It is a relationship which has changed significantly over the past 50 years. It is a relationship which in some ways has been partially sustained by the events of 1941-45: a significant number of people in our older population have retained memories of the war atrocities that were committed, which from time to time has injected a degree of emotionalism into any discussion or debate about our relationship with Japan.

As I indicated in a debate on a Bill which came before this Senate last year-the War Crimes Amendment Bill-I do not think we should ever forget the cruelty and the viciousness and the lessons of history we can learn from uncontrolled abuse of power. Those lessons should never be forgotten. They should be taught to generation after generation. But there is a second step in the art of diplomacy, the positive side of diplomacy. That second step is to ensure that the outbreak of conflict never happens again. That takes a degree of objectivity, a degree of resoluteness, on the part of all participants to make sure that outright conflict does not recur. History has a habit on the whole of repeating itself.

The one thing that stands out most clearly in the period 1930-41 is Japan's effective isolation from the rest of the world politically, economically and, in many ways, culturally. That isolation allowed extreme right wing elements in Japanese society to seize control of the political and parliamentary machine through violence and ultimately through popular sanction, which in the end led to Japan's attack on Pearl Harbour. There are many economic reasons behind the decisions made by the Japanese to go to war but, above all else, it was that sense of isolation which enabled them to lose their perspective and to initiate and engage in that disastrous conflict.

When the Prime Minister talks about not only enmeshing Australia in the South East Asian region but also enmeshing ourselves with the Japanese economy and those areas of South East Asia which are most influenced by the Japanese, he is looking to the future, learning from the past, and giving us a message and South East Asia a message that our future cannot any longer be as a predominantly white country in the middle of the Asian region.

It cannot be that any longer. The world is too small. The best thing we can hand on to future generations is precisely a fulfilment of that enmeshment, culturally, socially and economically, that the Prime Minister talks about, so that the Japanese interests are, in effect, our interests; our interests are the Japanese interests-as much as is compatible with the different cultures that we have. That does not mean that we become more Japanese than the Japanese and they become more Australian than us; we retain our national identities.

It is extremely important that that isolation which occurred in the 1930s does not occur again, and economic involvement is but the first step to ensure it does not occur again. Involvement in terms of foreign policy-mutually agreed goals-is one other approach. Cultural exchanges, tourism, all those ways that we have of serving our own needs and of connecting with other countries, we have to use in the case of our relationship with Japan. Japan is on the same time line as Australia. It is, in a sense, a straight sevenhour or eight-hour journey. It is just a hop, step and a jump away from us.

The Japanese have a constrained and slightly unusual approach to foreign policy, born of their defeat in World War II and, to some extent, affected by their constitution, which was imposed on them by General MacArthur and the allied occupation forces. Yet despite that constitution, which prohibits the development of a military capacity of an offensive nature, despite the articles specifically referring to the need for Japan to have defence forces that are just that-defence, rather than offensive arrangements-the reality is that Japan is now one of the military powers not only of this region but of the world. For example, it has an extremely impressive air force. I will not go into the technical details as Senator MacGibbon is not in the chamber and he is the only one who would appreciate them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would.

—Senator Tate, you are not a warmonger, so you would not appreciate an examination of the Japanese air force. Japan has the fourth largest navy in the world. It has a very efficient and effectively trained army. Above all else, Japanese industry has the capacity, particularly in the electronics area, which is so vital to the development of new weaponry and support of existing weaponry, and its technology is extremely advanced; and it is that possible military capacity which must make us aware that Japan will have, and in fact is already approaching, superpower status in terms of its defence capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister, in his comments in Tokyo, made it quite plain that the hypocrisy which has surrounded the question of Japan's defence capacity has to end. We have to accept that it is a major force and that what Japan's constitution says is no longer reflected in reality in terms of its armed forces.

Similarly, with regard to Japan's economic power: for many years Australians refused to accept, in much the same way as we now seem not to accept Japan's military strength, Japan's economic strength. I remember, when I was a teenager, the image of Japanese goods: they were cheap; they were considered to be shoddy; they lacked design; they were imitations; they were borrowed designs. Very few people could say that today. In fact if one picks up a pair of scissors, any household utensil or something of a similar nature, the item that is most likely to break in one's hands because of its bad design or poor workmanship is likely to have come from Sheffield, England, than from Japan.

So we ignored the lesson that was staring us in the face 20 years ago. Secondly, we ignored our own weakness in terms of our constitutional framework. We are a large nation, geographically, with a small population, and we are divided into six States. We have a Noddyland parliamentary arrangement for the Australian Capital Territory. I am talking about the local parliament, and I think Senator Reid would agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not agree with it, and you are being offensive.
—I meant to be.
—You are being offensive to 17 people who are working diligently in the interests of this city.

—Diligently maybe, but not competently. The question of our constitutional structure 20 years ago was absolutely vital. We ignored it. Generally speaking, we missed out on any opportunity to change the Constitution to improve cooperation between the States to turn us into a nation. In fact we tended to praise the activities of Premiers like Joh Bjelke-Petersen and Sir Charles Court of Western Australia who seemed to specialise in undercutting when competing with other Australian States in order to secure contracts with, for example, Japanese buyers. The problem is: we are now suffering as a result of some of those contractual obligations that were set and signed by various State Premiers 20 years ago. It is only now that Australia is starting to see the sale and the development of its resources in a much more logical light and in terms of national perspectives-not as Queenslanders, South Australians, Tasmanians and so on, but as Australians. Were we not a pushover, not just for the Japanese but for most businessmen who had the backing of a national government in any dealings they had with Australia and particularly with the Australian States!

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for Senator Coulter to come into this chamber and to talk-from what I think is a slightly prejudiced viewpoint-about the domination of Australian culture, and in particular the Australian economy, by the Japanese. If the Japanese have an influence here which he finds unsatisfactory we have ourselves to blame, because at the basic level business is about bargaining: there is a buyer and there is a seller. There is a long term interest and there is a short term interest of the buyer and the seller. We were never able to put those interests together, firstly because of our constitutional framework and, secondly, because of our attitudes. We did not see ourselves as an integral part of Asia. My home State of Tasmania was once called the Apple Isle. That is now a joke. Why? Because we were still, in 1960 to 1962, looking to Europe for markets, when those markets were already going, when the question was really when Britain would join the Common Market, not if.

So one Tasmanian industry, a very important industry, went down the chute because we did not look to the future. We did not say to ourselves, `We are in South East Asia'. Our marketing and transport arrangements were appalling. I remember being in the State House in Tasmania, and sitting behind the Minister for Primary Industry-the poor bloke, because anyone who got that job I think deserved a medal-thinking, `When am I going to get a question on a couple of other things?'.

As a Minister I did not get a question because all Question Time-which in those days in the Tasmanian Parliament was unlimited; there was not an hour, it could go on for three hours if necessary-was devoted to where a particular ship carrying Tasmanian apples was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was it?
—It turned up in a port about 1,000 kilometres from where it was supposed to be going.
—What happened to the apples?

—The apples got left on the ship and the ship turned around and came back again. Our capacity to see ourselves as citizens of the world, as marketers in the world, as people who needed to get their act together to be exporters, just was not there. We said, as we did with so many industries, `Let us put up the tariff barriers. Let us put in the quotas to make sure that there is no genuine competition from outside. Let our industry become slack and uncompetitive. Let us consider that the domestic market is good enough. Let us allow multinationals to come into Australia and build up an industry but build up an industry behind tariff walls so that General Motors-Holden's Ltd could come in and buy an Australian company out'. Then General Motors could say to the Australian Government of the day, the Liberal Government of the day, `Now we want to be protected against foreigners'. Australians still cannot see the irony in that: that General Motors-an American company-could come in and then demand protection against other foreigners and that Ford could come into Australia and do the same thing. That is just one other area where Australians have no-one but themselves to blame, because the resolution of these problems is inevitably at the ballot box. They kept putting back in conservative governments who sold us out.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall standing in two elections against my colleague Senator Watson, a fair candidate and a fair opponent, a man I have a lot of time for. But one thing--

TALK.START.PARA: —But wait for it.

—As he said, `But wait for it'-but one thing used to appal me about Senator Watson. It is the only thing that I have against him. It was his obsession, in common with his colleagues in the Tasmanian Liberal Party, with States rights. It was like a religion. Those colleagues used to go on television and say, `But what about States rights?'. I used to think, `Hang on a second, what about apple pie? That has probably got more relevance to Tasmania. What about motherhood? What about the right to drive a car on the left hand side of the road?'. States rights was just as relevant or irrelevant. It was exactly that type of thing, the right to ruin your State, that the conservatives asked for. The right to build a $1 billion dam, not one megawatt of electricity from which would ever be used.
—I was for small dams.

—Yes, you were. I will give you credit for that. You were one of the few in the Liberal Party who saw that as an economic and environmental monstrosity. Yet States rights allowed Robin Gray to start on that dam. It was only when this Government--
—Order, Senator. Mr Gray.

—I am sorry. Mr Gray. I think he is still there. Very importantly, this Prime Minister more than any other Prime Minister since Prime Minister Chifley has ensured that we take a national perspective. He has ensured that first of all our resources belong to all Australians. He was the first to ensure that our infrastructure, under the stewardship of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), is about to be improved: a national perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter comes in here on behalf of the Australian Democrats and says, `Isn't it terrible that the Japanese have got market advantages in Australia; that the Japanese dominate the economic relationship between them and us?'. Senator Coulter has not looked at history. Senator Coulter is making sure that history repeats itself. It is precisely his attitude towards the Japanese, in particular, which will cause Japan to become isolated again. Prime Minister Hawke on his visit was absolutely right to have the courage and the tenacity to stand up and tell the world that Japan has to be treated as an equal-not as a superior, not as an inferior, but as an equal-with an equal right to its economic destiny, to its destiny with regard to its defence, and to its cultural destiny as part of a South East Asian area. It is right to have a relationship with us from which we both learn.

I want to make a point, for example, about the MFP, the multifunction polis, which the Prime Minister raised in Japan. Initially I had reservations about the multifunction polis, for the very good reason that when it first began it was promoted by businessmen who do not understand the meaning of the words `debate' and `inform', and who did not know how to bring the rest of Australian society with them. They were not prepared to put their cards on the table, to talk about who benefited, to bargain in fact with the Japanese as to what they wanted from a multifunction polis in Australia. In fact, they were selling us short. There were a couple of occasions when I was approached by people to give my support to the multifunction polis, and I told those lobbyists to go home, to do their homework, that I am an Australian, and that when Australians bargain with the Japanese or anyone else, then they ought to be bargaining as hard as they can. The facts should be put before the Australian people-clearly, concisely and honestly. I believe there was a lot hidden in those early proposals; they could rightly have been described as a potential land grab disguised as technology sharing. Why else would someone want to build a technology farm, or a technology city, on the most valuable land in Australia-Queensland's Gold Coast? The answer: if the technology development fails, one still has the valuable real estate. I said to those people who were talking about that sort of proposal, `Get off my patch, I am not interested in that'. Most Australians said the same thing. Australia is not for sale, and certainly not that cheaply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it, or is it not?

—It is not for sale. Worse still, it was being sold cheaply. That is what I meant; I had better clarify that one. We do not come cheap. The point I want to make is that the multifunction polis is now out in the open. It used to be called the MFP. The average Australian would not have known an MFP from an AFL-and that was over on Saturday-or a VFL.
—Or a VFT.

—Or a VFT, or a bifocal. Either way the problem was the debate. The debate had to be public. The Prime Minister has raised that discussion about our relationship with Japan to a new level. He said things which the rest of the world wants to hear. In other words, he said, `Let's us be honest about Japan's defence capacity'. He said to Japanese businesses, `We don't want you here just for tourism. We are not just a tourist destination'. He said, `We are not real estate for you to buy up any time you like. We are, and we want to be, equal partners in technology sharing. We want to be part of the sophisticated economic development'.

SPEECH.PARA: That has to be said over and over again to the Japanese business world and Japanese business leaders, because they need to get that message. I thought that the Prime Minister gave that message courageously, with the exception of one phrase which they had some problem with; about playing football, or silly people. That problem aside, they got the message. Australians are starting to get the message, particularly Australian businessmen, and particularly those who are associated with the early development of the multifunction polis. Those businessmen who were selling cheap I think are being pushed to one side, and it is up to us to ensure that Australian businesses involved in this multifunction polis, and our bureaucrats, know exactly what they are doing. So at the end of the day the Prime Minister's visit was extremely important, if badly and inadequately reported in Australia in terms of its significance.

I believe that in a decade or so people will look back to this particular period and they will say that that was the first Prime Minister of Australia who actually started to put the debate in perspective, to put it honestly and to demand that our relationship with Japan and other major countries in South East Asia is an equal and a productive one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for long on this matter of the visit overseas of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I just want to mention one part of the Prime Minister's statement, and that is in regard to Papua New Guinea, and in particular to Bougainville. I was very pleased to read that the Prime Minister had raised concerns over human rights abuses by both the Papua New Guinea military forces and the Bougainville Revolutionary Army. I was also very pleased to see that the Government has acknowledged the need for an outside body to investigate allegations of human rights abuses by both sides. I am sure that everyone here is aware that Amnesty International has documented many cases of human rights violations on Bougainville and these include really quite appalling things such as torture by both sides, police threats, assaults by both sides, extra-judicial executions by both sides and deaths in custody. I could go on and describe some of these things but they are the sorts of things that nightmares are made of and I, for one, do not get enough sleep around this place, so I will not.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that Australia has a very clear responsibility to ensure that the supply of aid, and especially all our military aid, cannot be used to violate human rights. Australia's defence assistance to Papua New Guinea has been doubled since the 1988-89 allocation. In addition to that, Australia has agreed to spend an extra $12m this year on training and equipping 450 members of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force and another $3m in civil aid, which will be partly used to improve the professionalism of the police riot squads which have been linked with excessive force on Bougainville. About one-fifth of our defence cooperation allocation to Papua New Guinea last year was used on the four famous Iroquois helicopters which were used in Bougainville by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force.

While here we may be able to understand the arguments for and against Australia's role in providing these helicopters and the fine distinction between having guns bolted to helicopters versus having them tied on with rope, I would imagine that these distinctions are not quite as clear to the Bougainvillians, who see helicopters with guns attached flying overhead, but who do not have the benefit of the debate in our plethora of news and current affairs media. Actually we should note at this point that the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Government itself has a very good record on human rights. It has safeguards written into its Constitution and it also has judicial safeguards. There is obviously a very large disparity between the intent of the PNG Government and the actions of both the PNG military force on Bougainville and the Bougainville Revolutionary Army. As I said, the Prime Minister has raised Australia's concerns over these actions. I would be very interested to hear whether the Foreign Minister intends to press these concerns when he gets back in order to try to achieve an inquiry by the Papua New Guinea Government into human rights abuses on Bougainville. It is something that we must all hope for.

It is interesting to note that the distinction between Australia's role in Bougainville and in Cambodia is really quite large. Enormous steps still need to be made to stop human rights abuses on both sides. Australia's role has been one of negotiation in Cambodia while we must be seen, on Bougainville, in a very different light. We have to ask whether that difference is due to the different attitudes of our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Department of Defence. Our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and in particular the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) who does deserve credit here, were in charge of our response on Cambodia while the Department of Defence was in charge of our response on Bougainville. We must agree with Amnesty International that the Australian Government cannot abrogate its responsibility for the uses to which Australian provided equipment or training is put.

In general, Australia's recent record on human rights has been very good under both Labor and Liberal governments. A little earlier during this debate Senator Schacht mentioned that the Australian Government has brought up human rights abuses with several countries-I think he said 87 countries around the world. I do not think that is something which can purely be said of the Australian Labor Party here. I think the Liberal Party, the National Party of Australian and the Australian Democrats have all said that they would do the same in government and I think a lot of that is due especially to the very good work of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International; in particular to Mr Robert Tickner of the other place and to former Senator Chris Puplick.
We must, though, accept that we do have a responsibility to act to stop human rights abuses being committed as a result of Australia providing any military aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: — I too would like to join with other honourable senators in commending the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for the success of his four overseas trips and I will attempt, in my contribution today, to speak about those trips and certainly to speak about the response of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to the statement made by the Prime Minister yesterday in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I think what we have seen from Dr Hewson is an absolutely desperate attempt to show that he is a little more than just a one dimensional man. I think everyone knows how inexperienced Dr Hewson is. We all know that he is new to the parliamentary game-pretty new to politics-and he is trying to widen his base.

TALK.START.PARA: —Attack the policies, not the person.

—I think I understand that and I can hear from Senator Watson's interjections that he can understand that also. But, unfortunately for the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, Dr Hewson has chosen the area of Foreign Affairs to try to display some new found expertise. Of course, I think it is fair to say that Dr Hewson really has only demonstrated ignorance and callowness in his performance so far. Unfortunately for the Opposition but fortunately for the Government, Dr Hewson is only an economist and not a very good one at that. I think his performance over the last couple of weeks and his response to the parliamentary statement by the Prime Minister is absolute proof of that.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Acting Government Whip asked me this morning to speak in this debate-and I was very delighted that he gave me the opportunity to do so-I was thumbing through today's Australian newspaper as I received his phone call and what should I find in the Australian but this article from Foreign Affairs writer, Greg Sheridan, under the headline `How Labor stole the foreign policy show'. Greg Sheridan said this:

. . . foreign affairs is an area of signal success for the Labor Party and it is the conservative Opposition which finds it almost impossible to make any inroads into the Government's standing in foreign affairs.

Since 1983, there has been a succession of coalition foreign affairs spokesmen, including Michael MacKellar-very forgettable, I interpolate-Neil Brown, Andrew Peacock, John Spender and now Senator Robert Hill. It is fair to say that none of them has really laid a glove on the Hawke Government. While I do not always agree with what Mr Sheridan says and while I do not necessarily agree with everything in his article today, I do find myself in agreement with those statements.

I think it is worth addressing the question of why the Liberal-National Party coalition has failed so dismally in the area of foreign policy and in an attempt to develop an alternative policy to that which has been pursued by the Government since 1983. I think the coalition really does have a few problems and we need to focus on them. The first is, of course, the manifest differences between the Liberal Party and our friends in the National Party. One can start with the question of the structure of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The National Party made it very clear through its former leader, Mr Charles Blunt-defeated, of course, at the last election-that if a coalition government were elected to office one of the first actions of that government would be to ensure that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade would be separated. I think that most Australians, certainly those interested in public policy making and in better administration in this country, would accept that the amalgamation of the former departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade has really been of great benefit to public policy making in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly with the balance of payments.

—I know that this is a very difficult question for Senator Watson because the Liberal Party takes a different view to the National Party on this issue. He is quite right to identify it. The first problem that the Liberals face is the difficulties they have with their coalition partners, the Nationals. Of course, the other real fundamental problem that the coalition has is the adherence to the conservative dogmas of the past which, of course, led to the sorts of policies that involved Australia in Vietnam and so on. It just stands in very stark contrast to the sort of role that the Labor Government has played over the last seven years because the Labor Government has developed a self-reliant policy, a foreign policy which gives Australia a capacity to make its own decisions in its own national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there are many differences between the policy that has been proposed by the Labor Government and the position that the Opposition has consistently taken. For example, it is this Government that took the lead in negotiating the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty; it is the Opposition that is committed to throwing it out. It is the Government that has not endorsed the strategic defence initiative, star wars; it is the Opposition which endorses the SDI. It is the Government that opposes any possibility of stationing nuclear weapons on Australian soil; it is the Opposition that wants to keep that option open. It is the Government that appointed an ambassador for disarmament and established the Peace Research Centre at the Australian National University; it is the coalition which is committed to abolishing both.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As most honourable senators will be aware, it is a longstanding practice that the printing of legislation takes priority over the printing of the daily Hansard. At 6 o'clock last night, the Australian Government Publishing Service received 32 pieces of legislation for printing, with 28 of these being required by 8.30 a.m. this morning. As a result, the preparation and printing of these Bills took priority over the production of the daily Hansard. The delivery of the daily Hansard which, in the ordinary course of events, should have occurred between 9 o'clock and 10 o'clock this morning, was delayed until after 1 o'clock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
This seems to be further evidence of what we have been saying for the last two days, that this Government is in a legislative shambles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good stuff.

—I will go on a little while longer, if the honourable senator likes. Let us just reflect on where the Senate is at the moment. We have today the embarrassing situation where it literally has no legislation at all. Yesterday the Senate adjourned early because it ran out of business. Legislation was listed last week, then pulled off and then called back on today, and now it seems that it is not going to be debated at all. We have the new committee system. Committees are supposed to meet on Friday and they still do not know which Bills they are going to be debating. We have the privacy one, for example, to deal with credit agents. It looks as though up to 10 witnesses will need to be called, none of whom have yet been advised that they are going to be called to give evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: These are senior business people who simply do not know whether the Senate is going to request their attention to contribute to its legislative process this Friday. In other words, all the President has done in making that statement today is indicate again that the whole process of the legislation at the moment is a shambles. The Government should get its house in order and the production of Hansard should not suffer as a result of its incompetence.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Minister will recall his recent statement:

QUESTION.PARA: There are many particularly small companies that have suffered immensely, and a lot of them have gone out of business. There may even be more.
He also said:
So there may well be as a result of this shakeout a reduction in manufacturing capacity in Australia . . . there will be some good ones which disappear, there's no doubt about that . . .
I ask the Minister: Has he subsequently discussed these statements with the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, and does the Minister stand by these statements today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not subsequently discussed these matters with the Treasurer or the Prime Minister, but I must say that over a period of time, of course, in the process of government one has discussions about these sorts of things. So the answer to the question is that there have been no subsequent discussions; there have been discussions on other occasions about these sorts of issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Because the honourable senator chose to read out what I said, let me put it in some sort of context because under this Government, as at the end of 1988, manufacturing had the highest levels of production in the history of this country.

The employment in manufacturing industry in Australia had increased by 100,000 people. Sure, with a relatively high level of business bankruptcies and so on, there will be a loss of capacity in a period of decreased demand such as exists at present. But, in terms of the overall picture, the manufacturing sector is in much better shape now than it ever was in any one of the seven years of government of those opposite, or at any--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that outside.
—Senator Watson, a refugee from the textiles industry, for goodness sake--
—Whose fault?

—Whose fault is it that Senator Watson was a refugee? It is Malcolm Fraser's fault. Senator Watson is still determined to fight the battles of the early 1970s, and he interjects about these matters. But is it not right that the highest level ever of manufacturing production in this country was in the last quarter of 1988 and that during the life of this Government there has been an increase in manufacturing capacity, a very substantial increase in investment in manufacturing and an increase in employment?
