ANSWER.PARA: The sad thing for those opposite is that they limped out of office with their tails between their legs, not being able to say anything like that-and they still cannot say it now except by way of giggling when I give them a few facts that are unpalatable to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What part is the Government's policy of continuing high interest rates playing in `the good ones which will disappear'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has had a tight monetary policy for a considerable period. That, of course, will have an effect on a whole lot of business activity, as it was intended to do because we were concerned to lower levels of demand in the Australian economy.
—You wouldn't say it was intended to destroy manufacturing.

—No; but a complex of factors is at work in Australia at present. First, there are the consequences of continued tight monetary policy, in spite of a reduction in interest rates of 4 per cent in the last couple of months, which bear on the issue. The second issue is, in my view, the behaviour of some sections of the financial sector. I do not in any sense stand alone in criticising the banking sector, for example.
—What about the Government? Has it played any role in the demise of industry and funds?

—Senator Boswell interjects, `What about the Government?'. But his Leader had a lot to say about this. Senator Boswell has not said anything as nasty as this about the Government, but let me tell him what his Leader said about the banks last week. He said that the banks have a lot to answer for, referring to `business cowboys' who have been guilty of fraudulent activity. He went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . in 1990 Ned Kelly is alive and well: he comes with a white collar and quite often a management fee . . .

He said that these things have to be examined. Senator Boswell's Leader said that. In judging the balance between the effects of government policies and the effects of various other behaviour of institutions and so on, nobody, including Senator Boswell, has ever said anything like that about us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Social Security agree with the New South Wales Liberal Party's resolution, which is to be discussed at its Federal Council later this month, that the sole parent pension should be seen as a transitional payment during a period of difficult adjustment rather than a permanent welfare payment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even from some remarks made this morning by Senator Alston it is still obvious that the Liberal Party not only in New South Wales but nationally fails to recognise what sole parents pensions are about and still believes that governments should not fund those sole parents who seek to maintain parenting as their primary role in life. It is a matter of great sadness that the New South Wales Liberal Party should adopt such a position officially and seek to have that view promoted nationally through its party apparatus. Given that people such as Senator Alston are in charge of that apparatus at a parliamentary level, they do not need to worry, the position of the Liberal Party on sole parents pensions has been well said by him. Basically the Liberal Party just is not in favour of them, and that is, of course, a stark and fundamental difference. When one looks at the period of entitlement of sole parents pensions--
—What is your authority for that?

—I am glad the honourable senator has interjected on that. It is not a matter of there being an authority for it, because I have never referred to Senator Alston as being an authority on anything. He is, nonetheless, the source of the comment that I have made.

ANSWER.PARA: Sole parent pensions recognise that there is a limit on the time for which they are received; in fact, at present it is an average of three years. There is an obvious problem after marriage break-up for sole parents in that some children need care for a particular time after a marriage breakdown occurs. The sole parent pension recognises the fact that that must continue and at times that will mean that parenting must continue without a return to the work force. Nonetheless, the Government has been at pains in the last 12 months to make sure that some opportunity is given to those sole parents who do seek to re-enter the work force, but the sole parent pension has never been regarded by the Government as a permanent payment. I think once we recognise that there are particular needs after a marriage breakdown, then we will understand that that payment does not need to be permanent; in fact, sole parents have shown that they do not actually expect it to be so.

The Government has also endeavoured to have training opportunities available for sole parents through the jobs, education and training program, which was discussed in the Parliament yesterday. We are making sure that we are targeting those sole parents who are seeking to have some training before they re-enter the work force.

It is disappointing that the kind of transitional payment that sole parents pensions represent should be put under threat by the New South Wales Liberal Party, Senator Alston, or anyone else. But such is the world in which we live. Fortunately, the Government remains committed not just to the payment of the pension but, more importantly, to those families who rely on it for their support.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the Minister whether he recalls the memorable media interview by the Treasurer on 14 May this year in which the Treasurer, commenting on remarks that Senator Button had made the previous day in relation to tax and other matters, said:

QUESTION.PARA: Now, I don't want to begin another week where I've got to put another 10 days of work in to deal with loose remarks by colleagues...it's time they disciplined themselves and got down to their own portfolios, but not only got down to their own portfolios, lifting their ambitions for change. And not just talking about it, actually getting it done.

Does the Minister consider that his remarks on the 7.30 Report last night are likely to incur similar public wrath from the Treasurer and the Deputy Prime Minister? If not, why not? If he does so consider, then will he be prepared yet again to be publicly humiliated by the architect and engineer of Australia's current economic recession? Finally, can the Minister now provide a clear statement to businessmen and women on the prospects for lowering interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sort of question was a good try, I suppose. The honourable senator put an awful amount of work into that, about as much as he put into the questions about the Olympic Games funding last week. The answers, I am afraid, are much the same.

ANSWER.PARA: I recall the Treasurer's remarks of 14 May, but the issues which I was talking about in the 7.30 Report last night-I think Senator Short would agree-are certainly within my portfolio responsibility. There is no question of any analogy there.

In so far as Senator Short's comments about the Treasurer are concerned, I think the Treasurer has been, and is being at the present time, very successful in keeping his nerve when all sorts of people-all sorts of snake oil salesmen-come in here, like Senator Short, suggesting that some sort of magic wand can be waved which will fix the problems of this economy overnight.

That goes to the last part of Senator Short's question about interest rates. Interest rates have come down 4 per cent in the last couple of months, as Senator Short well knows. Of course, I am not in any sense speculating about interest rates but on a number of occasions the Government, for reasons very obvious to most people-and I hope to Senator Short-is concerned that interest rates come down as soon as is economically responsible; and that will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer and ask him: if he does consider that the matters he discussed last night on the 7.30 Report - that is, the environment and interest rates-are within his portfolio then, as at least one of the Ministers responsible for those matters, can he now provide a clear statement to business men and women on the prospects for lowering interest rates?
—It is scarcely a supplementary question. I answered that in the earlier part of my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What action is being taken to ensure the privacy of consumers from observation when they enter a personal identification number (PIN) into automatic teller machines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of great concern to those people who use the innovative techniques offered by various financial institutions to enable people outside the institutions to use those holes in the wall which have electronic machinery in them-I do not use one myself-in order to get access to cash at times which are convenient to the clients of the banking system.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe it has been the occasion for some comment by some clients of some banks that, in so far as the keypad is vertical, it is very hard for it to be shielded by the body or the hand at the same time as carrying out the transaction-the punching in of the various numbers and data-from those who might be in the close vicinity and, therefore, ensure the privacy of the PIN number.

In this situation, Ministers for consumer affairs in their meeting in Perth in July made it clear that they required the vertical keypads to be changed, in those institutions which had them, to a more horizontal position to assure the privacy of those using those particular facilities.

Indeed, only last week the Westpac Banking Corporation wrote to me indicating that it was, in fact, engaging in such a change of its keypads from the vertical to the horizontal position in order to enable that privacy to be assured to its clients. I think the National Australia Bank Ltd is also one of those institutions which was not offering that same degree of privacy which the consumer affairs Ministers thought was essential, and I hope that it follows Westpac in this regard in changing the keypads over a period of time. I think all honourable senators would accept that there is a need to ensure the security of the PIN number and the privacy of the person using these machines when dealing with their banks or other financial institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the killing by Israeli police of an estimated 21 Palestinians and the wounding of 140 more in response to stone throwing which wounded 11 Israelis at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. I preface my question by concurring with the view of the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Dr Blewett, that the situation was a difficult one but that the response of the Israeli authorities was disproportionate. I ask the Minister: Firstly, why is it consistent to suspend ministerial contact with the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) over its position on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, while maintaining ministerial contact with the Israeli Government, in view of these killings and the systematic denial of basic rights to Palestinians in the occupied territories; secondly, does the Government accept that a failure by the United Nations (UN) Security Council to act decisively on the situation in the occupied territories will greatly undermine the credibility built up by the Council in its concerted response to Iraq's invasion; thirdly, will the Government convey to the Bush Administration the need for such action, including the sending of a UN mission to the occupied territories; and, finally, will the Government resume ministerial contact with the PLO to allow differences to be addressed directly and to maintain at least a semblance of even-handedness in its Middle East policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Powell, having had lengthy experience in the Senate, will understand that some parts of her question will have to be taken on notice. Whether the Government will send a United Nations mission, resume contacts with the PLO and so on are policy questions which will have to be considered. I will take those parts of the question on notice. It might be helpful, however, to make one or two observations. Senator Evans, in a press release yesterday I understand, deplored the deaths of Palestinian demonstrators in the incident to which Senator Powell has referred. The Australian Government has previously condemned the use of live ammunition against unarmed demonstrators and, in the incident in question, Israeli authorities fired on a large crowd of demonstrators causing at least 20 deaths and scores of injuries.

ANSWER.PARA: According to reports, the demonstrators had been throwing stones at Jewish worshippers at the Western Wall and subsequently attacked an Israeli police station at the end of the Temple Mount area. The demonstration was associated with rumours of an attempt by a Jewish group to lay a foundation stone for a third temple on the Mount, but Israeli authorities denied this group entry to the Temple Mount area and have said that they believe the demonstration was premeditated. Clearly there was a very difficult situation, but the use of force on such a scale by the Israeli authorities appears, on the evidence now available, to have been a disproportionate response.

The current situation in the Middle East-in Israel and on the Bank and elsewhere-is very tense and these sorts of situations can exacerbate such tension. It is the Government view that the Israeli authorities must recognise the need for maximum restraint as incidents such as that which took place yesterday can only increase the frustrations and antagonism of the Palestinian population. The United Nations Security Council is currently examining what action it should take in reaction to these incidents. Australia would support an appropriate response, such as a United Nations mission, to report on the situation but in the context of a United Nations consideration of the matter.

The Government has said before that there is and can be no linkage between the resolution of the Gulf crisis and the resolution of the Palestinian issue. The requirements for a resolution of the Gulf crisis are clearly stated in the United Nations Security Council resolution and are quite distinct. The Government deplores attempts by Iraq to make political capital out of the tragic deaths on the Temple Mount and to divert international attention from the issue of its aggression against Kuwait.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, relates to the fall in rural incomes due to shrinking markets, in particular for wheat and wool. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the support systems available to assist individuals and communities through this time of adjustment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a range of Commonwealth Government assistance measures available to support individuals in rural Australia. The main assistance measures available to farmers are the rural adjustment scheme, known colloquially as RAS, and the rural counselling scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: In the August Budget, total funding for RAS was increased from $53.3m in 1989-90 to $60.7m in 1990-91. New funding for interest subsidies on loans to farmers and other measures to encourage structural adjustment was doubled to $6m, which should support more than $60m of farm debt. Funding for household support equivalent to the unemployment benefit and re-establishment grants of around $32,000 is available for farmers leaving the industry. Funding for these purposes was increased to $6m. However, the Commonwealth's commitment to this rural assistance is open-ended and claims will be met as they are incurred.

As well as that, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, stated earlier in the year that the Government is prepared to review the supply of funds under RAS to assist woolgrowers in financial difficulty. This commitment was reaffirmed in a recent meeting-I think it was last week-with the National Farmers Federation.

Later this year Mr Kerin will be meeting with State and Northern Territory rural adjustment scheme Ministers. The emerging problems in the wool and wheat industries will be a major factor in the Ministers' consideration of future priorities for RAS.

This financial year $960,000 is being provided to support 24 rural counsellors to provide independent financial counselling to farmers. Counsellors are located in every State except Queensland, which has it own State financial counselling service. It is understood that rural community groups in these areas not presently serviced by rural counsellors will be applying for Commonwealth support. In addition, individuals in rural communities could be eligible for a range of Commonwealth support and welfare assistance through the social security system. The CountryLink free telephone access service can provide information on eligibility requirements.
While it is recognised that any downturn in the rural economy has a serious effect on whole communities, Commonwealth assistance programs are targeted at individuals on a needs basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to an article on page 1 of today's Sydney Morning Herald as saying that he will not take part in any further cuts in welfare spending. Does the Minister's announcement mean that the Government has taken a policy decision to quarantine social security from the considerations of the Expenditure Review Committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all.
—You don't need a brief on that.

—I thought I had the newspaper clip-I was just going to get it out. The answer to that is no. As all honourable senators would be aware, irrespective of who is in government the same kinds of options, when one looks at savings, are put up to the Minister concerned and to expenditure review committees, or whatever they might be called in an Opposition regime, every year. This Government has consistently rejected those options which would affect social security recipients-those least able to protect themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has spent seven years making sure that welfare spending is targeted to those most in need. The reality was that prior to 1983 very little targeting had ever been attempted. We spent seven years doing it year after year. I think everyone in the Senate ought to be aware of the fact that if we do not adopt the kinds of options that the Expenditure Review Committee adopted in the last couple of months-that is, looking at the use of new technology with tax file numbers to take money off cheats-we will have to look, to receive the same cuts to make sure that the public sector borrowing requirement is not any greater than it ought to be, at attacking those people who can least afford to be attacked.

What I said this morning is that I did not believe that that was appropriate. I think the actual quote that I was trying to find was that I would resist that very strongly. And I most certainly would. I am proud to be on record as saying that. That is in keeping with Labor's philosophy. It is also in keeping with Labor's record over the last seven years. My predecessors in this job, Don Grimes and Brian Howe, got down to the business of targeting welfare payments to those most in need and not reducing them. That has always been and remains the fundamental difference between the Opposition and the Government. We still maintain, as our highest priority, that we will look after those least able to protect themselves. I only wish that we could get the same comments out of those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the article in which he is reported as saying that the Federal Government had exhausted every option for social security savings in the last Budget. Is the Minister making it clear that for the remaining life of this Government there will be no further attempt at social welfare reforms unless they involve more spending and not less?

—The point I was making in that article, and I can only repeat it, is that we have exhausted all those options which can produce large savings in social security without actually taking benefits out of the hands of those most in need. Of course, I could not guarantee that in the Budget discussions next year, the year after or in 10 years' time the Department of Finance will not produce what it does every other year, and that is a series of options which would take some benefits out of the hands of those who cannot afford to lose them. Of course it will. What I am saying is that I will resist those attempts very strongly.
—Irrespective of the merits?

—The honourable senator should wait a moment. I have a real problem with taking money from those at the bottom of the scale. That is a problem that Senator Alston has never had and will never have. As I said on television in an interview with him a few weeks ago, when it comes to taking benefits from those at the lowest end of the scale or from sole parents, those who are really in need, Senator Alston is right at the forefront-he is really tough. When it comes to tax avoiders, he will crawl across the Simpson Desert on hands and knees to save them. That will always be the difference between the two parties.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In light of the Minister's reply to a question from Senator Newman asked on 19 July 1990 concerning the supply of gas masks to the Australian Army, I ask whether the men on board the three Australian warships in the Gulf have been issued with new gas masks, given that in answer to Senator Newman the Minister said that the majority of current gas masks have reached or are about to reach the end of their useful life. Have the same warships and any others destined for service in the Gulf been fully issued with state-of-the-art equipment to counter any kinds of chemical weapons, given that both the United States of America and Iraq have a record of using chemical weapons in the past, and that it is likely that these weapons would be used if there were a full scale conflict in the Gulf?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that in answer to Senator Newman, Senator Robert Ray indicated that the majority of gas masks were reaching the end of their useful lives. Having said that, I would say that only serviceable gas masks have been issued to our personnel. All nuclear, biological and chemical defence equipment issued for the Gulf crisis was individually inspected to ensure packaging integrity. Representative samples were inspected and tested to ensure that they would provide adequate protection to Royal Australian Navy personnel aboard a ship. The results were satisfactory, so the issues were made to the Navy.

ANSWER.PARA: Although the gas masks are not new, no inadequate gas masks have been issued to the Navy. The complete protective kit is suitable for the type of operation to be conducted by the Navy, and is the same equipment being used by the United States of America. Personal decontaminants issued are adequate for the task. Warship protection against chemical weapons is provided by a pre-wetting/wash down with a continuous water spraying system to wash away chemical agents and by restricting personnel to a ``gas-tight'' area within the ship which excludes nerve and chemical agents. Broadly speaking, the information that I have at hand is that all precautions that could reasonably be taken on this matter for our personnel in the Gulf have been taken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. The Minister will no doubt be aware that an industry briefing was held on 19 September 1990 for prospective tenderers to provide a high speed computer parallel matching system within the Department of Social Security to enable identity and income records of all recipients of social security, veterans' affairs and student assistance benefits to be subject to computer parallel matching, including an overlay of income and identity data provided by the Australian Taxation Office. The Minister will further be aware that selected sections of the draft request for tender, namely parts 6, 7, 8 and 13, were distributed at that meeting. I ask the Minister whether the whole or part of the draft request for tender was given to the Privacy Commissioner for his advice as to whether the proposed system will comply with the Privacy Commissioner's data matching guidelines, which I understand will be released within the next fortnight. If not, why not? Further, will he make available to this Parliament all or any advice which the Commissioner may give? I seek leave at this time to table a copy of the extract from the draft request for tender and ask the Minister whether he will make the remainder of the request for tender available.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the exact date upon which the meeting took place; nor am I aware of what 6, 7, 8, 13 or other numbers exactly referred to, because I do not have them on me. However, I think Senator Bishop is approaching this question from the rear end, so to speak. It would seem to me that the undertakings I have given here in the Chamber are that we, in implementing our Budget policies on tax file numbers and accelerated computer matching, will make sure that we do nothing to go outside of the guidelines which will be provided to us by the Privacy Commissioner. So, were there to be anything that we have done so far outside of those guidelines, it would be modified to take account of them. That was the undertaking that I gave to the Commissioner when I first saw him about this prior to the announcement of the Budget--
—Why don't you get the guidelines before you call the tender?
—The guidelines will not be ready for a few weeks.
—Why don't you hold the tender up?
—At least I am glad you finished this morning's meal. We have to have our computer systems in place for the--
—I will fix you right up.
—Mr President, there are threats across the chamber. I am appalled at this.
—Order! Senator Boswell.

—In conclusion, we will ensure that the guidelines which the Commissioner brings down are adhered to. I think that has got to be a fundamental part of the guarantees that will be required, not just by this Parliament but by the Australian people, and it is not something that we intend to move away from. Having said that, as to providing Senator Bishop with whatever else is not tabled here today, I will inquire of the Department of Social Security whether or not there are any commercial-in-confidence reasons for its not being supplied. On the assumption that there are not, it will be supplied to her.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. On 20 September this year, the Department of Social Security in answer to questions in Estimates C answered that the Privacy Commissioner was not consulted concerning the preparation of that draft request for tender (RFT). I asked the Minister why not and he declined to answer that part of the question. I would ask the Minister again to tell us why he was not consulted, and I similarly ask if he would make available to this Parliament all and any advice that he received from the Privacy Commissioner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can just add to what I said earlier-the Privacy Commissioner's role here is not to set policy but to ensure that when Government is implementing that policy, it does not infringe on privacy requirements. What we are doing is making sure that the Privacy Commissioner has an input on each and every aspect of that to which he is entitled. That is something that will not be varied. Therefore, the Privacy Commissioner was briefed on what the Government wanted to do and the kind of programs that we wanted, and asked to draw up some guidelines for their operation. He was also told at the same time that we would be providing staff for him not only to prepare those guidelines but also to monitor the effectiveness of the Government's compliance with them. That undertaking remains and nothing that Senator Bishop has just said changes it. I do not believe that in any way it could even be suggested that we have not acted properly with the Privacy Commissioner in this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the provision to Senator Bishop of advice that I may get in the next two weeks from the Privacy Commissioner, obviously the guidelines will have to be made public. I will certainly do that. The Privacy Commissioner may provide advice that is for the Government and the Cabinet. If that is the case, it will not necessarily be made public. But we have a duty to make public as much of the information as we can. I will certainly be advocating within the Government that we release all this information because we cannot possibly attempt to hide behind any cloak of secrecy, and we will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister seen reports of suggestions of the use of ethanol as an alternative fuel source? Can he give honourable senators any information regarding the viability of an ethanol-petrol blend as a solution to Australia's long term energy needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter that has excited the interests of the National Party of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I might say, in acknowledging that interjection from a Liberal senator, that it is the Liberal Government in New South Wales which has conducted the most recent study on ethanol. Neil Pickard, the New South Wales Minister for Minerals and Energy, engaged in a study which involved expensive visits to Brazil and to the east and west coasts of the United States. Despite the investigation which was conducted, the Government has not yet reported. I guess that is a bit typical of New South Wales Government efficiency these days.

ANSWER.PARA: The former Queensland Government, then in the person of the Queensland Minister for Mines, Mr Bob Katter, was a vigorous supporter of ethanol. He wanted a 10 per cent ethanol-petrol blend to be used in Queensland. This, of course, has been discontinued by the Goss Government since it took office.

Ethanol has been tried as a fuel in only two countries in the world-the United States and Brazil. In both cases it was a financial disaster. The Brazilian Government provided subsidies worth more than $2.7 billion a year, but the new Government of Brazil is abandoning that program. It is dismantling the subsidies and introducing free market policies so that whatever fuel sources are produced have to compete with others on the international market. We will see that program in Brazil disappear.

A 10 per cent ethanol-petrol blend in Australia, as advocated by Bob Katter, for example, has two drawbacks: the economic ones and the environmental ones. If the 10 per cent blend were to be an excise free blend, it would cost Australians $435m a year in revenue forgone. Subsidies for industry to keep the price below current bowser petroleum prices would amount to another $400m a year.

Mr Roy Deicke, the Managing Director of the Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd, told the annual general meeting of his company last year that sugar based ethanol could cost about a dollar a litre. Bearing that in mind in relation to the other area of concern I mentioned before-the environmental costs, which are prohibitive -disposal of liquid wastes from ethanol distillation would be a major problem. Mr Deicke, in his speech to the annual general meeting of the Bundaberg Sugar Co., said that in Brazil the waste disposal problem had turned rivers black, caused by the effluent coming from ethanol plants. A 10 per cent blend equals a doubling of land for cane farming in Australia to produce an efficient product. This would also increase pressure on marginal lands and on the environment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: TENDER FOR MANAGEMENT INFORMATION SYSTEM

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the report tabled by Senator Bishop, which shows extracts from a draft specification for a request for tender for the provision of a high-speed matching, searching and management information system facility that was distributed by his Department to interested vendors at an industry consultation on 19 September 1990. Is it true that the system described by the draft request for tender is intended to include a central register? Further, can the Minister confirm that the system is expected to process vast quantities of personal data, producing in excess of 2.5 billion attempted matches per annum?

—Several times in this chamber in the last few weeks I have given an explanation of the type of system which we will have in place next year. I have given honourable senators an indication that there will not be a central register. I have indicated that when tapes are produced, they will be run through our computer; only then shall we be getting information that will show apparent matches. We will not, therefore, be seeing a whole list-
—You want to check the tender.

—Just a minute, Senator Boswell. We will not be seeing all of these billions of pieces of information. They will be put on a secure tape. All we get out at the end are possible matches. They will then be followed up for action.
—They will put it in their pockets and walk out.

—Nobody will be putting anything in pockets. We in the Department of Social Security are not that sort of people. That means that all the undertakings that the Government has given about privacy on this question must be kept. But the important point to note is that Senator Boswell, as I understand it, has even refused to go out to see the equipment. It is pretty hard to work out-

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I have been accused, wrongly, of not going out to see equipment, not tripping around on the fantasy stories that Senator Richardson is on about. I was speaking in the House at the time that Senator Richardson arranged the appointment. I believe that takes precedence over the fantasy tour by Senator Richardson.
—Order! There is no point of order, but there are procedures whereby you can make that statement later.

—As I was saying, Senator Boswell has not availed himself of an opportunity to inspect the area in which this will take place. In fact, we attempted to arrange not one appointment for him, but several. But everything is more important to Senator Boswell than actually looking at the real system. The odd fact gets in the way of his rhetoric. He obviously wants to avoid the truth. I cannot make him face it. But as far as the tax file number system is concerned, there will be privacy questions that the Government must answer, and we have therefore encouraged the Opposition and members of the Government to have a look at the system. I am confident that once they go out there with Mr Murphy from my Department, that their concerns will be allayed and their fears will be put aside, and we will get ahead with the business of taking $400m out of the pockets of cheats and bludgers and putting them into the hands of honest Australian taxpayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Section 8.5 of the draft specification describes the proposed system in terms of a national database with the provision for a national names index. There are also references to the storage and updating of data in the large file, and of large volume historical data. How does the Minister reconcile this with his statement of 23 August when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Information will be destroyed every three months. There will be no central data bank.
Yet tenders have been called for one. He said:
I might say that personally I would not have a bar of one, anyway.
How does he reconcile this with his statement of 14 September when he said:
There will be no central data bank created as a result of the measures proposed in the Budget--
and he has tendered for one!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell, ask the question.
—He does not have the slightest idea what he is talking about.
—I know exactly what I am talking about. He has not got the slightest idea and nor has Senator Collins.
—Order! It is not really a supplementary question; it is an additional one. If the Minister wants to answer it, I will allow it.

—In answer to that additional question, all I can say is that there will not be a central register. There does have to be the provision for the Government to get its computer matching done. That obviously means that it must receive millions of pieces of information to get the job done. What we are ensuring is that no-one in the Department actually gets to see those bits of information. The only things that anyone in the Department will see will be possible matching. That is the only information followed up. Within three months all of that information is then destroyed; so privacy concerns are simply not there. Once again, I urge Senator Boswell to take time off from eating muesli bars and get out there and have a look at it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of comments by the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard, in one of his numerous statements in support of the now discredited Bjelke-Petersen regime, in which he is supportive of the voluntary employment agreements (VEAs) which operated under the former Queensland National Party Government? Does the Minister have any information to show whether Mr Howard's statement is correct and that the voluntary employment contracts introduced by the National Party Government played an important role in the success of Power Brewing Co. Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the first problem I have with so-called voluntary employment agreements is their title. It is Joh-speak or indeed Orwellian logic to say that what is proposed is in fact voluntary because what the word `voluntary' conjures up is an image of two equal and equally strong parties negotiating from an equal point of view and consenting freely to the outcome. That can hardly be characteristic of a situation in which management sits there with the full panoply of managerial prerogative, all of the resources of the company behind it, access to industry association information, and with the power to hire and fire, talking to ordinary workers in a one-on-one situation. In that situation in the worker's mind there must always be a question: `What happens if I dissent, and is my job in question if I do?', without an ordinary worker's access to the same information base in order to answer propositions being put.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think that the term `voluntary' is a fair characterisation of the sort of bargaining that is envisaged by this type of agreement. I think the first point is to beware of the language, which tries to encourage us to see something that is inherently exploitative as being voluntary in nature.

Turning to the Power Brewing example, I must say that Mr Howard is one of a number of conservative commentators who frequently say that Power Brewing had a voluntary employment agreement, Power Brewing got 15 per cent of the beer market in Queensland, ergo, voluntary employment agreements are the basis of that success. Given Power Brewing's penetration of the Queensland beer market, there may be some advantage in the exploitative type of relationship which it had through a voluntary employment agreement. But that type of mindless and illogical approach ignores the fact that of course the product was promoted by Wally Lewis in a very slick advertising campaign; it ignores the marketing fact; it ignores the taste of the product compared to others; it ignores the fact that Queenslanders objected to Alan Bond having his name on the bottom of a XXXX can and tended to move to another locally produced product; and it ignores the fact that in a new company, with new plant and equipment and better and newer technology, better production results are likely to be achieved; and it ignores the fact that in setting up the Power Brewing plant the Queensland National Party Government supplied cheap land at the Yatala industrial estate south of Brisbane for the purposes of setting it up. It ignores all those factors.

The Queensland Industrial Relations Commission on 25 September approved an interim enterprise award covering the operation of Power Brewing to replace the former VEA. The interim enterprise award will operate for about four weeks, until 2 November. The Commission is arbitrating on what will be the conditions to apply in the workplace between then.

Under the Queensland Industrial Relations Act, as it has now been amended, voluntary employment agreements expired on 30 September, and the secretive voluntary employment agreements that were introduced by the Queensland National Party Government in 1987, which provided that agreements between employers and employees were not open to the Commission's inspection or scrutiny, or they were not open to a public interest test and were not publicly accessible will now be replaced by a situation in Queensland paralleling section 115 of the Federal Act, where agreements can be reached between workers in an enterprise and the enterprise management but those agreements must be registered in the Commission and thus be open to inspection by other parties and scrutiny by the Commission.

My understanding, in conclusion, is that, given the new industrial freedom that workers at the Power Brewing company have, there has already been, by negotiation on their behalf by the union, a reduction in the number of hours worked, an increase in sick leave entitlements and improvements in shift penalty arrangements.

That being the case, given that these standards are open to scrutiny, I expect that we can look forward to an improvement in productivity knowing that the workers in that enterprise at least have a fair deal industrially.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. As a result of the new data matching procedures announced in the Budget, will the Department of Social Security be collecting tax file numbers and income information from the departments of Community Services and Health, Veterans' Affairs, and Employment, Education and Training? Will these tax file numbers of people who are not necessarily Social Security clients then be given to the Australian Taxation Office, which will return them with Tax Office income information? Will the Tax Office income information and the income information supplied by the other departments be cross-matched by Social Security and any possible incorrect payment results given to the departments from which the tax file numbers originally emanated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supplying the Taxation Office with tax file numbers; it will be supplying us. I cannot see much point in our re-supplying the Taxation Office with information it already has, so I do not imagine that we will do that. We will do exactly what we said we would do: we will get a matching of our own information with tax file numbers which will be supplied to us by the Taxation Office. By this method, we will detect quite a degree of fraud that previously we were unable to detect. At the end of the day, that will return some hundreds of millions of dollars to us.

ANSWER.PARA: All of this will be done by a process directed by a steering committee on which the Privacy Commissioner sits, so he will be involved in every step of the process. This means, of course, that if he sought to modify his guidelines at any point during that process because he felt that something new and different was occurring he would be able to do so, and we would abide by the guidelines that he had set. It is important to stress those guidelines because, without the Privacy Commissioner overseeing this operation, obviously there would be the potential, certainly not for this government but for future governments, to do the wrong thing. That simply will not happen.

In terms of reports to the Parliament, there is no way that this system can work without the Privacy Commissioner's monitoring being made publicly available to everyone. If there was any instance at all of my Department abusing the privilege that it would get from this, not only would I want to know about it and do something about it but also it would be my duty to draw it to the attention of the Senate, and I would do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the question: As a result of the new data matching procedures announced in the Budget, will the Department of Social Security be collecting tax file numbers and income information from the departments of Community Services and Health, Veterans' Affairs, and Employment, Education and Training?

—I do not think there is anything new in the question Senator Patterson has just asked. We have been through this process dozens of times. We will be collecting tax file numbers. We will be comparing them with our own social security information and the Privacy Commissioner will monitor those steps.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It relates to several reports attributed to him in today's newspapers following his rather bellicose and anti-environmental remarks about greenhouse gas reductions. Does the Minister really believe that the Toronto 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2005 cannot be met without damage to Australia's economic performance? Does he not accept that about 25 per cent of Australia's foreign debt has been caused by State electricity authorities building excess generating capacity and that enormous scope for improved electricity efficiency use exists using known and proved technology? Does he not accept that in other energy using areas of the economy, such as in land transport, including motor vehicles-I refer here, of course, to the so-called Button car plan-similar improvements could be made using existing technology? Does he not accept that a reduction in consumption is as good for the economy as an increase in output? Therefore, why can he not see that the 20 per cent greenhouse reduction targets could be met with an improvement in the economy rather than an adverse impact?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I declined to comment on the factors which have to be considered by the Government and, indeed, governments around the world in relation to the greenhouse gas issue. I did say that it was important for Australia to have regard to what was happening in other countries. That is a view from which I do not retreat at all. I think it is very important to have regard to the implications for Australia of reducing energy consumption, as Japan has done, by exporting a lot of industries to other countries where the same sort of environmental effects are taking place in probably less controlled circumstances. These are the sorts of issues which I think have to be taken into account. These are matters for discussion by Cabinet and, indeed, governments throughout the world in the next few weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of whether there has been wrong, false or misguided investment in electricity authorities around Australia- yes, I am sure that has occurred from time to time. The honourable senator has referred to the car plan. The car plan has nothing to do, and was never purported to have anything to do, with the question of emissions from motor vehicles. That issue is dealt with by a series of--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's hardly the point. Why shouldn't they?

—The Australian Democrats would solve all these things in one fell swoop, I presume. It is very easy to do when one is sitting over there in a tin shed at the bottom of the garden party discussing all these issues. The question of motor vehicle emissions is one which is controlled, monitored and dealt with by State and Federal governments under the various transport departments. That is the traditional manner of dealing with it. I am not saying that it is the best manner of dealing with it, but there are a whole range of issues in terms of future technologies which the motor vehicle industry has to face up to, including levels of fuel consumption and the types of fuels which are used. Of course those things have to be on the agenda.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding the question of energy consumption, I think there is an immense capacity for improvement in terms of Australia's levels of energy consumption, but they are not issues which can be dealt with tomorrow by any magic fairy from the Democrats, or anywhere else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister, in his reply, has referred to two things: the energy efficiency of the Japanese industry and the motor vehicle industry. Does he not accept that the Japanese get a tonne of steel using approximately half the amount of energy that Australia uses and it would be very much in our economic interests to pursue similar technologies? Moreover, does he not accept that one factor which has led to the dominance of the world car market by the Japanese is that the Japanese make fuel efficient vehicles and it would also be in our economic interests to make more fuel efficient vehicles?
—These are questions for a tutorial at high school. I would agree in part with many of those things, but so what? What follows from all that?
—Oh!

—Senator Powell thinks that is funny. Perhaps she ought to have a party meeting about this issue around there. In answering the major question, I agreed with most of what Senator Coulter put. Then he wants to, if I might use the expression, `recycle' a whole lot of other information which was really embraced in my answer to the first part of the question.
—What is the answer?

—`What is the answer?', says the Democrats interjector. The answer is: what is the question? Is it capable of being answered? The answer is that it is not capable of being answered because, in the context of what we are discussing in this chamber, in some ways it is too silly to be answered.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister, John Kerin, was presented with the Australian Wool Corporation's corporate plan at the end of September. He has chosen to selectively release parts of this plan to the press. In view of the importance to woolgrowers to be informed of what is proposed for their industry, when will this plan be released publicly?
—I table the media release by John Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, of 8 October announcing the Australian Wool Corporation's business plan for the wool industry.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. My question was: when will the details of the full plan be released publicly? They have not been.
—I will refer that part of the question to Mr Kerin and see whether he wants to answer it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to supplement an answer I gave earlier concerning automatic teller machines (ATMs) and the way in which the National Australia Bank Ltd has, very cooperatively, decided on modifications in relation to the keypads of such automatic teller machines.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, in a letter which recently arrived in my office from Mr Max Bray, the Chief General Manager, Development Ventures, National Australia Bank, he indicates that the National Australia Bank will modify its keypads and recline them at a 45 degree angle, which, as I indicated to the Senate, will help ensure the greater privacy of those persons using this particular facility.

The National Australia Bank proposes to modify the ATMs in the eastern States first-given the larger concentrations of consumers, no doubt-and hopes to complete this by March 1991. The remaining 200 machines will be modified over the following 12 months. That is very good news, indeed, and I believe that customers of the National Australia Bank, as of the Westpac Banking Corporation Ltd, will be well pleased with these modifications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Richardson on two occasions. The first occasion was when he said, in the course of a diatribe about the notice of motion which I gave this morning, that I, in particular, and the Opposition, in general, were just simply not in favour of sole parents. That is a preposterous and grotesque fabrication and I want to take the opportunity to clarify what Senator Richardson is clearly unwilling or unable to understand. He well knows that the number of sole parents has increased quite significantly in recent years-there are now something like 250,000 of them-and the cost to the taxpayer is in excess of $2 1/2 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: We, as an Opposition, and I, personally, have the greatest degree of sympathy for those sole parents and we well understand the problems they are confronted with, particularly in the present economic climate. But we also take the view-quite contrary to what Senator Richardson has tried to suggest-that it is often in their best interests, after they have been at home with their children in the formative years, for them to be more directly exposed to the labour market than they are at the present time. That is why we have advocated that the jobs, education and training (JET) scheme ought to be extended.

Senator Richardson again attempted to pour scorn on my suggestion this morning that somehow the JET scheme should be compulsory, and suggested that we were opposed to the operation of the JET scheme. The fact is that less than 5 per cent of sole parents are currently within the JET scheme and, of those, less than half are classified as labour market disadvantaged. To pretend, as he did, that the Government is interested in targeting those sole parents who need special assistance is quite wrong.

The other matter I want to clarify is that he referred to a television so-called debate several months ago, and repeated the absurd suggestion that when it comes to taking money off low income earners and sole parents the Opposition, in general, and I, in particular, are real tough but when it comes to tax avoidance, as he said, we would crawl across the Simpson Desert. Once again, he shows a profound misunderstanding of the distinction between tax avoiders and tax evaders.

But, putting that to one side, there is nothing that I have said in this capacity or in any other that could be possibly construed as giving solace to those who might seek to bend the corporate or tax rules. Most importantly, for present purposes, I have never in any shape or form suggested that we are in favour of taking money from low income earners or sole parents. The facts of the matter are that we are very interested in helping sole parents and low income earners in general by introducing them to not only a range of financial support mechanisms but also real labour market activity wherever possible. For Senator Richardson to suggest that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, you cannot turn this into a debate.

—I was endeavouring not to, Mr President, but I will be guided by your advice. Our approach has always been that as many attempts as possible ought to be made to create real work situations-that is, on-the-job training and not these mickey mouse labour market schemes that the Government seems so fond of that simply provide opportunities for navel gazing outside the work force. I take particular exception to the sorts of bully boy tactics that might work well at factional meetings but do not go down too well here.
—Oh, don't be so precious.
—I am not precious at all.
—Order!
—Can't you handle it?

—We can all handle it, but I do not think it is fair to the people of Australia to have Senator Richardson wandering around and suggesting that somehow we have policy positions that are quite wrong. I hope that the position is now clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. In answer to a question without notice on 19 September, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) claimed, in the same way as he did today to Senator Boswell, that I would not want to go and see the operation of the Department of Social Security computer centre at Deakin. I must say that the Minister made it possible for us to go and visit the Deakin centre by setting a date. It happened to be a time which would have coincided with the sitting of Estimates Committee C next Friday and I felt it was more important that I attend that meeting. Because of that, and because on the invitation there was an opportunity to make another time and I wanted to see this centre-contrary to the Minister's mistaken belief, I have wanted to go for a considerable period-on Monday I had that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to tell the Minister that I was not disappointed. I had it confirmed that from 1 January 1990 this computer centre will be the central benefits control base for the departments of Employment, Education and Training, Community Services and Health and Veterans' Affairs, as well as Social Security. I found out something the Minister could not tell me. I wonder whether he might go along so he can get the answers too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. The honourable senator is now debating the issue and is not making a personal explanation. She should be confined to making a personal explanation of where she was misrepresented, as she claims to have been, and explaining what was wrong with that. She should not debate an issue that was the subject of question and answer across this chamber.
—I am listening to Senator Patterson. I ask her to confine herself to her personal explanation.

—I am showing that I was interested in going along. I did not just go along and not find out what was there. I could have gone along, closed my eyes and walked out again. What I am demonstrating is my real interest in the Department and in the Deakin centre. It was also confirmed that tax file numbers would be used by the Department of Social Security to cross-match income information provided to it by all these departments with income information provided to it by the Australian Taxation Office. In making that personal explanation I am showing that I have a very keen interest in this area. I thank the Minister for Social Security not for his comments about my lack of interest but for the opportunity to visit the centre. I suggest that he go and visit or revisit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Richardson and seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Is leave granted?
—If it is a personal explanation, leave is granted.
—Leave is granted.

—In Question Time, Mr President, you suggested that I should make a personal explanation at this time. I am following your advice. Senator Richardson told the Senate today that I was not prepared to accept his invitation to go out to the Deakin centre. I saw little point in conducting a magical mystery tour around the Deakin centre when the necessary equipment that was called for by the tender document, so capably tabled today by Senator Bishop, was not even installed.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot see any point in going out and examining an empty computer base when the tenders are going to be called and the necessary equipment will be in there at some future time. I am interested in going out and seeing the equipment that has been called for by the tender document.

I ask Senator Richardson to extend a further invitation when the equipment that the tender documents have called for is in place. We will then be able to examine the machines and have all the information available to us. There is no point going out there now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. This is getting a bit tiresome, I must say. The purpose of a personal explanation is for senators to say where they believe they have been misrepresented and actually to put the socalled facts right. We now have an explanation of what Senator Boswell thought, what he believed, what he hoped, what he imagined and what he dreamed about. That is not a personal explanation. Mr President, I ask you to ask Senator Boswell either to make a personal explanation or to sit down.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. As you will recall, Senator Boswell was attacked during Question Time by Senator Richardson for failing to take up the invitation of the Minister to attend the computer centre. It seems to me quite clear that Senator Boswell is now explaining why he did not take up that invitation. That seems to be quite clearly within the Standing Orders. Certainly, I respectfully put to you that so far, in any event, he has not gone beyond them.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, I think Senator Boswell has been making a personal explanation. I think he was beginning to stray into debate. I would ask him to conclude his personal explanation.

—I willingly accept your ruling, Mr President. I conclude by saying that when the equipment is in place I hope that Senator Richardson will be courteous enough again to invite interested senators to visit the Deakin centre. I can give him an assurance that I will be there. But I am not going out there unless the equipment is in place.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, at 8.30 a.m. today, Senators Archer and Coulter submitted letters in accordance with standing order 75, one proposing a matter of public importance and the other a matter of urgency. In accordance with the standing order to decide which letter should be submitted to the Senate, I determined the matter by ballot, in the presence of a representative of Senator Archer and the Clerk of the Senate. As a result of that procedure, I now read Senator Archer's letter. The letter is dated 9 October, is addressed to me and proposes that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The devastating impact of the Government's economic policy on rural Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The future of Australian farming has never looked worse in my lifetime than it does now. The economy of Australia is shot to pieces as a result of badly flawed economic dogma and the years ahead will place enormous strains on rural and regional Australia. With an anti-rural bias, Australia has seen huge rises in costs, great losses in rural population and falling rural exports. The future is so bleak that Australia needs to be told exactly what the real state of affairs is.

SPEECH.PARA: For nearly all of the last 200 years the country has been renowned for its prowess in the production of both food and fibre. In a country where conditions of soils and climates have been very hard, the achievements in research and production have made Australian primary producers stand out as amongst the greatest in the world.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and many of the universities have been world leaders in breeding, management, pest and disease control and many other things. Agriculturally, Australia has a tremendous record. As a result of these and their own efforts and despite falling numbers, Australia's farmers more than doubled the gross value of farm production between 1982-83 and 1989-90, albeit at considerable cost.

In the same period farm indebtedness also doubled, so that by the end of 1989-90 the debt owed to financial institutions was almost $11 billion, some two to 2 1/2 times the level of the farm income in that year. In 1982 Australia last faced the horrors of extensive drought and, to make matters even worse, it was coupled with a major international economic downturn. Between those two, farm incomes in 1982-83 fell by a massive 80 per cent and many thousands of farmers went to the wall. The numbers are still diminishing-the number of rural establishments has fallen from 175,000 in 1982-83 to an estimated 150,000 today-and right now they are facing the sharpest reduction in my lifetime.

The one derisively referred to at that time as the world's greatest Treasurer (WGT), having done nothing to change either the drought or the recession, then proceeded with his long term plan of introducing his own brand of national economics. As his prime ministerial prospects continue to follow his popularity poll ratings, so unfortunately does this great country's reputation, stability and economic reliability.

This monetary policy paranoia is more than that. It is an obsession which has resulted in Australia having hit skid row on virtually every reasonably accepted economic scale of comparison available to us. We just did not become one of the world's top 10 in the overseas debt category; we had to work on it. It took Australia 80 years to accumulate overseas debt of $15 billion and just 10 more years to increase that tenfold to over $150 billion, on which the annual interest bill alone is of the order of $13 billion. This is the equivalent of almost 90 per cent of the value of the rural export trade of Australia last year. It was not the banks, it was not the farmers, it was not the Opposition: it was the direct result of the policies of the WGT himself.

Who pumped up the interest rates to 18, 19 and 20 per cent and kept on guaranteeing and assuring a continuation of high interest rates? Again, it was not the banks, it was not the farmers, it was not the Opposition, but the policies of the WGT himself. Who then accepted, aided and abetted a 16 per cent increase in the United States dollar value of the Australian dollar between 1986-87 and 1989-90, the dual effect of which was to depress the returns on our rural exports while increasing the interest bill on our overseas debt? It was the same man and the same Government.

Rural exports as a proportion of total exports of merchandise have declined from 36 per cent in 1982-83 to 32 per cent in 1989-90, largely because of the policy which has kept the value of the Australian dollar so artificially high. What did the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Government then do to unravel the situation that they had built? Did they say, 'These conditions will be disastrous for Australia's entire productive sector and we must do something about it.'? No, not a bit of it. Did they say, 'These conditions will bankrupt thousands of people and thousands of businesses because they will make them uncompetitive in the real world of international economics.'? Did the Treasurer or the Government say, 'Our producers will be less able to compete.'? Did they say that foreign interests will have a field day every day if we go on with these policies? Not at all.

Instead, we have come to live with all the new platitudes, such as, 'We are right on course'; 'We've got a lovely set of numbers'; 'We're right in the middle of the expectations'; 'The economy is slowing at about the right rate'; 'We are still heading for a soft landing'; and various other nonsense, while all the time Australians generally, but the productive sector particularly, were going down and down and down. The obsession then went to transferring a Federal deficit to become State cuts. These changes did not reduce taxes and costs; instead, they just made them the province of States and local government, resulting in the loss of services and increased costs all round.

In my own State, for instance, as a result of the last round the productive rural, forestry and mining sectors have had huge rises in land tax, municipal rates and payroll tax; the primary producers diesel fuel concession was cut; there were cuts in rural and regional health and education; cuts in technical and further education college courses; cuts in rural research and advisory services; removal of rural education living away from home allowance; increase in electricity charges; and cuts in road maintenance and so on. The result may well be a warm inner glow to the Treasurer, but certainly and positively it creates a severe reduction in the competitive capacity of all the industries involved and their employees.

In farming our productivity is magnificent. Our costs of production are the equal of any in the world for efficiency, and it is not those costs that affect our profitability. Again, it is the social costs. Consider the benefits that apply within Australia and the particular effects they have on the major commodities that Australia expects to sell profitably on world markets. With our productivity and our costs-such as four weeks annual holidays, 14 or 15 public holidays a year, paternity leave, et cetera-how do we really expect to compete with trading partners such as East Asia, North America, Europe and so on?

Whether or not I agree with all those comforts is of no consequence. What does matter is that this country simply cannot afford the standard of living that we have set ourselves. What I stress therefore is that the Government must take into account the capacity to pay when it is considering more of these cost increases and cost shifts that it has in mind. There is no benefit for employees who are awarded increased wages and conditions if those increases mean that they then have no job and we lose an industry as a result.

How would the Government members opposite like to be farm workers right now? I am told that, in spite of disastrous prices for wool and wheat, farm workers over the last 12 months have been granted wage increases of $60 a week-an amount that now obviously cannot be met, at the cost of thousands of jobs. We only need to follow that through with the wool and wheat industries nationwide and various other industries on a regional basis-such as rice growing in the Riverina and potato growing in Tasmania-to see what the situation is like. Surely farming has its ups and downs, and just as surely farmers must be encouraged to save for bad weather and bad economic times; but bad government is very hard to plan for. So, in the opinion of the Government, the best way to level out those vagaries is to start off by destroying the income equalisation deposit scheme, the scheme put together especially to encourage self-help.

Then there is tax. The complexity of the tax system is still getting worse. The Bill before us this week gave us another 236 pages of legislation, which took 416 pages of explanation to tell even skilled practitioners how to interpret it. Is it any wonder that Australian taxpayers are now spending $3.8 billion or 11 per cent of their personal tax just to submit their taxation returns? In other words, preparing returns is just as much a tax as the tax itself. The farmers are the prime victims of this gross incompetence, when clearly the efforts should be going into producing a new, simplified and equitable taxation scheme that can as far as possible be operated by any reasonably intelligent taxpayer himself without huge supplementary fees.

Let me come back to interest rates. We are not just playing some gigantic game of monopoly; it is all very much for real. Interest rates are still hovering in the region of 17 to 20 per cent and they are absolutely horrendous and a disaster for the productive sector. Has the Government any idea of the chaos created by its high interest rates policy on business and farming interests? Has it ever asked or properly inquired? Just how out of touch can it be? Does it know or care about the uncertainty that this and other costs create for those in the productive sector, which we all depend on?

The foreign interests love us. They flood us with imports. They defend themselves against our exports and they skim off the highest interest that they could ever have hoped for. Has this Government ever considered the effects of high interest, even in areas such as property rentals and the way in which that flows on to add cost to our rural communities? In turn, high interest rates have also produced enormous changes in investment patterns, out of equities and into high marginal operations.

Farming, however, is a long term operation. It takes years and years to get a livestock breeding operation off the ground. It takes years and years to get fruit trees or vines to come into bearing. It takes years and years of trials to establish new crops and new varieties of vegetables or pastures. But has the Government recognised that? What steps have been taken to offer some security for those looking to get away from the pursuits that could be seen to be getting risky with oversupply or world market changes or other matters?

Let us look at forestry. I wonder what is the Australian Labor Party's policy on forestry. What security can be demonstrated to people looking to the next 50 years or so? Who can tell me whether we are discussing now sustainable development for various forest classes or whether we may be talking about ecologically sustainable development-and, in fact, the difference between the two? What I can tell honourable senators is that the extra word makes all the difference.

In Tasmania, as a result of the Labor Party's policies and deals, we are still burning millions of tonnes of first class chip wood in what amounts to criminal waste when every stick of that should be going into pulp and paper. We go on fighting so that in the main the land we are talking about can be replanted with trees, hopefully for ultimate conversion to sawlogs. But in the meantime we are burning it. What sort of economics is that? Policies such as this have an absolutely devastating effect on rural Australia and on the economy generally.

I return to other policies and actions where the Labor Government is so slack that no decisions are being made in so many areas. I have been asking questions for months on certain aspects of quarantine decisions, and I pick them up again here. I refer to the importation of pork from Canada. What will the Government do if there is an outbreak of disease? What is the policy? All I am told is, `Wait and see when it happens'. Then there is the problem of fireblight in apples. What will the Government do if there is an outbreak in Australia as a result of injudicious import? We will wait to see what happens. What about honey infection from chalkbrood, and what about the hundreds of thousands of tonnes of ballast water discharged in Australian waters, and what about the serious effects of the dinoflagelettes on our inshore shellfish operators? What is the Government's policy, and is that policy designed to protect the Australian producer, or is the main consideration going to the various overseas interests?

I also raise the issue of imported foodstuffs labelling. While I have no objection to people buying foreign produce, if that is their wish, I believe there should be a policy that imported goods should be much more clearly marked to let those who prefer to buy Australian be sure they do so. Let us have a policy on that, too.

I return to the farmers' problems. We have tens of thousands of farmers who are at least as efficient as any in the world. Year after year farmers have been extending their holdings, running more stock and growing more crops, just to survive. Their returns per person employed or per hectare, or whatever, continue to astound agriculturalists around the world. But it has inevitably been done to survive and this survival has been bought on borrowed funds.

We support the family farmer. We believe it is a more preferable system to huge corporate farms. But the family that has borrowed is now the family in dire trouble. Many of those have had generations of association with the industry, many on the same properties for in excess of 100 years. Most regrettably, that will not save them now.

I wonder whether amongst the weekend reading of the Treasurer and in amongst the antique dealers guides, et cetera, he gets around to reading Land, the Weekly Times or Stock and Land and reads the pages and pages of heartbreak and disaster that go with all those thousands of rural properties now on the market Australia-wide. As a result of this Government's policies, Australia has simply priced itself out of world markets. Other countries just cannot be expected to pay for the extravagances and economic mismanagement that we have taken on.

How does this Government support our farmers, and how do other countries support their farmers? How does it compare with how the Government looks after, say, our car industry? Why is it that the Government believes that our farmers, unlike those anywhere else in the world, can survive as price takers in a totally corrupted international market? I am not asking for subsidies nor suggesting that subsidies would solve Australia's rural problems, but I do ask why it is that our Treasurer believes that he can continue to take actions and stubbornly stick with failed policies that are clearly so damaging to Australia's biggest and most traditional international earner?

I give honourable senators one example. In my area there is the question of imported frozen potatoes from Canada. We all know that a high volume, low price product can only be moved long distances around the world if there is a price fiddle. So right in the middle of this, the Government is now talking about a further cut of another 10 per cent off the tariff that comes with those at the expense of what is Tasmania's best and biggest industry. Surely the Government is not anxious to have farmer demonstrations, but can you wonder that we have reached that stage. What may be lovely numbers to Mr Keating are the sound of disaster in rural Australia. We have had talk of the Argentinean Road and of a banana republic, but what all Australians want to know is: how close are we?

We must ask the Minister to make a statement in the Parliament of the absolute truth of Australia's financial position and, in particular, of the real state of the rural economy. What we have had has not been good enough. The people deserve to know and must know. We are all sick of these flowery, sugar-coated misrepresentations.
