For years we have been soft-soaped with a terrible failed accord. Never since day one has it done anything for the man on the land to control costs or increase productivity. It may well have softened problems between the Government and some of its more difficult masters, but it has done nothing for the farmers except for them to cop the flow-on, cost them more, put them further at odds with their international competitors and, as it stands now, hasten their entry into financial destruction. So much for the accord.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, for instance, takes all the information and gives a variety of forecasts. The Australian Bureau of Statistics gets the figures and provides trends and records. How is it that so suddenly and so drastically we fell into a heap with these two largest rural industries without any warning bells by the Government or others before the event?

In this debate Senator Boswell and Senator Panizza, both with wide experience of non-metropolitan Australia, will develop special issues. There are so many questions I must place at the feet of the Government. Rural Australia wants the answers. It wants them from the Government, and it wants them now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When notice of this matter of public importance first came around I read it and thought, `What a silly statement'-`The devastating impact of the Government's economic policy on rural Australia'. There are two major problems in Australian agriculture now. The first is the price of wheat. That is caused by a very large harvest in the Northern Hemisphere and by the propensity of the European Community and the United States to subsidise exports. That has absolutely nothing to do with the economic policies of the Australian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The second major problem is wool. It is not a question of price per se, but the fact that at the minimum price which has been set, only about one-third is being sold and 25 per cent of the gross proceeds are currently being taken or about to be taken in the levy to finance the stockpile or to partially finance it. Who is responsible for that? Effectively, the price of wool has fallen a great deal. It is being propped up by withholding from the market somewhat more than 50 per cent of Australia's current production. In other words, the market price is not being met.

Why has that happened? There are two reasons. The principal one is that on the demand side the major communist economies in the world-Russia and China-have gone broke and are not buying any more wool. Is that going to be attributed to the economic policies of the Australian Government?

The second reason that the wool industry is in real trouble is the ill-advised decisions made by the industry elders-there is no pun intended there-in 1987 and 1988 when there was a sharp upward movement in the market price of wool, way above the long term trend, and these clowns thought it would be a good idea to follow it up with the reserve price.

If honourable senators want to hand out blame for the problems of the wool industry, they should start handing it out to people like Hugh Beggs, Chip Sawers, and that near-unique bunch of neanderthals in the New South Wales Farmers Federation, because they are the people who made the decision to jack that up and the people who steadfastly resisted the attempts by the Government-and, I acknowledge, with the full support of the Liberal Party component of the Opposition-to bring the wool market back to something approaching reality and lower the reserve price. They are the people who have done more than anybody in Australia to create the present problems in the wool industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you bring the value of the dollar down, you will help.

—I will come to that. I mentioned the near-unique bunch of neanderthals in the New South Wales Farmers Federation. Why I say they are near-unique is because they have something nearly as bad as themselves or nearly as antediluvian as themselves in Queensland. I suspect it is no coincidence that Queensland and New South Wales are the only two States where the Country Party-cum-National Alliance-cum National Party remains a significant political force. Farmer organisations in the main throughout the rest of the country are much more attuned to reality than they are in New South Wales and Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: If anybody wants to level some partially justified criticism at the Government, or John Kerin in particular, they might criticise him with some justification for allowing the floor price for wool to be jacked up to 870c in 1988, at the staunch recommendation, of course, of the Wool Council of Australia and the Australian Wool Corporation-Beggs, Sawers, the New South Wales Farmers Federation and Co.

Certainly with the wisdom of hindsight, it is clear that that should have been stopped, but it would have been extremely difficult at that time when the market price was well above the 870c floor price level and the Corporation was sitting on cash reserves of more than $1.5 billion. It would have been extremely difficult for any Minister or any government to say at that stage, `The Government knows better than the people who are supposed to be representing the industry, and we will not let you jack it up to 870c'. As I said, with the wisdom of hindsight it clearly would have been a better option, but I doubt whether there would have been much support from the Opposition had Mr Kerin or the Government so intervened at that time. Given that the conventional wisdom, particularly of the New South Wales Farmers Federation, is that people in the industry are the people who really know what is going on, they are certainly in no position to criticise John Kerin for that.

Concerning Senator Archer's comments, I would have had a little more sympathy in regard to interest rate levels and the exchange rate-and I will return to that later-had he not sat silent and inert like a stuffed bullfrog throughout the nearly 7 1/2 years of the Fraser Government, when that Government deliberately maintained in a regulated financial system an overvalued Australian dollar in an attempt to control inflation.

We then heard him complain about wrecking income equalisation deposits (IEDs). Income equalisation deposits are a complex question. They are a taxation measure and I will not try to explain them fully. But I will tell the Senate, and anybody else who wants to listen, that income equalisation deposits were supposed to be a device which, when utilised, would equalise the taxable income of Australian farmers by paying deposits in in years of high income and withdrawing money in years of low income.

Because of rorts introduced by the Fraser Government in 1977-at the instigation, needless to say, of the Countrycum-National Party-the way to minimise tax liability over the long term was to pay money into income equalisation deposits in years of low income and take it out in years of high income. I am not going to try to explain all the arithmetic reasons why that was so, but it was because of a rort introduced at that time which turned IEDs into a device not to stabilise after-tax income but actually to provide an incentive to destabilise after-tax income.

That is the sort of sordid little rort which the Government of which Senator Archer was a back bench member for 7 1/2 years perpetrated and about which he said nothing. I was waiting, of course, for Senator Archer to revert to type, that is, to display yet again his troglodytic protectionism, and I was not disappointed.

History never exactly repeats itself, but there is a precedent for the current wool and wheat industry problems and for problems to be hitting both of those major agricultural industries at the same time, and that happened in 1970. The problem in 1970 was different in this respect: because there was a free market at that stage it was the price of wool which was the problem. Eventually, because of that, a floor was put under at a level of 30c. Thirty cents a pound, even after allowing for a fair bit of inflation, is a great deal less, obviously, than 870c a kilo, even though the latter is clean.

With the wheat industry it was not a question of the price of wheat per se, because at that time a coalition government-again at the instigation of the Country-cum National Party-had a guaranteed price for a limited amount of wheat based on some nonsensical concept which used to be called the cost of production. The Government was liable to make up the difference between the market realisation and the guaranteed price based on this nonsensical thing which used to be called the cost of production.

Just to demonstrate how nonsensical that was, let me say that the wheat industry had complained throughout the 1960s that wheat growers were producing wheat for less than the cost of production. Then when the Tory Government introduced wheat quotas in 1969, growers fought tooth and nail for the right to produce wheat-that is, to get a quota-to sell at what they had been asserting for a decade was below the cost of production. It might be hard for the Country Party to work out why that does not make sense, but I can assure it that it does not.

At that stage, of course, it was not the price of wheat per se which was the problem, it was the existence of wheat quotas. There has been a precedent. It is most unfortunate in 1990, as it was most unfortunate in 1970, that the two major agricultural industries have a world market induced slump in prices or in demand at the same time. It was unfortunate then; it is unfortunate now.

The grain of truth-microscopic though it is-in the argument that has been put up by Senator Archer is that, yes, it is true that as a demand management tool the Government has relied for about two years on tight monetary policy and, consequentially, high interest rates. However, that is not an unambiguous negative for agriculture. Not all farmers owe money. Some farmers have quite substantial cash balances. They have been the beneficiaries of high interest rates, not the victims, but my expectation is that there will be more farmers owing money than holding cash balances.

There is the secondary consideration that high interest rates are believed-and, other things being equal, I believe it-to have maintained an Australian dollar exchange rate higher than it would otherwise have been. That is conceded. It is hard to quantify but in principle I do not think anybody could argue against it. But it is not that simple, as we have seen recently.

Official interest rates have fallen by nearly 4 per cent over the last six months or so. The Australian dollar has actually gone up. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and I think Senator Button yesterday, all had a go at talking it down. Even that did not work. Interest rates came down. We had the three most senior people in the Government publicly saying that the dollar was overvalued and, after a little bit of a blip, even that did not bring it down. Why is this?

I believe that markets in the long term make rational judgments. But, in the short term, the cowboys of the forex market are no more guided by reason and are just as likely to be guided by what Cain has called `animal spirits' and what others might call `speculative feedback' than the cowboys of the stock exchange who thought that a licence for a television station in Sydney and Melbourne was worth $1 billion, though some pedants point out that it was not actually $1 billion; it was $800m for the two Channel 9s plus a promissory note for $200m that was worth nothing.

From time to time markets have been irrational in the short term. That is what is now going on in the foreign exchange market, just as the market was irrational in 1986 when the Australian dollar fell to US57.2c, and would undoubtedly have fallen further had the Reserve Bank of Australia not intervened pretty heavily.

That is a microscopic kernel of truth in the complaints that the Opposition has made and the degree to which Government economic policy has contributed, very much at the margin, to the problems that plague a couple of agricultural industries.

Some farmers are facing insolvency. I will set the background to that. As a normal part of the operation of a capitalist-I do not use that term in a pejorative sense-or a market economy, some firms will be facing insolvency, becoming bankrupt and being wound up. In a healthy market economy businesses are always being wound up, frequently because the proprietors have become insolvent, if not bankrupt. In agriculture, because the prices for agricultural products are cyclical, as are seasons variable, this tends to be bunched. At particular times there is a larger shake-out than there is likely to be in other Australian industries, be they retail, trade, manufacturing or whatever. But always some farmers will get out of agriculture because they have not succeeded financially in that industry.

In some cases individual farmers are insolvent because they have bought overpriced land, aggravated, it is true, at the margin, by an increase in interest rates. But the fundamental mistake was to purchase overpriced land. Anybody who continues borrowing money to buy overpriced assets, be it land or television licences, and be that person John Elliott, Alan Bond or an ordinary Australian wheat farmer, will become insolvent. That is an arithmetic truism. Some of the farmers who have in the past been insolvent, have gone out of the industry and are currently insolvent fall into that category.

According to the most recent evidence presented to me, there is still an alarming propensity for wheat and sheep farmers in particular to overinvest in plant and equipment, to have per unit of production or unit of land cropped a plant investment two and three times higher than those of other farmers operating the same areas who still manage to achieve the same sorts of results. That is bad management. There are quite a few of those. Their financial position, as with everybody else, of course, is aggravated by bad management.

There is another group-a very much smaller one, but it is worth mentioning because of the innate absurdity of what was done. Just over two years ago-two years and four months ago-there were farmers in Western Australia who were paying more than $100 for merino wethers. Even if wool prices had been maintained at the then extraordinarily high levels, there is no way that those farmers would have got their money back. I would not mind taking a punt that they had borrowed the money to do it from Elders Pastoral or some other stock firm, and were encouraged by Elders Pastoral or some other stock firm to borrow the money to pay those ridiculously high prices. It is very sad for the individuals concerned. To some extent, they are victims of circumstance; to some extent, they must face the consequences of previous unsound management decisions which they themselves have made.

What would the Opposition have the Government do-lower interest rates? I think that was implicit in what Senator Archer said. Interest rates have come down by 4 per cent; the exchange rate has gone up. The wheat industry could turn around in a very short period. One bad harvest in the northern hemisphere and the outlook for wheat will be changed entirely, something which financial institutions ought to bear in mind.

It is much more difficult to see the wool industry getting out of its fundamental problems for a very long time- problems, I emphasise again, due to a substantial degree to the appalling leadership that the wool industry received from the people who were supposed to represent it. If one wants to criticise the Government, one could add a bit on to that and say that the Government should not have let these people do it in 1987 and 1988. But I bet there would not have been too much support on the Opposition side of the Senate or on the comparable side of the House of Representatives if John Kerin had done that in 1987 or, more particularly, in 1988.

Businesses go broke. What does the Opposition want-a guarantee against bankruptcy, such as that which the United States Congress or the United States Federal Government gave to savings and loans societies?

In a way, I am sad that I am speaking first. It would have been much more fun to speak after Senator Boswell and Senator Spindler, but I have already made a few comments about the National Party. I have little doubt that another bottle of snake oil will be produced by the Australian Democrats. It is worth reminding farmers and other politicians that the Democrats' policy for agriculture includes a proposal to impose a tax on agricultural chemicals and then use the proceeds to subsidise organic farming. If one wants a one-shot formula to destroy the economic viability of Australian agriculture, one could not devise anything more certain than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the devastating impact of the Government's economic policy on rural Australia. It may be as well to start with the extent of that devastating impact. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics predicts that net farm cash income is expected to fall by 32 per cent in 1990-91 to $4.6 billion after remaining largely unchanged in the previous year. I have a figure from Victoria. In May we had an unemployment rate in western Victoria almost 50 per cent higher than that of Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to Western Australia. I quote from the West Australian of 9 October 1990:

The rural crisis will cost WA's economy $1.6 billion. Preliminary estimates show the gross value of rural production could fall as much as $640m in 1991 in WA. With the flow-on in losses in rural goods and services the cost is approximately $1.6 billion.

I understand that in a couple of days the Western Australian State Government plans to announce a special task force to combat the rural crisis. There is an estimate that, even so, some 5,000 people could leave Western Australian country towns by Christmas unless virtually a miracle happens.

The Government obviously will point to the worldwide drop in commodity prices, as Senator Walsh has done. We should perhaps get that out of the way first. The Bureau again, which is a professionally independent research organisation that is attached to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, in its latest edition of its excellent agricultural and resources quarterly, says that the rural commodities price index is forecast to fall by 19 per cent during 1991. Last year it fell by only 3 per cent. Falls are expected in the international prices for wool, wheat by some 40 per cent, dairy products and sugar. Rice and sheep meat are also predicted to have tough times ahead, and even the beef industry is expecting an easing in export volumes mainly because of the uncertainty surrounding the Japanese market.

Let me turn now to some of the other reasons, apart from the drop in commodity prices. I, and the Australian Democrats, believe that a large part of the crisis now facing the rural sector can be put at the feet of the Government and its high interest rate policy. The policy is intended to bring down our foreign debt but, as such, it is a blunt instrument. It is inequitable in that it falls only on those people who have borrowed money for whatever reason. It is a silly policy economically because it falls on people who borrow funds for productive purposes, and farmers belong to that category. They have taken loans for new machinery, land and improvements, very often encouraged by banks which, in the last two or three years following deregulation, had funds awash and wanted to get rid of them. Farmers in other countries, against which we are competing, are paying half or at the most two-thirds of the interest rates that our farmers are paying.

Very often inflation has been touted as the main reason for the problems of our primary products on overseas markets. No less a person than Dr Gus Hooke of the National Farmers Federation has stated that this is not the prime reason, that interest rates and exchange rates must come down. In the latest summary which has been provided to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) only a week or so ago, he suggests that we need a drop of 3 per cent in the interest rate and a decline of 9 per cent in the exchange rate if we manage to increase domestic expenditure by $408 billion, and that can be achieved only by increasing economic activity.

The Government has not only created this problem of high interest rates in its single-minded attempt to bring down our foreign debt, it has also deregulated primary industries. Since July 1987 the subsidies for dairy products have been substantially reduced. By January 1992 all these levies will have been eliminated, thereby significantly reducing farmers' income in that particular sector. I might say in passing that perhaps Senator Walsh should note that, while wool and wheat are certainly our main primary exports, farmers are engaged in the dairy industry, in orchards and in other primary production. Potatoes were mentioned by Senator Archer. We need to look at the primary sector as a whole. The butter levy has been eliminated and the sugar embargo has been lifted and replaced with a 35 per cent tariff, but this tariff will be down to 15 per cent by 1992.

Tariffs on dried fruits and citrus products have also been reduced greatly. The abolition of the income equalisation deposit scheme has been mentioned before. So the Government is not taking any steps to assist farmers, people living in country areas. We have taken deregulation to the country. Our exchange rate has obviously been propped up by our interest rate. It is now well above US80c when it should be around 65c to 70c to enable us to be competitive on overseas markets.

I am indebted to the Democrat member, Mike Elliott, in the South Australian Parliament, who provided me with some information on the comparison of hourly labour costs converted into Australian dollar values and produced by the South Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association. I think this will give us some indication of the competitive pressures that Australian primary producers are facing overseas. In Australia, one hour of a worker in, say, a cannery costs $11.18; in South Africa it is $1.34; in Greece it is $4.73; in Spain it is $6.29; in Chile it is $0.94 and in Argentina it is $1.24.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Philippines?

—I do not have a figure for the Philippines, but I am sure that it would be close to the figure for Chile. These are the sorts of wage rates that we are competing against. It is no wonder that canneries in Victoria have advised growers that they will not be able to take a large proportion of their fruit this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Other governments are taking some action to maintain viability of their primary industries. In the European Community the measuring stick being used is the stable use of agricultural resources and a reasonable return to growers. Even processors are subsidised so that their wages can be maintained at reasonable rates, yet in trying to get some value added component into our exports we are prepared to let our growers and producers compete against the sorts of wage rates that I have just quoted. Where we do try to make some adjustment-I mentioned the canners and fruit growers and the problems that they have in areas in South Australia and Victoria-we are doing it, believe it or not, at the expense of other producers-in this case, potato producers.

I refer to a proposal which is now being negotiated with Canada. We are apparently prepared to reduce our protective tariffs on frozen potatoes, asparagus, cherries and strawberries in return for Canada's reducing the tariffs on pears, apricots, peaches and mixed fruits. Obviously our canneries need help, but who makes the decision that potato growers do not need help? Who actually decides that we can make that sort of trade-off? Is the decision simply based on the fact that the Government does not have a safe seat in a particular area, a seat that is at risk on the Government side?

I believe that we need measures which will assist not only primary industry but also the economy as a whole. If we are looking at the sorts of wage rates that are being paid overseas and compare the conditions that the workers work under, the workers compensation that they have not got, the conditions regarding their health that apply to them and to their families, are we really prepared as a community to allow our workers and our industries to compete against people who have been forced to work under conditions which are below acceptable standards?

I think that particular question goes further. The Australian Government, to its credit, is now pushing the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to remove polluters' advantages. In other words, where environmental conditions are not as stringently enforced as they are in Australia, people should be exposed to tariff protection against their products in Australia. As a community, we need to ask ourselves whether we are prepared to make primary producers carry the burden for the living standards that we enjoy, or whether the community as a whole should.

I am not asking for general tariff protection. However, I am asking for selective tariff protection, and I am asking for effective anti-dumping provisions. It is quite clear that these are not working satisfactorily at the moment. It is quite clear that, when we have to prove not only that the product that is being imported is priced below the production costs in the country of origin but also that our industry is effectively destroyed, we are putting barriers into the paths of our own industries, which are feeling the destructive brunt of dumping before they have a chance to take any action.

There are other matters to be investigated in this area apart from the actual procedures-for instance, the margin to middlemen. Many products-such as citrus fruit concentrate-are imported from overseas. The profits here are being made by the middlemen who are handling them, placing them on the market at a little below the price of the local product but sufficient to knock the local product out of the market. I know that my friend Senator Boswell has been trying for some time to get an inquiry into dumping procedures off the ground. I wish him well and assure him of our support. If Senator Boswell has some difficulty with his Party-and I do not expect he will-or perhaps with the coalition, we can move and put the pressure on both the Opposition and the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us worry about that one.

—I have assured the Opposition of our support. We really need to look at whether we want to take deregulation to the point where it damages the fabric of our society to an extent that we cannot retrieve it.

SPEECH.PARA: No assessment of the crisis in rural areas would be complete without looking at the position that people there face in terms of social security and other benefits. We are now being faced with targeting in many areas of social security and, in times of financial stringency, that is essential. However, in this year's Budget an assets test is proposed on family allowance from 1 January 1990, which places---

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Spindler, your time having expired, I call Senator Boswell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance today is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The devastating impact of the Government's economic policy on rural Australia.

I have been associated with the National Party for some 20 years and I have made many trips into rural Australia and rural Queensland. I can honestly say that this is the worst time that I have ever seen for people in rural Australia. They seem to be hit from so many areas.

Normally, as Senator Walsh said, agriculture is cyclical-it has its ups and downs, as every other industry does-but it seems that the whole spectrum of problems has descended on agriculture in one year. We have been caught in the crossfire between the agricultural economies of the European Economic Community and the United States of America. It has dropped the price of our wheat by some $40 a tonne. Our wool industry is in a very precarious position.

I do not want to talk these industries down, and I am always frightened of these debates for that reason, but I do want to tell Senator Walsh that I believe he trivialised the debate somewhat. He picked on two industries-wheat and wool-and he said that the fall in the price of wheat was caused by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the loss of markets in Iraq and Iran.

He then talked about wool. There are two distinct opinions on whether the floor price of wool should have been dropped. I do not think it really helps us to go into the argument, but Mr Kerin made a unilateral decision to drop the wool price from 870c to 700c. Whether the price should have been at 870c is a different matter-it is another matter to argue with or about. When that floor price went down-when it was destabilised and talked down by Mr Kerin-as soon as the Parliament reassembled, there were questions by Senator Cook, there were questions in the House, there were doorstops and all sorts of things that promoted the loss of sales; and the Australian Wool Corporation was buying more and more until it became inevitable, according to Mr Kerin, that the price was too high.

Unfortunately, I believe, that stampeded the market. It has caused a loss of confidence on the part of buyers. People overseas are not prepared to buy in case their competitor is able to buy cheaper than they can and make their wares uneconomical. We had a stable market destabilised. I know there are sensitivities in the House about that and I do not particularly want to open up those wounds again.

Senator Walsh also said that there are some beneficiaries of high interest rates. Sure, there are some wealthy farmers and there is the squattocracy, but for every wealthy person that I know in rural Queensland-the area that I know best-I know of hundreds and hundreds of battlers. These are people who have been kangaroo shooters, bought a little paddock, then bought a bigger paddock and put a fair sized property together: people who have started small and tried to build up. These are the people who are being really hurt by the Government's policies. High inflation, high interest rates-these are the sorts of people who are really copping it.

Apart from the two areas of wheat and wool, there are many other policies that this Government has inflicted on rural Australia over the last eight years that have shown absolutely no sympathy whatsoever. I do not think the Government even shows any understanding of the whole problem. For eight years we have seen a policy direction of this Government that could be described only as hostile to rural Australia. There have been some major changes; there has been a lot of nitpicking; there has been the drop in the wool price, which was a major problem; but over the years we have seen policies that have been implemented that have really hurt rural Australia.

At the moment, rural Australia has devastating problems. Mr Kerin has to accept that responsibility-it is his responsibility. He should be in there fighting for rural Australia. Today, Mr Peter Taylor of the New South Wales Farmers Association, said:
No-one has done more to damage Australian agriculture than the present Primary Industries Minister, John Mr Kerin.

Yesterday in Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) called Mr Kerin the farmers' friend. Mr Kerin is not a bad public relations person, but it is dawning on Australian farmers that he has not delivered for them. He goes out and talks to them, making the right noises, but he has never delivered one thing for them. There is a rural committee, made up of Mr Brian Courtice, the member for Hinkler--

TALK.START.PARA: —A cane farmer.

—He was a cane farmer. Mr Courtice let his farm. I do not know whether he was able to make ends meet. Maybe he wanted to get into politics. Mr Courtice is not a cane farmer. I think he was a vegetable farmer and had cane at one stage. He says that there is no crisis. The Government back bench committee claims that the farming community is over-reacting and that no crisis exists. Mr Courtice said that he does not believe or agree that rural Australia is in a crisis or about to collapse. Mr Rob Hulls has said that the Government's economic policies are working, albeit slower than a lot of people would like. If that is the sort of sympathy that rural Australia can expect from a Labor back bench rural committee, God help rural Australia. If Mr Courtice and Mr Hulls, whose electorate is largely a sheep growing one, do not realise that there is a crisis in their electorates, the most generous position I can put on it is that they know not what they do.

SPEECH.PARA: Since taking office in 1983, Labor has embarked on a high tax, high inflation, high interest rates regime that has damaged our export industries. These macro-economic policies have increased costs to producers, particularly in capital and labour. As Senator Archer mentioned in his speech, there has also been the accord. That accord was designed to produce productivity, which has not come about. Senator Walsh would agree with that. He has made statements on it. What the accord has done and all the agreements that the Government has made with the unions have done has been to effectively increase the cost of labour by 25 per cent. Including the 6 per cent for superannuation, the 1 1/2 per cent for training, the 38-hour week and a number of other things that have taken place, it has cost Australia 25 per cent more to employ a person than it did last year. The Australian rural producer cannot pass on that cost. Rural producers are price takers, not price makers. They compete against overseas countries whose input costs are much lower. However, that has never been recognised.

The Government has introduced the capital gains tax which has made it almost impossible for a farmer to buy out his farm and turn it over into a larger farm. It is also a death duty because when a farm is passed down to a family no duty applies, but when a farm is sold-when it passes from that family-a capital gains tax is introduced. If a farmer has four sons who all want their share from the inheritance, the farm must be sold. Therefore, we have a de facto death duty with a capital gains tax.

An assets test has been applied to people receiving pensions, Austudy and family allowance. There are thousands of properties that at the moment are worth a considerable amount of money mortgaged up to the hilt and not producing income-in fact, they have negative income. Yet those country people are not able to educate their children as well as city people are. They are not able to obtain family allowances or pensions. Funds for isolated children's education have been cut and patients' contributions to the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme have been increased. Labor has abolished agricultural machinery bounties, the liquefied petroleum gas subsidy, the superphosphate subsidy and practically all the petroleum products freight subsidies.

The nitpicking in these areas is hurting rural Australia. It is not so much the wheat and wool industries, although they have major problems, but for over eight years we have had this running attack on primary industry. The Government has systematically increased revenue from primary industry levies up to $850m this year. Meat export industry charges increased 200 per cent in the first Labor Budget and were increased again in the latest Budget. Mr Kerin and all members of Cabinet-I include Senator Tate-knew that Australia was in a rural crisis, yet their answer in the latest Budget was to increase export subsidies. That shows no sympathy for the plight of rural Australia.

The Government has introduced full cost recovery for customs inspection, imposing a further burden on rural Australia. This does not just affect one industry; it affects all sectors of the rural community. Woolgrowers have suffered a 30 per cent decline in their income. Wheatgrowers are in terrible trouble. I will leave that to Senator Panizza as he understands the industry a lot better than I do. However, the industry has reached a 40-year low.

In the eight years of this Labor Government we have not seen any understanding of the needs of rural Australia. Yesterday I raised the matter of imports flooding into this nation at a rate of $2 billion a year-food that can be grown by Australian farmers. Because it is subsidised, with one stroke of a pen--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an interest in primary production because I come from a family which is still involved in that occupation. In fact, today my brother is attending the sale of his wool. Hopefully all his 17-micron wool will reach a reasonable price. I listened with great interest to the comments and arguments from both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats and not one solution did I find, except that interest rates are too high and we should drop the value of the dollar. However, Senator Walsh has very carefully pointed out that there is not an apparent nexus between the two because interest rates have fallen and the dollar has risen. So I do not know what the Opposition would expect us to do if that is its solution. It has given us no solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to deal with several issues today. One is commodity policy and one is the welfare net and the care we provide as a government to people in rural areas. Let me say that when I talk about rural areas I am not just talking about farmers. There is more to areas outside the central business districts of Newcastle, Sydney and Wollongong-or in other States, Brisbane and Ipswich-than sheep and cattle.

A bit over a third of Australia's population live outside of the metropolitan areas. We are providing policies and caring for those people who, as a group of individuals, require assistance in the same way as do people living in the cities.

In making some general comments about why the rural downturn is emerging and the proper way to deal with it, let me reiterate that we are subject to international forces. We do not live in a country with a brick wall around it and which can dictate what is going to happen elsewhere. That is important to remember.

Many things are beyond our control and are brought about by events overseas. Surely honourable senators are not unaware of the fact that last year the Chinese army invaded Tiananmen Square. Surely they are not unaware that there is conflict in the Middle East-in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq. This has an important and major effect on us. We cannot live without being aware of what our neighbours are doing.

These fluctuations, crises and problems do cause frustration and anger in the rural community. I am sure that this frustration helps to breed resilience in country people. But it also encourages them to be active and to take action. I have no objection to that. But people should make sure that it is constructive comment and criticism.

In highlighting the fact that we are part of a global community, I would draw the attention of honourable senators to an article appearing on page 10 of today's Australian Financial Review and especially the comments of Mr Ignaz Kiechle, the German farm Minister, who is opposed to any cuts to the current European Community subsidies on farm produce. I think that article is well worth reading because those people are just looking after themselves and do not want 70 per cent cuts. It is important to be aware of what they are doing.

At present and for several years the Northern Hemisphere has had excellent grain harvests. As a result, the countries of the Northern Hemisphere do not require imports from us. A trade war is going on between the European Community and the United States of America. There are economic events in China, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and eastern Europe over which we have no control.

It is quite erroneous for the Opposition to suggest that the current difficulties of farm industries in rural areas are caused by decisions of this Government. If we were to take the easy way out and make short term responses which are politically attractive, we would simply be sowing the seeds for worse problems down the track. If people want to look at taking the easy way out by the provision of a subsidy, I draw their attention to the assistance that was given by the conservative government in 1970-71. Of course, that assistance went to those who had larger incomes.

In 1970 it was suggested also that we must not upset the consumers of wool, that we must not upset the markets and that we must not demand a floor price. People would not want to abolish the floor price now. We certainly have come to accept the floor price and appreciate that it is of great value to us in terms of allowing people to plan. So, any easy solutions have very long term ramifications. We are not about having easy solutions that are going to cause harm and problems to people later on down the track.

The two major areas of primary produce that are having problems are wheat and wool. The outlook for wool is obviously very difficult. Like so many others, it is an industry that is very exposed to the fluctuations of international demand and overseas events. In 1989-90 sales fell to 543 million kilograms-down from 860 million kilograms in the previous year. In 1988-89 the USSR bought 18 per cent of our total sales. Last year it bought only 9 per cent and this year the amount is likely to be lower still.

China and eastern Europe have also largely withdrawn from the market because of their internal economic problems and the lack of foreign exchange. In effect, the USSR, China and eastern Europe, which between them make up over half of the volume of sales, have effectively withdrawn from the market. Supply, meanwhile, is still at record levels. The estimated wool stockpile at the end of 1990-91 will be around 3.1 million bales.

No-one today from the Opposition has addressed that problem-the problem of what are we going to do with those issues. If the Opposition is going to be an alternative government, it has to have policies and ideas as to what it would do that is different. Today we have heard nothing.

As honourable senators know, the Government has been working closely with the Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia. The latest measures, which were announced earlier this week, will maintain growers equity in the stockpile and will, hopefully, make growers think harder about alternatives to wool production. The plea for growers to think harder about alternatives to production and where their industry is going is not new. It is a plea that has been going on, as I say, since the 1969-70 crisis.

It is very important that all producers have input. I have had criticism from farmers who feel that some of the leaders of their industry do not fully represent them. The average farmer does not have the time to spend in a lot of these farming political organisations. As a result, they feel somewhat under-represented.

A number of woolgrowers, I have to say, supported the move to reduce the floor price of wool from 870c to 700c. They had opposed the rise to 870c prior to that because they felt that that was going to encourage farmers who had not traditionally been woolgrowers to hop in and get a quick quid. They were critical of that problem.

I can tell the Senate of an incident involving a farmer who was fairly aggressive about the dropping of the wool price. When he was asked what size holding he had, it was revealed that he had less than 200 sheep. This man, who was critical of the reduction in the floor price of wool, was also a producer of dorsets, which are not noted for fine wool production. They are certainly part of the fat lamb industry, not wool.

Measures will continue to be taken to raise the demand, particularly in the USSR and Chinese markets. As part of this, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will be leading a delegation to these countries in November. That is a very constructive way in which to approach this problem-it is not a critical and carping approach.

The Government is being subjected to something of a campaign by disgruntled woolgrowers, some of whom are still hung up on the political opportunity offered by the situation. As the industry leaders and the Minister have done on so many occasions, I call on all woolgrowers to work and think constructively about the future of their industry and to give up their pursuit of senseless and bitter political recrimination. Recrimination does not help anybody.

The second commodity that we are worried about is wheat. The problems here are, again, largely outside Australia, although I would have to say that a fair section of New South Wales was under water for a significant time during the sowing season and many wheat growers were not even able to get their crops in.

There have been a run of good seasons in the Northern Hemisphere. The trade war between the European Community and the Americans has hotted up. We know that the Americans use the export enhancement program in order to maintain their market share as they see it. Let me tell honourable senators that from discussions with agricultural leaders and bureaucrats that we had in 1986 in Kansas, we know that they see their market share as almost their God given right, that they will do anything to protect that market share and that it does not matter who gets trampled in the interim.

It is true that Australian growers next year may not find their second payment very good. That payment may not cover all of their costs and that is a problem. Again, we have the ironic and frustrating situation where we have good yields in Australia but we are still talking about an industry downturn because of external factors.

We have heard today use of the term `rural crisis'. A couple of weeks ago I was in Moree, which is noted for its cotton industry. No-one there whom I spoke to-and these people were actively involved in the cotton industry-was prepared to say that there was a crisis in that industry. In fact, they were most keen to make sure that I did not use the word `crisis' in relation to that industry. They were looking at future options for their industry; they were wanting to progress. It is important that we do not just use the term `rural crisis' to mean the whole of the rural industries. We know that the wool and wheat industries face major problems, and I have outlined why. But let us not fall into the trap of labelling the whole of the industry as being in crisis. That is a very important point.

I would refer to the meeting of the Caucus committee yesterday about which Senator Boswell made some rude comments. We had some very constructive discussions with the National Farmers Federation. It stressed that in its view, as in the Government's view, the long term and medium outlook for Australian farmers remains bright. I thought that its attitude was responsible and profitable in the current situation and it was very welcome to those of us on the committee.

In the short time left to me in this debate I wish to move on to the things that we are doing to protect rural communities, and that is very important. What would the Opposition do? We know that it would cut our budgetary spending. Opposition senators would cut spending, but they will not tell us where from. Maybe they would like to tell me how much they would cut from the rehabilitation services. Maybe they would like to do away with the 10 new locations for rehabilitation services. Maybe they would like to abolish the rural and remote respite care scheme. Maybe they would cut funding to the Royal Flying Doctor Service. Maybe they would cut all the initiatives in rural women's health. Maybe they would do away with family planning services and the geriatric assessment program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—What would honourable senators opposite do? There is no point in their coming in here and being critical. The Government has established a rural and regional area health unit in Darwin, which will investigate the problems of delivering community service and health programs to sparsely populated and isolated regions. What are the Opposition's alternatives? What would Opposition senators do about it? They would just abolish these things because they would make massive cuts. We have seen what is on the agenda for the debates those opposite will be having at their Federal conference, which is to take place shortly, and we know that that is the way they will be moving.

—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. Before I call Senator Panizza, I should point out to the chamber, for those who have not noticed, that, although Senator West's speech was by no means her first speech in the Senate, it was her first speech since she returned after a short break.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator West leaves the chamber--
—Tell us where you will cut.

—Do not worry about that; we will get to it. The Minister should just sit down and wait. As I was saying, before Senator West leaves the chamber I want to remind her of three things. I would be jumping for joy if the wool stockpile at the end of this financial year was 3.1 million bales, because we could handle that and improve the price. I say for the information of Senator West that the stockpile will be around six million bales at the end of the year. I wish to remind Senator West that no-one on this side of the chamber in this debate this afternoon asked for any subsidy. I remind her also that she should look beyond Moree and the cotton area.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic policy of this Government has finally and drastically come to fruition in regard to rural Australia. The result, whether intended or not, is almost the total collapse of those areas-and the wider community is not far behind. The situation cannot be compared with the downturn of 1982-83 because the problem then was caused by a massive drought and nothing else. That drought encompassed all of eastern Australia. Unfortunately, it also came to Western Australia the following year. But with a drought there is always hope of recovery; one does not often experience two in a row. But there is not much hope of getting out of the present situation under this Government. Here we have the worst disaster in rural areas, if not for Australia as a whole. However, I am addressing only the rural crisis today. It is early days yet, because this is only the tip of the iceberg, but I am sure that it will rival or surpass the situation in the Depression of the 1930s.

Let me point out to honourable senators how drastic things were in the 1930s. I will pick up the history of my own district, the Yilgarn, from a book edited by Lyall Hunt. Let me quote from the book regarding a scene in the 1930s:

The reality of the Great Depression hit the Yilgarn early in 1931 when farmers saw that, despite the bumper crop, they faced ruin because of the collapse in wheat prices. The farmer who had planted the local average of 113 hectares . . . grossed only $1,026 for his crop. He owed $250 of that to the bank as interest. For many this was the last straw. They had been in deep recession since the crop failures of 1929 and could not expect further bank loans. Some despaired. Charles Greenall of South Moorine Rock, had expressed anger at the financial crisis, telling his 12 year old son, `The best thing we can do Peter, is to shoot ourselves'. Their bodies were found on their farm on 28 December 1930.
We have not gone very far down the track, as one can see if one picks up the Perth Sunday Times of last week. An article under the heading `Tragic Sign of the Times' reads as follows:
A roughly-fashioned sign on a gate outside a Riverina farmhouse helps to explain why a struggling young farmer shot his wife and two children and then himself this week.

There was a message with a cry for help on his front gate. If any honourable senator wishes to see the article, I will show it to him or her later. The message read, `Will Bob Hawke shed a tear for primary producers?'. Then he went on to mention a Mr `Paul Cheating', representing someone else, I suppose. His final message was, `God help Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a despicable reference.
—It is not despicable, and Senator Cook knows it. Let me refer to a comment made by the detective who attended the site.
—This is totally despicable.
—It is not. Detective Constable Danny Sharkey said:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm no economist-I'm just a dopey copper-but it just doesn't seem fair that blokes like this can work their guts out without making a living wage . . .'.

It is not a despicable reference; this is what is going on in Australia today. This is all happening with not a single drought since this Government has been in office. If we had the drought of 1982-83, I would excuse it, but it has all happened without that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania? What about Queensland? Where have you been?

—I know where I have been. I doubt whether Senator West knows where she has been. In fact, in 1982-83 the Government did claim that it broke the drought when it came to office. I would like to know what the present position would be if we had a drought on top of it. If there was a drought, I would be prepared to accept such a situation. There is no-one in this chamber who knows more than I what it is like to experience a drought. Farmers are efficient and work hard and long hours.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh earlier said in an exchange with Senator Patterson that he was a farm owner and not a wage slave. Well, I would like to ask Senator Walsh where he has been in the last 10 years or so. Farmers work twice or three times as long as any employee.

When I am on the farm I work three times longer than anyone I employ, and at the end of the year he probably finishes up with just as much. What is more, farmers cannot afford to employ any more workers. This Government's economic policy of high interest rates and unwillingness to reform, at a rate acceptable to keep Australia up with our trading partners, has been the main cause of the plight of rural Australia today. Rural production is down by at least 67 per cent over the last two years. The record interest rates charged to primary industry are nothing short of irresponsibility.

Many farmers are still paying between 20 and 25 per cent for borrowings when banks seem to be paying a limit of 13.5 per cent. I know that. But where has that great instrument of Australian banking been in this fiasco? Senator Button put things right yesterday in respect of the manufacturing industry when he broke ranks with the rest of Cabinet and told us in no uncertain terms that interest rates are causing most of these problems.

The latest from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in trying to convince us that he is on track is blaming the banks for not passing on lower interest rates. I blame the banks also, but it is not the banks totally, even though they are at fault in places. I will give a couple of quotes from an article in the Australian Financial Review as follows:

While Westpac, the State Bank of New South Wales, and the ANZ-all with crippling bad corporate debt portfolios-are regarded as being the most harsh by the farm sector, even the National Australia Bank, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank are in the same category.

It goes on to say that one bank manager is charging $70 for each appointment with his clients. I thought that clients could regard bank managers as public servants rather than having to pay to go and see them. Another example:
There are claims that NAB is now charging up to 10.5 per cent on penalty margins which start as soon as payments have been missed.

Banks are at fault, but they are not totally at fault, because the Government has put them in the position of acting as they are. If Mr Keating is right that it is the banks' fault, why has he not used the instrument of the Commonwealth Bank to lead the way? But the Commonwealth Bank is doing nothing about it.

The high interest rates used by this Government to dampen imports and keep down inflation have totally backfired. All they have done is create a demand for Australian currency and lift the Australian dollar far beyond its value; far beyond the value that it deserves based on the productivity that Australia has-and we have already been told by others what sort of productivity Australia has. That is the single biggest killer of our competitiveness with our overseas trading partners. We cannot compete in wheat, we cannot compete in wool, and we see no improvement. Never before has there been an occasion when, unfortunately, all these industries have been down together. This situation does prove that it is caused by the Government's monetary policy, otherwise some industries would be up and some industries would be down, as all industries have had turns over their time. Wheat prices are at their lowest since 1947 with the inception of the Australian Wheat Board (AWB). The chart that I have here shows that the present price of $160 to $140 a tonne is certainly the lowest since 1947. In real terms we would have had a price of $1,000 a tonne in 1947. I know that the world demand is down, but there are ways in which this Government could help. The agricultural industries have put up with these things, but the Government does nothing about it. Because of the exchange rate, the Gulf crisis and escalation of the United States-European Community trade war, the first payment for wheat has been downgraded by 40 per cent this year. The wool situation is just as bad and falling, and we accept that the Australian Wool Corporation has a lot to answer for. I am the biggest critic in this place of the Wool Corporation for certain things that it has done, but the Government has been party to a lot of things that have occurred.

As I have said before, I know that there are problems with those industries, but if the Government situation was not what it is now, they would have a chance. A reduction in interest rates of 3 per cent and a corresponding fall of the dollar to US75c would reduce payments by $4,500 on an average wheat farm with a debt of $150,000. It would increase the value of Australia's 16 million tonne wheat crop by $260m and increase the value of coarse grains by $106m. This equates to $10,000 per grain farmer. The cost imposed on grain growers of providing assistance to inefficient industries stands at $8,000 per farmer. With the Government being more determined on this reform, we would wipe that figure out.

The Gulf crisis has added 5c to the dollar, and the Government has been very happy, amongst all things with the Gulf crisis, to keep receiving the windfall gains that it is getting out of the increased prices for oil. Senator Cook, in answer to a question yesterday, failed to mention the increased levies that the Government has been picking up on the increased oil prices. He dodged round and round, but he never mentioned that the Government is making a windfall profit from oil because it set its Budget on $23 a barrel and the price is now at $35 to $37 a barrel. If he is dinkum, just as in 1986 when the Government put the levies up to make up for the downfall in the oil, it could have done the same and kept the oil levies coming in so that they would reflect the forecast Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—We will discuss that one later on if it is not true, but Senator Cook dodged the issue. As my time is running out I must mention, as was pointed out by Senator West, that it is the wider community that is copping it as well. There are the machinery dealers who have got to put men off; there is the fellow who works on a farm and is put off. There are all these country people who are going to be affected, and worst of all, there are the children who will be affected as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Of rural students, only a third ever get to university. We are going to have a problem now. I know that there is a limit on assets that one can possess before the tertiary allowance is taken off, and Senator Walsh believes that one should sell the farm; but a farmer cannot do that in the next 12 months if he is not in a viable position. If children lose one year's study, it affects the rest of their lives. Therefore, measures have to be taken by the Government so that those children will not be affected. As Senator Walsh told us, 30 per cent of farmers are in a pretty good position and making money from high interest rates-but 70 per cent are in debt. Of course, with those high interest rates, the income is wiped up by the inflation that they cause.

All in all, the Government-as shown by the comments I have got from the other side of the chamber today-knows, but does not want to admit, that its policies have caused the rural industries and allied wider communities in those areas to decline in no uncertain terms. It is time that it realised its position and put some actions in place that will turn this rural crisis around-and it is nothing but a rural crisis-so that that sector of Australia can take its rightful place in the community, as it has always done, for the welfare and betterment of all Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We welcome this debate today. We appreciate the opportunity to contribute to the matter of public importance. The health and well-being of rural Australia contributes not only to the general economic health of Australia but also to achieving a buoyant regional economy. We heard precious little from honourable senators opposite on how they would help to overcome the problems we face in the rural sector today. Before I go on, I want to make some brief reference to some comments-a stretch of the facts-made by some Opposition senators in their speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, in the usual Opposition manner of continuing to attack, and advocate the reduction of, the wages and conditions of workers in this country, Senator Archer referred to a list of alleged benefits. In that list he referred to workers receiving 14 or 15 public holidays. That is simply not correct. The national standard for public holidays in this country is 10 days. He then went on to refer to the cost of paternity and maternity leave. Again, in the private sector paternity and maternity leave is not a cost charged against the employer.

Senator Archer wandered into the forests at one stage when he referred to the alleged lack of attention that the Labor Government has been giving to forest industry strategy. He only needs to look at what is occurring in our home State of Tasmania, where a very far-sighted and constructive forest industry strategy has been adopted by the State Labor Government. It will be interesting to see the position the State Liberals take on that particular policy.

However, I commend Senator Archer in one respect. He referred to the potato industry, and I share his concern with the problems faced by that industry. I have already had some discussions with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) on this matter and I will also be having some discussions with the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Dr Blewett).

The major contribution to the debate of Senator Spindler on behalf of the Democrats was a comment that he favoured selective tariffs. However, the list that he gave broadened his advocacy of selective tariffs into one of general tariffs to protect all rural industries.

Senator Boswell, again, was not too accurate with his facts. He referred to the alleged 25 per cent increase in wage costs facing the rural sector in this country. That is factually not correct. Senator Boswell referred to that being made up of a superannuation contribution of 6 per cent. That is not correct; it is 3 per cent. There may be a further 3 per cent superannuation increase in coming years; but it certainly has not occurred yet. Senator Boswell also referred to the cost of the minimum training levy of 1 1/2 per cent. Again, if Senator Boswell knew much about that proposal, he would know that most farmers will not be affected by the minimum training guarantee. It is not 1 1/2 per cent yet; it is one per cent and it has not yet been implemented in terms of its cost.

The only other comment I would make about Senator Boswell's contribution is that he referred to the ups and downs and the cyclical nature of the rural industry. That is true. I am afraid that Senator Boswell's contribution to this debate, in some contrast to other contributions of Opposition senators, was a real downer. It is no wonder that the representation of the National Party of Australia in the Senate has declined to almost nothing. Senator Boswell's contribution on this issue today is indicative of that.

Drought was one of the major problems that the rural industries faced in 1982-83. Another was the collapse in terms of trade in 1985-86. To those Australians living in major urban centres, the effects were indirect. Despite the indirect nature of those effects, they were nevertheless real and substantial. The effects were real because the income earned by our primary industries allowed us to continue to trade without chalking up increased foreign debt. The effects are substantial because they multiply through the regional economy and then through the general economy. Of course, I am never encouraged by a rural downturn such as that which now appears to be on the horizon. Having said that, all honourable senators know that our rural industries will always be subject to cycles.

When the wool industry was last in a deep depression, in 1970-71, other agricultural sectors were doing fairly well. When the fortunes of the beef industry collapsed in 1974, wool had very substantially recovered. We have been fortunate that it has normally been the case that, as one particular commodity experiences bad times, others prosper. Even when large areas of Australia were drought affected in 1982, some parts of the country held up well.

It is true that the effects of changes in international markets will act to substantially reduce returns to Australian producers during 1990-91. This cannot be emphasised strongly enough. That is the major problem facing rural industries in this country today. A characteristic of Australian agriculture is that the Australian farmer and the Australian Government have little or no control over world prices. Variability in price inevitably results in variability in returns to growers. Estimates for farm cash operating surpluses for 1990-91 show that price and wool tax effects will drive cash operating surpluses to lower levels than those which have been considered normal over the past few years. For example, in 1991-92 specialist wheat growers' cash operating surplus is estimated to decline by 35 per cent. For specialist woolgrowers the decline is expected to be 47 per cent, and for mixed livestock and crop producers the decline will be about 49 per cent.

It is important to recognise that the relative contribution of the decline in net wool receipts essentially drives the total picture. The average figures for a decline in cash operating surplus are distorted by the extraordinary developments in the wool industry. To a lesser extent, changes in the world grains market affect the aggregate outlook for cash operating surplus. Estimates available to the Government indicate that diminishing returns in wool make up 58 per cent in the decline of cash operating surplus. Diminishing returns from cereals contribute another 36 per cent.

Honourable senators who are fair-minded and objective in their consideration of these issues will understand that variability of returns is something that most Australian producers accept as given in their industry. It is the genius of Australian producers that they continue to make strong efficiency gains and continue to do things better in their operations. They know that their own efforts form the basis for their continued prosperity.

Let me catalogue the changes in world markets which will act to reduce returns to Australian growers and over which we have little or no control. We have seen a dramatic decline in world wheat prices resulting from two major factors. The first is that the wheat harvest in the northern hemisphere is at a record high; consequently, excess stocks are being released into what is a residual world grain market. This means that the price not only of wheat but also of other cereal grains will be driven down. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, will know that the US dollar price for wheat will decline by an estimated 27 per cent. Irrespective of changes in the level of the dollar, this decline will set the parameters of price falls in the world's grain markets.

The second major factor at play is the activities of the United States and the European Community. Clearly, corrupt trading practices put additional down pressure on prices. The costs to Australia of export subsidies and agricultural protection have long been recognised. The Government's efforts to wind back these practices and gain a meaningful solution in this round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) negotiations have been consistent and extensive.

I do not pretend that wins in the current GATT round will eliminate variability in world grain markets. I do not pretend that the long term solution offers the answer to short term problems which currently face Australia's producers. However, it is not possible to pretend that Australia exists as a discrete entity removed from the world trading system. In fact, it would be a curious flight of fancy to advocate such a proposition. Australia's lifeblood is trade in our natural resource based industries. We critically depend on open and unrestricted access to international markets if we are to achieve our legitimate goals of social justice.

Those whose analysis is not a product of their own imagination will understand this elemental fact. They will therefore recognise that the palliatives of rhetoric offer little when dealing with complex problems. The solutions lie in facilitating adjustment, in ensuring support to individuals, and in developing the industry structure which is best placed to handle the complex requirements of the 1990s. The solution also lies in forcing the pace of change in industries associated with our efficient rural producers. In other words, the solution lies in the measures which the Government now has under way and which the Opposition cannot offer.

The current difficulties of Australia's premier agricultural industry-the wool industry-are well known and well documented. Those who have an interest in history will understand that the current situation is a function of industry decisions made some three years ago. Of course, the response of the Government has been central to the maintenance of stability within the market and the viability of the Australian Wool Corporation and the industry itself. I have little problem with accepting that the extraordinary measures initiated by the Wool Corporation and the Government will mean that times will be very tight. However, I have no difficulty in defending the decisions taken as being appropriate, timely and proper, given the circumstances which now prevail in that industry.

Those who care to criticise the Government for difficulties-such as those stated by Senator Panizza-now being experienced by Australian producers might also care to explain the fundamental link which exists between world prices and the returns to Australian producers. It is a fact, and not just a matter of idle National Party or Country Party chatter, that the decline in farm cash operating surplus resulting from the application of a tight monetary policy is insignificant when compared to the total decline induced by world prices. A permanent element in the farm equation is that industries subject to economic pressure will not always survive but will always come through in a stronger, leaner and more competitive shape than they were in at the start of the pressure.

Industries survive but, sadly, not all individuals in those industries do, and our Government has very great sympathy and is attempting in a positive manner to ensure that those individuals are protected as much as possible. This will be the same on this occasion, but I am confident that all honourable senators must also be aware that our farm industries will gain long term strength from short term adversity. I have been encouraged to observe in the present debate on the downturn that there is a much broader appreciation in the media about the causes of economic difficulties for our agricultural industries and, consequently, about the breadth of necessary policy adjustments. It is no longer a question of attributing blame to narrow commodity policies nor, thankfully, of agricultural lobby groups mindlessly pursuing protection of various sorts for their own industries.

There are four categories of policies affecting the economic well-being of farm and other rural industries which the Government has addressed and the Opposition has failed to address. The first category is to determine the general macro-economic setting; exchange rates, interest rates, inflation and wage policy above the others. The second is the provision of physical and social infrastructure of the industries and the communities in rural areas. The third is commodity policy. The fourth is the existence of a welfare net for those who, for whatever reason, fall upon hard times. Previous speakers for the Government have dealt with a number of those areas.

It is important when looking at macro-economic policy settings, and appropriate, to remind honourable senators that the overriding objective of macro-economic policy is to reduce the current account deficit to a level which stabilises Australia's net foreign debt. In pursuing this objective, the Government has employed a comprehensive range of policies aimed at slowing demand growth to sustainable levels and improving the productive capacity of the economy. The Government called on all arms of policy to slow the excessive growth in demand evident in 1988 and 1989. Fiscal policy remains tight. Wages policy has been tight, as is reflected in the continuing decline in real labour costs, unlike the continued assertions from the Opposition that there has been some sort of wages and cost boom. Monetary policy was tightened substantially in 1988 and 1989. In response to these policies, demand has slowed as expected, and the current account has improved from a deficit of over $20 billion last financial year to an annualised deficit of $17 billion.

The Opposition contends that we should ease monetary policy in response to the downturn in the economy. It talks of recession and crisis. It does not do itself or Australia any service with such talk. We are not in the business of talking down the economy and talking up a crisis mentality. The point is that the slowdown in demand in the economy, and the consequent improvement in the balance of payments, reflect a set of macro policies which are on track. Official interest rates have fallen by four percentage points since the beginning of the year. The impact of this fall in rates will still be feeding into economic activity in 18 months' time. The Opposition, in calling for further falls in interest rates, illustrates its complete ignorance of those lags.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council was held in Adelaide in July 1990. I have looked through the report. I have been particularly interested in people in rural Australia. One section that I noted particularly was the drought policy review. I spoke about drought when a report came in earlier this year. One comment here is that the Council noted that the report I mentioned treats drought as 'a natural recurring condition, which in most cases is a normal risk that should be included in the management of Australian rural enterprises'. That might sound good in theory, but I do not believe that it is good in practice. If honourable senators lived, as I do, in the country, they would be very conscious of the fact that droughts are the effect of nature; that God does not send the rain at the right time. It is very difficult to include that-as is said in the report-as part of the management of Australian rural enterprises. The Government ought to take cognisance of that.

Most certainly, one of the bad things that the Government did was to do away with the income equalisation deposits scheme, under which, in good times, we were able to put money away so that we had reserves to fall back on in times of drought. I lived in a city until I married and went to live at Kingaroy. Rain was just a bit of a nuisance value in the city. But my word, if people go to live in the country, they realise how important it is. We have just been quite thrilled at home because we have had an inch of rain in the last couple of days. For nine whole weeks it had not rained. If people are trying to grow wheat crops, one good way to ensure that there is not a huge amount of wheat to be sold is if they cannot get rain to help their crop to grow. That was one matter that I was interested in.

But I noticed that in this report not one mention is made of the rural crisis-something that is really very important. We have just had a debate on a matter of public importance concerning the rural crisis and the fact that the Government does not realise the dependence of Australia on rural exports. One reads all the headlines about the wheat industry facing a crisis of confidence, about angry farmers planning to have a big rally in Brisbane, and about the worsening farm crisis. There is certainly a crisis in the rural industry. But one also reads about Mr Brian Courtice, the honourable member for Hinkler, saying that there is not a rural crisis; and one reads about Mr Hull, the honourable member for Kennedy, saying that perhaps a little more could be done. Sadly, he took the late Bob Katter's place. I believe that the rural area in Kennedy will suffer very much indeed because Mr Hull is not aware of the problems of the wool industry.

There are just so many problems in rural Australia. The record current account deficits and the continuing very high interest rates are doing irreparable damage. Small businesses are collapsing. There is crisis everywhere. Then I read in our Courier-Mail just the other day that suicides were feared because of the looming rural crisis. The Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, has warned that farming finances will hit rock bottom in January and February.
