I believe that many farmers' incomes have already hit rock bottom. So the Australian Agricultural Council really should have said something about the serious crisis in the rural industries.

It went on to talk about a review of grain marketing, and I think we all realise that there has been overproduction of wheat in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the United States of America and China. These are some of the problems--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The report of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is quite enlightening in a number of respects. One item in particular which caught my eye and which has particular relevance in view of the fact that Senator Cook is in the chamber is the statement that the superannuation industry now has assets approaching $130 billion and that superannuation coverage is estimated to be approaching 70 per cent of the work force.

I do not know where the Commission gets that figure or whether it would care to elaborate on it, but my understanding is that the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics statistics indicate that barely 40 per cent of the private sector work force has actual superannuation coverage, although some 90 per cent of the public sector has. If we take the weighted average, we end up with a little over 50 per cent. That, of course, is the reason why most of the major players in the game, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), have been prepared to concede that there is indeed a crisis in occupational superannuation, sufficient to justify the need for a national conference.

The thing that struck me as extraordinary last week was that a prominent story in the Australian Financial Review said that the Government had agreed to convene a conference, that the agenda and timing had not been agreed upon, but that we would have that in due course. The ACTU expressed a deal of sympathy for this and, rather than simply bashing the employers over the head, said that as long as it was not a stalling tactic it was prepared to go along with it. Lo and behold, we heard nothing from the Government until about three days later when this tiny letter from Senator Cook appeared in the Australian Financial Review saying that it was all a bit premature, that his spokesman had been misunderstood and that the Government had not made up its mind.
I find it odd in the extreme, even if Senator Cook happened to have been away for a couple of days, that we had to wait virtually three days before we got this sort of response.

TALK.START.PARA: —We faxed the letter the same day. I cannot take account of editorial policy in the placement of letters to the editor.
—Why did you not get your letter in the following day?.
—We faxed it the same day as the report appeared.
—Did you put out a press release?
—Senator Alston, you should address the chair. This is not a time for conversation, but for speaking to reports.

—The fact remains that Senator Cook was remarkably silent on the issue and has therefore left a great deal of concern in the community as to where the Government stands on the issue. Why does he not bite the bullet? It seems to me that a national conference, structured along the right lines, which concedes the crisis that there is at the present time, could be a very useful contribution. But again, the Government seems to be vacillating on it and is not prepared to do anything until the major players have come up with a deal and presented it to it as a fait accompli.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not exactly leadership, and I would have thought there was a very important role to be played out there. Instead, the Government seems to be more interested in other games, including the meeting on funder's funds, which I read about in the press the other day-in fact, I read about it in two newspapers, so someone comprehensively leaked the fact that the meeting was to occur. It turned out to have been a complete non-event. On my information, Mr Keating was bored, Senator Button was disorganised, and Mr Howe did not bother to turn up. So the end result is that nothing in particular was decided upon.

Senator Button's claim that something like $514m has been invested in the venture capital industry is not accepted by the insurance industry. As I understand it, it regards the figure as probably being double that, especially if it includes research and development. I think the sooner the Government clears the air on what it really has in mind the better, because it is making all these noises to appease the trade union movement about how this will lead to increased industrial muscle and how the industry ought to be a lot more imaginative, to quote the words of Mr Keating to the Life Insurance Federation of Australia in November last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say anything about industrial muscle.

—Mr Keating did, and he has certainly not resiled from that. He said that by the turn of the century, when superannuation funds had assets of $600m-unions would be in a very powerful position indeed and would be able to exercise both commercial and industrial muscle.
—You have to invest for the best rate of commercial return.

—Indeed, so they ought to be allowed to do that, and yet what we have at the present time is still this hidden agenda which is being encouraged by the Government and which is, I think, causing a great deal of unnecessary concern in the community about imagination being required to invest in socially desirable projects. It is about time the Government concentrated on letting the commercial industry operate effectively and gave it a better playing field than the minefield of complexities and over detail that it seems to be burdened with at the present time. Legislation by press release is operating better than it ever did, despite the fact that on 29 June last Mr Keating completely reversed his decision of 12 months earlier.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the people who have a knowledge of the superannuation industry, on reading this document before the Senate today, would be perturbed that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission has not got on top of what is required. We acknowledge that there have been many changes but there must be some lingering concerns in the industry about what is happening in view of the drop in market prices, the practices by certain people within the industry, the lack of adherence to the standards, and the attitude that this Commission is taking.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the report states that an important function of the Commission is to provide advice to the Government on the proposed changes to legislation-we certainly have had a plethora of changes- and to provide adequate prudential safeguards which will lead to continued stability and community confidence in the insurance and superannuation industries. These are the aspects that I believe should have been embodied in that report. Have they concerns? What are they doing? Tell the public. It is this lack of information that is of some concern because I do not think the whole truth is in this document.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you alleging?

—It is this Government's policy to encourage as many taxpayers as possible to be saving for their retirement. This is the whole aim of the current superannuation policies. People's superannuation must be protected, it must be safeguarded. There must not only be prudential standards, but there must also be an adequate body that has the guts to enforce those standards, and this is where I believe it is falling down.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the growth in the superannuation industry that perhaps has become the bright spot of an otherwise sluggish investment market in 1990-91, but future superannuation benefits depend on the returns gained by investments made on the stock market, in property and in other sorts of enterprises, by both insurance and superannuation companies. Any person can tell, for example, that the stock market is not exactly in a buoyant position at the present time; nor indeed is the property market. For example, to take just one paper this morning, the Australian Financial Review said:
The Australian Stock Market struggled to hang on to a modest gain yesterday, with another bout of short-covering providing the only boost to flagging trade.

It was further stated that the institutional investors generally believe that the market is in a downward trend. Indeed, these are worrying comments for those who have money invested in superannuation companies. Their protection, I suppose, is through a spread of investments, but if the whole market is depressed the whole economy is going down. There must be some concern about the insurance industry's ability to be able, in times of retirement, to provide income to match the future promised benefit outlined in some of those schemes.

Over the last couple of weeks, the prices of shares in many of Australia's top companies have been steadily dropping. Every now and then we have a little boost described in glowing terms as euphoria, but this is often very short-lived. One has only to read the share market action pages in Australian newspapers to understand the seriousness of the situation. We are feeling the effects of a recession not only in the rural economy but right across the board. This, I put to honourable senators, is also affecting the future of our ageing and aged population.

I also note that the report under consideration states that the current economic climate is likely to impact on the results of the insurance and superannuation industries in 1990-91. I would have hoped for some elaboration on that. I am glad that the industry acknowledges the facts that are glaring at us in the newspapers today, but it should have added to what was said and given us a little more information.

I am concerned at the possibility of many future superannuants believing that they will receive a certain amount of money, which will now need to be revised as a result of our present share trading practices and because of the drop in property prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Watson, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Senator McKiernan:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak again on the report from the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Migration Regulations, entitled Illegal Entrants in Australia-Balancing Control and Compassion which deals with the matter of illegals in Australia. I do so noting that today is 10 October and that a special concession available to illegals in Australia at the moment who wish to apply to regularise their status expires on 31 October, which is only 21 days, or three weeks, from now.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this final opportunity to urge some of those people, if they happen to be listening to this broadcast, to take advantage of that concession. Although the majority report from the Committee contains some recommendations that some other means be introduced by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) to allow them to avail themselves of opportunities to regularise their status, a reply from the Government has not yet been forthcoming and time is running out for those people. I take this opportunity to urge them to seek to regularise their status. If they feel that they will not be able to gain the benefit of permanent residency by an application to regularise their status, the only course of action open to them is to remove themselves from Australia. I urge them to take either of those courses of action.

I do so for the reason that, from 1 November onwards, illegals, when they are apprehended, subject of course to the Minister's and the Government's response to the recommendations by the majority of the Committee, will be subject to mandatory deportation from this country-harsh action, but action of which notice has been given for well in excess of two years.

I have advised those illegals who have contacted my electorate office and sought advice on matters such as this to remove themselves, because if they are apprehended from 1 November this year and subjected to mandatory deportation, in some instances they will be leaving behind a home that they own that will have to go on the market in some sort of fire sale. Furniture and other possessions will have to be disposed of in Australia or arrangements will have to be made to remove them to the country which they are moving to. There are also the difficulties associated with children's education.

I make this final plea in the Parliament that people take advantage of this concession or, if they do not seek to take advantage of it, to voluntarily remove themselves from Australia. I doubt that all 90,000 illegals in Australia are listening to this broadcast, but I hope that people who know illegals will encourage them to take this action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I can understand Senator Watson's laughter at that particular remark. I would not impute any ulterior motives to his frivolity; I suspect that he is laughing at the thought that we might have 90,000 people listening to the broadcast, rather than at the very serious subject that I am addressing.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also reinforce my earlier remarks by recording in Hansard the fact that there has been an increase of 200 per cent in the resources available to the enforcement branch of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. There are now additional officers around the country checking up and following through on illegals. Their efforts-although not fully on stream-are paying dividends at the moment.

Two weeks ago in Perth the Department, in conjunction with the Australian Federal Police, mounted a raid on a market garden just north of Perth in a place called Guilderton and apprehended some 16 people of Polish nationality who were working there. The people were immediately arrested and detained until some of them were able to be released on bail or other provisions. This is an example of some of the resources-probably not enough-available to the Department. So the illegals who think they can continue to hide in this vast and beautiful country might have to think again after seeing evidence such as that in Perth.

One very disturbing aspect of that Perth raid was the fact that not only were the people concerned illegally in Australia but also they were compounding their illegal situation by working. Indeed, one of the people actually had a tax file number. That concerned me because he was, as it were, a non-citizen, not entitled to work in Australia. I noted a report in the West Australian newspaper of Thursday, 4 October which quoted a taxation officer from the Perth office-Mr Rod Todman, Director of Revenue Collection-as follows:
As far as we're concerned, we are only interested in people paying the right amount of tax, regardless of how they derive the income.

It does not surprise me that a person who is here on a visitor's visa, under which employment is prohibited, could be granted a tax file number. That is of some concern to me because people found to be illegally in Australia and therefore subject to a penalty attached found that further penalties applied because they were working. Penalties are also imposed on employers who knowingly employ illegals in Australia.

This is a matter that the Government needs to address. The Committee in its report-I stress that on this occasion it was a majority recommendation of all members of the Committee rather than of those who were present who endorsed the report-recommended that the Government should look more closely at what penalties could be imposed on employers who knowingly engage in rorts that seek to exploit illegals who may be in their employ. Evidence, some of it anecdotal, has been given to the Committee previously that such practices are in existence, although I do not in any way suggest that those practices are widespread. This is of particular concern at the moment when Australia is facing growing unemployment. Hopefully it will not grow too much more. We are eager to ensure that any job vacancies that may arise will be taken by Australians legally entitled to work rather than by illegals in the country who are, therefore, not entitled to work.

I conclude my remarks by yet again, hopefully, encouraging those people who are illegally in Australia to either avail themselves of the concession that is available to them prior to the thirty-first of this month or to voluntarily remove themselves from Australia. If they do not do that, they are making a very conscious choice and there will be very little point in making appeals to parliamentarians, such as myself, for some compassionate outlook on their cases at a later time.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
(Quorum formed)

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Senator Aulich:
That the Senate take note of the report.
upon which Senator Patterson had moved by way of amendment:

At end of motion, add ', support the recommendation of the Committee's report and deplores the attack by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on the Chairman of the Committee, witnesses who made submissions to the Committee and the role of Senate committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add my support to the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Patterson. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training who contributed to this report on priorities for reform in higher education, I wish to support the remarks of the Chairman of that Committee, Senator Aulich, and our other Committee members. I draw the Senate's attention to remarks made by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, who is reported by the Australian as dismissing the report as having `a very shallow basis' and being a `totally useless' contribution to the debate on higher education. Certainly with the passage of time the Dawkins view is becoming less and less credible, if it had any credibility at the commencement. I take this opportunity to state that I stand firmly behind the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Two years of work went into the report, including the consideration of 227 written submissions from higher education institutions, academic staff associations, students' unions, private sector organisations, individual academics, and State and Federal governments. In addition, 80 witnesses appeared at public hearings held by the Committee. I believe that the comment made by Mr Dawkins was an off the cuff, dismissive comment not worthy of a Minister for education.

In the light of the number of submissions and witnesses, I believe it was wrong of Mr Dawkins to dismiss the report as unrepresentative. Unfortunately, Mr Dawkins appears to share with his colleague Mr Keating a blind belief in their own infallibility-a dangerous trait in any individual, but particularly serious for people in influential positions such as Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating.

Submissions received by our Committee raised a wide range of issues. These included the relationship between higher education and the economy, funding policies for research, academic staffing policies, ways of improving access and equity, the place of higher education within the framework of continuing education, distance education, which is so important in Australia, links between higher education and technical and further education (TAFE), policies relating to overseas students, and management processes at both institutional and system levels. This was a very wide and a very comprehensive report, which I think was well received in academia, if not well received at the time by the Minister. With the passage of time, I think that even Mr Dawkins has had to eat his words.

The Committee did not feel obliged to make definite recommendations about all the matters discussed in the report; it was a discussion document. It saw its role, in part, as a catalyst for public discussion about the future of higher education in Australia. The Committee's report was timely after so many radical changes which have been forced on education institutions by this Government.

The purpose of the report was to broaden the scope of public debate on higher education matters. In broad terms, the report criticised the standard of education and the quality of teaching provided by universities. In fact, the Committee found that university education in many places was too narrow and too specialised.

The Committee also found that education was viewed as a greenhouse in which people fulfilled their learning obligations-usually in three to four years-and that there was very little continuing education or a sense of education as a lifelong process. Surely we have got to improve on that if Australia is, indeed, going to be the lucky country, the quality country and the informed country.

We found that the quality of teaching was, in some cases, quite appalling. Specific recommendations were made in relation to curriculum, communication skills, the quality of teaching, and continuing education. It is on this latter area-that is, continuing education-that I wish to make a few further comments. The Committee believed that it is becoming less and less realistic to assume that higher education can be provided, once and for all, at the end of schooling. The concept of lifelong education is beginning to take hold in Australia, and I commend certain professions for being ahead of the field.

The Government's White Paper on education acknowledged that continuing education is a fundamental part of the education and training system, and that the principle of lifelong education is now accepted as fundamental to achieving social, cultural, technical and structural change, and to our future economic development. However, the paper said little about the implications of this view and did not propose any specific arrangements to increase the higher education sector's involvement in continuing education.

Therefore, the impression was created that continuing education remains somewhat peripheral to the central purpose of higher education-an impression reinforced by the paper's policy position that, in general, continuing education programs should be self-funding. This attitude is not new. As a number of submissions pointed out, adult and continuing education has long been regarded as a marginal activity within the higher education system, not only at Commonwealth level but also within the institutions themselves. At the institutional level, continuing education departments have frequently been among the first to experience budget cuts at times of financial strain. As a submission from the Australian Association for Adult and Community Education rather pithily expressed, `Adult education has presented a soft target for cost cutting' because it `lacks the political clout in the forums where budget decisions have to be made'. I believe this is unfortunate.

Of all the sectors in the Australian education system, continuing education is the most decentralised. The activity crosses educational sectors, involving higher education and TAFE as well as a number of community organisations, and varies in structure from State to State. There is no central policy-making body. As submissions pointed out, it is difficult even to establish basic information on trends because there is no agency responsible for the regular collection of data.

The Committee recognised that undue centralisation of responsibility and control may well damage the flexibility which is a vital element of this form of education. Nevertheless, the growing importance of lifelong education-in both economic and social terms-suggests that something more than a policy of benign neglect is required to ensure that continuing education is able to rise to the challenges of the coming decades.

Therefore, the Committee recommended that the Commonwealth establish a permanent policy focus for adult and continuing education at the national level. This mechanism should be established within the structure of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and should report, in the first instance, to either the Chair of NBEET or the Chair of the Higher Education Council. It should assume a leadership role for continuing education and develop policies appropriate to the emerging education needs of Australian society. A priority for this body should be the development of a national strategy on continuing education. Such a strategy would identify broad objectives for the future development of continuing education, and establish policies to achieve those objectives.

I commend the recommendations regarding continuing education, and the other recommendations contained within that report, to the Senate, to the nation's higher education policy advisers, to administrators and to students.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on this motion and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Senator Michael Baume:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that the present Chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts is in the chamber. No doubt she will speak with some eloquence on this subject because she has taken a view about it, as have two other members of the Committee from the Government's side who are also in the chamber. In fact, they have judged that the reference ought to be discharged.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that, to me, that is a great pity. It is no secret that I thought there was yet considerable work to be done not only in respect of the matters that the Committee has thus far dealt with but also in terms of the process of education-not only amongst school children, not only amongst the wider community, not only amongst athletes and administrators, but also amongst parliamentarians, not least the appropriate Minister who is responsible for sport in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, I understand that you have already spoken twice on this report. Under Standing Orders you can speak now only by leave. If you wish, I can put the question that leave be granted for you to speak for the remaining eight minutes.
—Yes, please, with your indulgence.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Senator Crowley interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that judgments made in this chamber are on virtue and merit, not on favour or persuasion.
—We were simply saying that you would appreciate our generosity.
—That means you are going to know how reasonable we are.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do know how reasonable honourable senators opposite are. That is a judgment. I was commenting on the necessity for education of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly). I was somewhat distressed-as were, no doubt, many others in the community who have some awareness and understanding of this issue-to hear her say that in Australia we really had gone over the top in respect of the matter of drugs in sport. That was said but some months following the death of a young body builder who had taken anabolic steroids and subsequently died as a result of that indulgence. That is but the tip of the iceberg. There is a very clear need for education in the wider community of the inherent dangers in the use of drugs in sport, not to mention the moral and ethical issues.

SPEECH.PARA: This Committee, its report and findings are unique in Australia. With the exception of the Dubin report, commissioned by the Canadian Government as a result of Ben Johnson being cast into disgrace through taking anabolic steroids and cheating at the Seoul Olympic Games, there is no other inquiry of the depth and width of this one.

Of course, the report is not universally attractive-one could say that it is not universally respected. By and large, that is because it has had to focus upon and direct its attention towards the level of cheating amongst Australian sports men and women in this country, not only at the elite level but also at the very casual, weekend level.

We have had to focus upon the attitude of coaches and sporting officials as to whether they have been prepared to root out the abuse and use of drugs and the cheating allowed by virtue of their use, or whether they have tolerated them and turned a blind eye, being more concerned about the embarrassment that the athletes bring to the blazer brigade, the officials and that sport than they are concerned about the health of the athlete and the fact that he is obtaining an unfair advantage over other athletes.

We have had to look at what steps have been taken to root out this cheating. We have had to look at how the Government has applied itself to the vexing question. We have looked at what steps have been taken in respect of the lethal administration, the lethal availability, of many of these proscribed drugs. I have to say that too often we were not surprised but disappointed to find that coaches, athletes, officials, administrators and governments had fallen well short of their responsibilities.

Without going through that which the Committee did discuss, let me in the few minutes available to me touch on those matters which we did not. To that extent it is a great disappointment to me that this Committee at least will not deal with them. The Committee did not confront the question of the ethics, the ethos or the morality of the use of drugs in sport. We did not define a distinguishable parameter of the philosophy in the use of drugs. For instance, we found that the argument was entangled with health.

I asked the Australian Olympic Federation what its attitude would be if the wit of man allowed for the synthetic manufacture of a drug which enhanced performance but had no detrimental side effects. Would that be cheating? It certainly would not be a problem in respect of health. Then it would be argued that it was cheating because it created an unfair advantage. So then I asked: What would be the attitude to such a drug if it was widely available, as is orange juice, amino acids or other performance enhancing substances which are freely distributed and provided? There seemed to be no proper answer to that question because it had not been addressed. We just had this blind, and quite proper, notion that it appeared to be cheating, giving a differential advantage to one athlete against another and therefore we ought to outlaw it. But we had not addressed the questions of education or philosophy.

The International Olympic Committee has a range of substances, including beta-blockers. Outside beta-blockers we can have substances such as diazepam which is a brand name for valium. Valium has the effect that a beta-blocker has in a different way. But it has exactly the same effect in respect of its application by a pistol shooter or somebody in archery. To that extent it gives an unfair advantage, but it is not a banned substance. However, beta-blockers are. That demonstrates that there has not been a proper consideration of these questions.

We have not questioned the distinction between a beta-blocker and amino acids. Amino acids are provided at taxpayers' expense, or they have up until recently, at the Australian Institute of Sport for the purpose of cloning the effect that anabolic steroids would have, except that amino acids are not lethal to the body and are not a banned substance. Perhaps they do not give any advantage, but that is an argument that was had in relation to anabolic steroids as well. Those questions have not been addressed, and I suspect that they will not be. The question of a level playing field, which was one of the arguments put in respect of drugs, was not addressed either.

Frankly, there is no level playing field in elite sport in the world. Some athletes cannot even afford running shoes, yet others have top of the range shoes. It is the same with medical treatment, training facilities, coaches and all those things which enhance the ability and performance of various athletes. If one had time, which one has not, one could turn to the question of education in Australia. I am absolutely horrified at the lack of information available to students. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the eminent Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, Senator Cooney, I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 7 of 1990 dated 10 October 1990. There is no Scrutiny of Bills report this week.

DEBATE.TITLE: VISITS BY THE PRIME MINISTER TO NEW CALEDONIA, THE SOUTH PACIFIC FORUM, PAPUA NEW GUINEA AND JAPAN

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I spoke about tensions in the coalition around the development of the coalition's foreign policy, particularly differences between the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party. I also mentioned some of the Government's achievements in the area of foreign policy. It is appropriate at this time to place on record the Labor Government's active and consistent position on South Africa and the fact that the Government has not been in the game of making Thatcherite concessions in terms of sanctions. The maintenance of sanctions and the fact that they are working and have the support of black South Africans again is an indication of the differences that exist between this Government's policy and what would be the policy in the unlikely event of a Liberal government being elected.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of issues have been raised in Australian politics over recent years which I think leave a bad taste in our mouths. The first was the one Australia policy and the whole immigration debate that was sponsored by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. Previous speakers in this debate have spoken of the multifunction polis. I will refer in a minute to the fear campaign that occurred during the last Federal election campaign.

Dr Hewson's fundamental position in his response to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was that Australia's status in Asia has somehow been reduced by this Government's actions. That is absolute claptrap. In fact, the Japanese must be particularly confused about what their position is, because on 25 March 1988 in an address to an Australian Chamber of Commerce luncheon the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, said:

I do believe the time has come for Japan to look afresh at its role and responsibilities in the Western alliance. A unique opportunity exists for Japan to develop a broader political strategy that takes into account not only its own national self-interests but also the wider political interests of the Western alliance.

Of course, we can contrast that with Dr Hewson's recent statements that he did not support an extended international role for Japan. There is a great deal of inconsistency in what Dr Hewson is saying. On the one hand, he is saying that he does believe that Japan should be a member of the United Nations Security Council. But on the other hand-and I will quote from his response to the Prime Minister's statement-he said:
. . . we do not believe that Japan should be assuming an international military role, even in peace-keeping operations, in the near future.

So there is a tremendous amount of inconsistency in the Opposition's position. It seems to me that, before Dr Hewson continues to pontificate on these matters, he ought to get his and the Opposition's act into gear.

I suppose what has particularly offended me in recent times has been the scare campaign about the multifunction polis. I want to remind the Senate what occurred in the last Federal election campaign in the electorate of Lowe where, in an absolute desperation move and with a few days to go in the election campaign, the honourable member for Lowe, Dr Woods, put out a direct mail letter to his electors in which he said:
The Labor Government has approved in principle a Japanese proposal to build in Australia a City of the Future, a so called `Multi Function Polis'.
The favoured site for this huge project is Homebush Bay.
Far too little information is yet available to assess the merits and demerits for such a project for Australia as a whole.
One thing seems very clear: it would be wrong to site it at Homebush Bay.

The concept is a massive one-the building of an ultra modern, high technology city inhabited by between 100,000 and 200,000 people (about 80 per cent of them Japanese Citizens) and providing a major industrial, commercial and domestic complexes.
He goes on with a little more xenophobic and paranoid rubbish and concludes his direct mail letter thus:
In summary it seems that this idea in its current form has doubtful benefits to the economy and may well destroy the harmony of our existing community.
I am fighting this proposal on your behalf. I would value your support.
So I would say that there is no better example than that of the Opposition's attitudes to Japan-of having its foot on the accelerator at the same time as having its foot on the brake.
Dr Hewson, in his recent foray into international affairs, said that Australia should be following a policy which he either refers to, in his words, as `selfish' or as `enlightened self-interest'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that this morning.

—That is right. It is interesting that he sees both those as being the same thing. What does Dr Hewson mean by this? I believe, frankly, that his visit to China and his actions there indicate strongly that he means that we should follow, rather than a policy of `enlightened self-interest', a policy of `unenlightened hypocrisy'. That is, he pontificates about how Australia should resume full relations with China so that our trade relationship is not harmed.

SPEECH.PARA: But just to have two bob each way, he makes a couple of little gestures. For example, he refused to attend the opening ceremony of the Asian Games while he was there. Fortunately, I do not think that our Asian neighbours were holding their breath on this one. And then he wagged his finger at the Chinese leadership over human rights issues. Then, just in case his audience back home had not got the point, he made sure, and again using his words, that `informed sources'-the oldest one in the book-knew how upset the Chinese were by his incredibly strong line on human rights. He had to do this because, of course, the Chinese did not seem to think it was worthwhile mentioning that Dr Hewson had thrashed them with a feather. The Age of 24 September stated:

The exchanges, in which Dr Hewson pushed human rights issues, `jarred' the leaders, according to informed sources, and prompted some invited officials to stay away from a reception at Australia's embassy.
Further, it stated:
Dr Hewson said today he had heard that some ministers planned to avoid the reception as a protest against the human rights stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —He obviously made his point.

—I would say that none of this came from the Chinese. As Senator Watson would know, all of it came from Dr Hewson. I would like to conclude my contribution to this debate by quoting again from the Australian. The editorial in the Australian of 18 September 1990 said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Far from being in disarray, as he-
that is, Dr Hewson -
claims, Australian foreign policy under Senator Evans has arguably been more consistent and effective than for many years.
I think those words are correct and are testimony to this Government's achievements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the parliamentary statement made yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with regard to his visits in recent weeks to New Caledonia, the South Pacific Forum, Papua New Guinea and Japan. In great contrast to the Yes, Minister comments of the new backbencher from New South Wales, Senator Faulkner, who spoke in adulatory terms of his Prime Minister, I have considered the statement carefully and disagree. This is yet further evidence that we now have in Australia a tired government-a government which is tired and out of ideas not only in respect of economic matters but also in respect of foreign affairs matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been critical of the Government for some time in respect of foreign affairs matters. The Prime Minister's failures in his recent visits overseas demonstrate what is happening in this important area which goes to the heart of Australia's national interest. The Prime Minister went to Japan but came away unsuccessful. The Olympics did not come to Melbourne although this was the intention and the purpose of his visit.

He went to New Guinea and came away without any constructive solutions to the present pressing problems of that country, including Bougainville. He went to the South Pacific Forum and came away with similar failures, having alienated Pacific leaders on the two major issues that were before that Forum. The first was the chemical weapons question with regard to the facility proposed by the United States on Johnston Atoll to destroy chemical weapons. As an apologist, without a proper brief and without preparation of his case, instead of benefiting from the arguments that he should have been in a position to have mounted at that Forum, he appeared to be the dupe of another foreign government's analysis of the matter and he failed to convince the Prime Ministers of our close neighbours.

On the second major issue discussed at the South Pacific Forum-that is the question of Fiji, assessments of the failures there as a result of coups, the overriding of the constitution, the failure of democracy in that country and the question of what the attitudes of other countries should be towards Fiji in these circumstances-the Prime Minister not only alienated the Prime Ministers of our neighbouring countries but also, through his inept behaviour and remarks, put off side Ratu Mara, the present Prime Minister of Fiji, and the Opposition which had, at least for some months, understood Australia's protest at the turn of events in Fiji.

We have a Prime Minister returned from Japan, from Papua New Guinea and from the South Pacific Forum with this succession of failures. It is no wonder then that the Opposition has described the Prime Minister's report yesterday in the House of Representatives as further evidence of the failures of this tired Government-a Government lacking ideas and inspiration. The report given by the Prime Minister highlights the failures and inconsistencies of a tired Government lacking ideas and influence. It is a sorry record of unnecessary confusion and disillusionment, caused by the Prime Minister's own incompetent handling of important international issues. That is the Opposition's assessment of this matter, and it has been maintained by Opposition speakers in this debate in the Senate and also in the House of Representatives.

In addition, there has been a pattern of failure this year by the Government in foreign policy matters. I refer to a succession of issues. The first is the Government's failure to respond in good time to the opportunities to influence our neighbour China. It has taken the Opposition to set out an initiative to open the doors to dialogue with China, and only now is the Government beginning to follow our lead.

For some years now the Opposition has urged a series of constructive commercial measures to enhance Australia's advantage in commercial relationships with Taiwan. Only after we yet once more, in August and September, explicitly set out our specific reforms with regard to Taiwan has the Government now begun to act. Last Friday it was widely reported in newspapers-for example, on the front page of the Australian Financial Review-that the Government was moving, at long last, to take up some of the reforms that the Opposition has been urging for some time.

Of course, I do not refer to any semblance of a two-China policy. There is one China and that is the Government in Beijing, which is recognised not only by the present Labor Government but by preceding Liberal and National Party governments of Australia. I am talking about initiatives in regard to Taiwan as an economic entity and maximising Australia's advantage in relation to Taiwan. I will return to these two areas, China and Taiwan, later in my remarks.

A third failure has been the Prime Minister's inadequate response to Fiji. Now the Prime Minister has, it appears, ditched his own former policy on Fiji in favour of the more realistic and more engaging approach that the Opposition has been advocating for months. We should not close the door on our discussions with the present Government in Fiji. Rather, we should put our strong views about constitutional proprieties and about democracy by direct meeting and engagement with whoever are the representatives of that country.

A fourth issue on which the Government has at last begun to heed our initiatives has been our call for the ending of a ban on ministerial contact with the Palestine Liberation Organisation. We have the news only today of the terrible event in Jerusalem where, following some degree of riot, there was an over-reaction by the Israeli authorities in the shooting dead of more than 20 Palestinians and the wounding of some hundreds of other Palestinians.

The foundation for our concern is not only the loss of life and this completely exaggerated response to provocations, but the lack of a solution-even the lack of any pathway that would appear to be leading to a solution-to the Palestinian question. In the present circumstances of the Middle East with Iraq's aggression against and occupation of Kuwait, unlawfully and against all the views of the allied nations now arraigned against Iraq, an event such as the one in Jerusalem which we had reported to us today is the kind of spark which could have begun the shooting war, which could have begun an engagement of Israel in the tinderbox of military confrontation in the Gulf.

It is therefore all the more urgent that there be a constructive and positive response by the present Government in Australia to take the preliminary and foundation measures that will see a solution to the Palestinian question. There has been a failure to report to this nation any advances in this area.

Another area is the now long drawn-out civil war in Sri Lanka and the Government's failure to put forward positive suggestions, especially since the change of government in India and, as a consequence of that change, the withdrawal of Indian troops from Sri Lanka. The Government, however, now appears to look favourably on the Opposition's proposal, which is a Commonwealth role to bring peace to Sri Lanka. Various nations of the Commonwealth, including Australia, could work constructively in that country, with the agreement of the Government of Sri Lanka, to assist in the disengagement of the forces arraigned against each other. Senator Hill has outlined that proposal in detail and with very real coherence.

Another area where the Opposition took the lead concerned the question of the moment, the response to the crisis in the Gulf. It was the Opposition which called for a practical commitment from our Defence Force in response to the Middle East crisis, and this public statement was one day ahead of the Government's announcement of the Royal Australian Navy's deployment. Despite repeated calls to the Prime Minister in extensive correspondence by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), the Prime Minister has not yet informed the Australian public on the full extent or full nature of Australia's involvement in the Gulf.

I know that we have had some disclosure of rules of engagement and guidelines with regard to the structure of command in the Gulf, but still the Australian public is not fully informed about our direct involvement with our allies in the Gulf region.

In addition to these instances where the Government has begun to follow the lead set out by the Opposition's declared policies, there have been three stark errors in foreign policy matters, and I mention them in passing. One has been the hypocrisy and confusion surrounding the Prime Minister's announcement concerning Chinese students in this country following the terrible events in Tiananmen Square on 4 June last year. Overemotionally, in a sweeping statement, without consultation or forethought, the Government announced a four-year extension for the visas of all Chinese students in Australia, irrespective of the merits of any particular case.

The Opposition, in contrast, has properly sought to have any Chinese student who would be in difficulty on return to China allowed to remain in this country. But the assessment of that matter should be on a case by case basis, and not made with the sweep of the hand, saying that 20,000 Chinese students could stay in this country for what appears to be an indefinite period but certainly whilst this Government is in power for a period of four years. This extends uncertainty. It blows the integrity of our immigration program, and it also gives signals to all those countries that send students for training in this country that our word is not reliable with regard to students being trained in this country with the imperative that they return to give assistance to their own country.

The second area that we see as an error, and indeed gross hypocrisy in the Government's decisions in the foreign policy area, concerns overseas aid. Foreign overseas development assistance has been cut by $100m because there was a bringing forward into the last financial year an amount of money that would ordinarily have been in this financial year. By this arrangement, whilst there appears to be the same dollar amount in the Budget Papers for foreign aid this year, on a closer examination one finds that there is a $100m cut.

On 19 September here in the Senate, I outlined my own assessments of this serious situation with regard to Australia's overseas aid. I highlighted then, as I do now, the hypocrisy of the Government in not honouring the promise that it made during the election campaign that it would maintain in real terms the amount of Australia's overseas aid. Very ironically, the cut of $100m is in fact the amount that the Opposition honestly declared before the election that we believed was necessary on the basis of guidelines we then clearly published, given the economic situation of this country and the need for us to be sure that we had the cloth to which we could cut our suit that the Australian public could afford.

But the Government, against that statement, clearly said that it would maintain overseas aid in real terms, and gladhanded itself among the Australian public and overseas aid groups with the contrast that the Opposition would make a cut and it would not. However, only a matter of months after that election, this hypocritical Government has in fact introduced a cut of $100m, and reneged completely on its promise to maintain overseas aid in real terms. I think that the public in future ought to look to the honest statements of the Opposition against the hypocritical record of the Labor Party.

The third area, which it is now very clear was a major mistake in the foreign affairs area, was the sale of Mirage jets to Pakistan at a time of extraordinary tension over Kashmir between Pakistan and India, at just the time when after several years of careful work in a bipartisan approach, there had been an increasingly substantial and close relationship between Australia and India. With no offence to Pakistan and to the other countries of south Asia, I say we have this $30m sale-30 pieces of silver-of some second-hand Mirage jets. It ought to have been entirely obvious to this Government that even this sale, however lowly it thought it was in value, being worth only $30m, was of direct offence to India and quite the wrong signal to give at that time. It was throwing an incendiary into a tense situation between India and Pakistan.

This is the record of the Government, of which this Prime Minister has now reported to the Parliament with regard to his visits to several overseas countries. Not only has he failed in the visits that he made, but also he has failed in the various ways that I have now listed. It is no wonder that the Senate does not have confidence in the present Government in terms of the handling of Australia's foreign affairs decisions. Because I wish to be fair, I point out that there have been two initiatives, now somewhat dated, in which there has been some degree of success. One relates to Cambodia and the other relates to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation process. The goals of both programs have the full support of the Opposition. Of course, we all in this chamber wish to see a stable secure solution to the problems of Cambodia. Indeed, the Opposition, with strong initiatives which preceded those of the Government, wishes to see an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation process which will lead to the further prosperity of Australia and all of the countries of this region.

I think it is fair to estimate that the Asia-Pacific region will become the most prosperous-the largest in economic terms-in the world as a whole by the beginning of next century. There will be three centres of economic activity: one will be Europe, another North America, and the third the Asia-Pacific region. This third region, including Australia, will be the greatest. It is important that Australia take initiatives to maximise the bridges for understanding and cooperation between the countries in this region.

It is with this in mind that I refer to the Opposition's visit to China recently and to our specific initiatives with regard to Taiwan. This has been referred to on a number of occasions by speakers, including Senator Faulkner, who preceded me. It is understandable that it be referred to because, in great contrast to the Prime Minister's visits overseas, this visit by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, was so strikingly dramatic as an initiative in the foreign affairs area, and so successful, that of course it has led to a great deal of comment around Australia and here in this Parliament.

Dr Hewson has made two significant journeys in the period he has been Leader of the Opposition. The first was to some eight countries in Asia: Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. It is significant that the Leader of the Liberal-National coalition went first to the Asia-Pacific region, to which I have been referring. He went with a very careful knowledge of the economies of these countries. His visit there was entirely successful. The second visit that he made was to China just a fortnight ago, following his short visit to Japan in support of Melbourne's Olympic bid.

As chairman of the Opposition's foreign affairs and defence committee, I had the privilege to attend in China with Dr Hewson, along with the Leader of the National Party, Mr Tim Fischer, and the foreign affairs shadow Minister, Senator Hill. I do not believe that in recent history there has been any visit overseas by the three significant leaders of the Opposition: the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.

I observed every aspect of the preparation for that visit and, indeed, every aspect of our discussions in China. I believe that our objectives were achieved and that it was a most successful visit. I am happy to see that Senator Gareth Evans has not chosen to make one single criticism of this new initiative by the Opposition. Indeed, since we announced the terms of our visit, Dr Blewett has visited China and, in a measured and appropriate way, I believe, the Government ought to continue the process of dialogue that we have opened up.

It is the Opposition's view that, of course, we are all-Government and Opposition alike-appalled by the turn of events in May-June last year. The massacre in Tiananmen Square last year appalled the world, appalled Australia. In our visit to the senior leaders of China barely two weeks ago our first communication was to reinforce that same direct criticism of the policies of any country that turns its guns on the people of its own state. The Army of China shot workers and students in the heart of the capital, Beijing. It is still graphically remembered by the Australian people and by the Government and the Opposition.

As a result of this there has been a wall erected by the nations of the world that has isolated China for more than a year. There have been no ministerial contacts. There has been a cessation of all development assistance to China and, of course, all defence cooperation arrangements. No new proposals for World Bank loans-the Asian development loans-that have been extended to China in the past were being considered.

The initiatives of private businessmen were also greatly reduced because of the political atmosphere, and there was a shattering by these actions of the Chinese Government of the kind of trust and foundation that one expects to enable the greatest taking of opportunities for joint ventures, for trade and so on. We have also observed that there has been a tightening of consumption within China, partly government induced, to beat the inflation that was roaring in 1988 and also because of the anxieties of ordinary Chinese in their consumption patterns. They have been saving money rather than spending it. As a result, we are now not selling as much wool to China. Our trade has decreased.

The Opposition has the view, and has held this view very successfully, that it is well nigh time for us to open the door of dialogue with China, to go at a senior level to Beijing to meet Ministers and officials and to speak frankly about Australia's attitudes, and at this transition time to have some influence with the developments in China. Following our own discussions with the General Secretary of the Party in China, Jiang Zemin, and the Premier of China, Li Peng, Ministers for education, textiles, foreign affairs and other senior officials, there will be a visit by a delegation of National Party members of parliament this month, and next month there will be another delegation of Liberal members of parliament.

The Opposition has taken the initiative to speak frankly to China and to listen carefully to China and to look to not only the very good economic prospects for mutual benefit between our two countries in the future but also the problems which beset us at the moment. This is the initiative that the Opposition has mapped out and it is of a pattern, with all that I have been saying through this speech in response to the Prime Minister's statement, that the Opposition has taken the lead and the Government has followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), on page 3 of his statement, devotes four paragraphs to the somewhat disturbing events at the South Pacific Forum, but of course without giving the whole story. We could not expect him to give the whole story because he was roundly criticised by our nearest neighbours for the attitude he took over the plan of the United States to incinerate chemicals on Johnston Atoll. In fact, the Prime Minister has been very soundly discredited for his support of United States policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Another aspect of the report I want to focus on is that of his suggestion to Japan that it should rearm; in fact, that that country should change clause 9 of its Constitution in order to take a greater share in the global security role.

In both of these cases the Prime Minister came unstuck because he was serving the United States Government rather than the interests of the Australian people and the interests of other nations in our region. He deserved to come unstuck, to be roundly criticised by our neighbours on both these issues. Other people have criticised him for other things but I will just say a few words about both those issues: Johnston Atoll and the speech in Japan in which the Prime Minister suggested that there should be an increase in military expenditure.

It is important to note that the Prime Minister thought that many of the criticisms made about the Johnston Atoll incinerator were unfounded and unnecessary and that useful talks were held in Washington following the Forum. I would like to expand on that a little to give some background information on this very delicate situation of Johnston Atoll, which the South Pacific Forum nations do not want to become a permanent waste dumping ground for chemical weapons; neither do they want to see dangerous technologies used which could have devastating environmental impacts on their region of the world. A newspaper article of 31 August 1990 states:
Greenpeace toxicologist, Dr Paul Johnston, from London University, said . . . that the risks of contaminants like dioxin entering the local food chain is high.
`There has never been a plant like this before. It would produce dioxins and hundreds of other uncategorised chemicals,' Dr Johnston said.

While the US had tried to assure the region that the US can control the emissions from the Johnston Atoll Chemical Agents Disposal System (JACADS), . . . that it is a `triumph of hope over experience'.

Interestingly, Dr Johnston was speaking before the JACADS unit at Johnston Atoll was closed down twice. The unit has been closed down twice since his warning in August because of unsafe emissions. The article continues:
. . . once JACADS becomes operational, the other 95 per cent of US chemical weapons currently stored on the mainland were liable to be transported to the atoll for destruction.

That is because the primary incinerator for United States chemical weapons on the United States mainland-the one at Tooele Army Depot, 65 kilometres west of Salt Lake City in Utah, where 40 per cent of the army's chemical weapons are stored-has run into a great deal of problems between 1983 and 1987. A further newspaper article states:

The plant was closed for a year after pipe leaks released a nerve agent into the work area in January 1987. In the worst incident, in February 1985, nerve gas was released up to 75 times the . . . hourly safety limit.

Details of the releases became available through the Freedom of Information Act. As a result, sites for the eight incinerators the army wants to build near its bases in the US have become the subject of environmental protests.

No wonder. Who wants to have a chemical incineration plant in their backyard when the record of the existing plant is so flawed with environmental problems. Dr Johnston from Greenpeace went on to say that though the United States has pledged that once the Okinawa and German weapons are destroyed JACADS will be closed down:
`I don't think they can be trusted. They won't shut it down, they will just keep on using it'.

Obviously, when they are putting such a lot of financial resources into developing this JACADS incineration unit on Johnston Atoll, it is very unlikely that, given the dearth of other destruction facilities on the mainland of the United States, they would close down the one that they can operate at Johnston Atoll.

Interestingly, too, Greenpeace has suggested four other methods of disposal. Sometimes the people who are critical of this United States disposal on Johnston Atoll are reminded that it is a good thing to be getting rid of chemical weapons. Of course, that is the case. We would totally support the elimination of chemical weapons deposits and the destruction of all existing stocks of chemical weapons. However, this is not the only method that could be used. It is the only method going at the moment but, as Dr Johnston says, four other safe methods of destruction could be implemented, and they are as follows: to neutralise the agents with other chemicals; to use an electronic chemical disposal system; to break down the chemicals with the sun's photochemical energy; or to use biological disposal methods. These new technologies, which are not harmful to the environment, could be up and running in 18 months, so that is the way we should be going. The people who are criticising the Johnston Atoll suggestion are not saying that chemical weapons should not be destroyed. Of course we believe they should be destroyed, and as soon as possible, but not at the cost of environmental havoc in the Pacific.

It is also interesting that the United States documents which have been unearthed by the Herald newspaper in Australia reveal that the European stocks are unlikely to be considered for destruction before the year 2007. This has been the big ploy to get rid of the chemical weapons which have been stored in western Europe but not to destroy them there. If they are so safe, why are they not being destroyed in western Europe or on the United States mainland? It is rather disturbing that these state-of-the-art weapons systems which have been developed by various Western powers are not actually going to be destroyed immediately, but the information that has been obtained from the United States Defense Department suggests that they will be kept in a state of readiness for any particular use that may arise. Since all of this was discovered from the United States Army records, the Gulf crisis has blown up, and the possibility of the use of chemical weapons there cannot be ruled out. Both the United States and Iraq have used chemical weapons before. If this crisis develops into a full-scale military exchange-which I sincerely hope it does not-there is every likelihood that chemical weapons will be used by either Iraq or the United States or both in that conflict. The United States Army document states:
The European Chemical Stockpile contains the best maintained munitions in the US inventory and as such is considered material not waste.

Once these materials reach Johnston Atoll the weapons will be held by the Army's active chemical warfare unit, known as the Army Chemical Activity Western Command-a body not only responsible for the storage and disposal of weapons but, as its designation suggests, and as a United States Defense Department document obtained by the Herald which outlines its functions shows, required to:
assist in the preparation of toxic chemical munitions for shipment in deployment situations and to deliver to the shipping point.

The case in point that I have just mentioned is the Gulf crisis. So we really have to question the United States Government's repeated assurance that the weapons will be destroyed, and destroyed quickly; that the chemical plant will be shut down and that the Johnston Atoll will not become a permanent repository.

We need to look at what some of the South Pacific Forum members have had to say about this. The Secretary-General of the 15-nation South Pacific Forum, Mr Henry Naisali, spoke at a news conference just after the South Pacific Forum when he compared the incineration project to the Gulf crisis and claimed that Washington classed Pacific Islanders as 'breadfruits and coconuts'. He was indeed very angry with the total disregard that seemed to be shown. The Deputy Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands, Mr Danny Phillips, was criticising Mr Hawke's position as supporting the United States line that this was a safe disposal, and he said that Mr Hawke's position had been based on prior consultation with Washington. He said:
He (Mr Hawke) said that we all agree that the destruction of lethal weapons is important for him.
I agree on that. But we do not think that Johnston Atoll is the right place to do that.

Mr Phillips told ABC radio that Mr Hawke had been too quick to accept the idea of the destruction of this material on Johnston island. He said Mr Hawke had been strongly criticised by the leaders of Nauru and Kiribati during the closed sessions of the Forum. Mr Palmer, the former Prime Minister of New Zealand, said that the debate was a real humdinger, so we can imagine what was said in the closed forum. But we have a few more quotes from the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Mr Namaliu, who said at the time, in criticising the Australian position, that it was very unsatisfactory that Australia had provided scientific assessment of this proposal only at the last minute. He said:
They left it too late, in our view deliberately, so that we weren't given the time to make the assessment of information, and then to ask the right sorts of questions.
He went on to say:

In the minds of most of us we suspect very strongly that there is some kind of collusion going on between the United States and Australia, in making sure that this thing was kept to the last minute, and we don't like it.

Such an approach had created a great deal of suspicion and mistrust. Solomon Islands Deputy Prime Minister Phillips went further, suggesting that Mr Hawke had been two-faced and that Australia's performance raised questions about whether it should be a member of the Forum. That is how strongly some of our Forum partners felt about the role of the Prime Minister on this question at the South Pacific Forum; hardly a victory.

The second issue I want to raise is the question of the Prime Minister's speech in Japan when he suggested that the Japanese Government should be taking wider responsibility in global matters, apart from what he said about the United Nations and Japan's role there. That would be an interesting debate, to consider Japan's possible membership of the Security Council, but the really disturbing part of that speech was that he suggested that Japan should increase its military expenditure. Again, we have to ask the question: Whom is he trying to please? We do not have to look very far to find the answer. The United States Government has been trotting out the line of burden-sharing for the last two years. They are under economic constraints in the United States. They do not want to have to foot the bill in the terms that they see it for global security, and why should they be policemen for the whole globe in security matters?

There are many of us who would rather they did not assume that role for themselves. But as they do assume that role for themselves, they expect their allies to take an increasing part of the financial burden, including Japan, including the Philippines, including Australia, and of course including New Zealand too in this part of the world. So the line of burdensharing has been trotted out by the United States Government, but not very successfully-certainly not in Japan, where clause 9 of their constitution forbids them from spending more than one per cent of their national budget on the military.

This suggestion from our Prime Minister comes at a time when we need to be encouraging non-military forms of conflict resolution in arms control in the North Pacific. That is what the Prime Minister should have suggested in Japan, but he is openly encouraging the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in Japan-which is neither liberal nor democratic-to defy its own peace constitution and allow the deployment of self-defence force troops outside their own territory, which has been unheard of since the Second World War. We should be very thankful for that. Japan already has the third largest military budget in the world, despite its one per cent limit, because of its huge national budget. This is largely geared to anti-submarine warfare and defensive strategies.

I would hate to think of the impact of Japan acquiring obviously offensive equipment such as nuclear submarines, aircraft carriers, nuclear weapons and long range missiles-all of which it could make quite quickly. The right wing has been chipping away at Article 9 for some years, and the latest move is the proposal to acquire a helicopter carrier.

The Japanese hardly need any encouragement from the Australian Prime Minister to undermine their own constitution, but if Mr Hawke encourages Japanese military might, he is opening the door further for these kinds of developments and, of course, for further military exports from Japan, which would be a very unwelcome addition to the Asia-Pacific scene. Anyone who has been to Japan recently knows about the resurgence of the Japanese right, which feels the need to restore its pre-war military might as well as the worship of the Emperor and the promotion of Shintoism.

We should be supporting progressive forces in Japan who want to maintain the peace constitution, and not encouraging the hawks and the ultra-right, which is exactly what Mr Hawke did. Thankfully, his opposite number, the leader of the Socialist Party in Japan, Ms Takako Doi, told him in no uncertain terms that she did not approve of any extension of Japan's military role. One would think that the Prime Minister would be sensitive to the links with his so-called opposite number in the Socialist Party in Japan and not go there and openly support the ultra-right hawkish conservatives.

I would hate to think what might happen if the Japanese corporations who are lobbying to export military equipment got loose in a region where an arms race is already under way and there are a number of conflicts that could blow up or escalate at any time. If Japanese military exports, especially in the area of defence electronics, are anything like their television sets and cars, the situation could get worse very quickly.

It is also somewhat ridiculous to think that Australia can compete with Japanese military exports in the region. We cannot have it both ways. We want Japan to get involved, but we also want, according to our Defence Department, to have a big slice of the military exports in this region. Of course I oppose that as well. What he should have suggested was a regional effort to promote naval arms control in the North Pacific by putting pressure on the United States of America, which resolutely refuses to contemplate any such proposals. That would have been a much more welcome message that Ms Takako Doi, no doubt, would have been able to endorse.

So not only does he alienate our friends in the South Pacific by his support for the United States continuing to use the Pacific as a garbage dump for all manner of nasties, but he also manages to alienate our friends in the Japanese Socialist Party, our friends in the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN), who are not excited about the proposal of Japanese rearmament, and even the Federal Opposition, although I doubt that that worries him very much.

I need to reiterate the view that I expressed in the chamber a couple of weeks ago, that the Prime Minister's goal is to stay in power with the blessing of the United States administration. He can only stay in power with that support, which he earns by his attitude of subservience to the United States, as exemplified by these two recent episodes, which rightly earned him criticism from our nearest neighbours.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 58, page 24, lines 2 and 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
``58 (1) Subject to subsection (2), the Authority may, by written instrument, delegate to a person all or any of its powers under this or any other Act.
(2) The powers of the Authority under subsection 40 (1), section 42, subsection 47 (1) and section 56, may be delegated only to a member or officer of the Authority.''.
Clause 58 says:
The Authority may, by written instrument, delegate to a person all or any of its powers under this or any other Act.

The issue of delegation of powers is frequently raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and indeed in its assessment of this Bill it expressed its concern at the unrestricted delegation powers granted to the Authority by Clause 58. To quote directly from the Scrutiny of Bills report:
The Committee has on numerous occasions pointed out that delegations to a person are inappropriate.

The Democrats concur with that concern. I recognise that the Authority needs to be provided with a certain amount of flexibility in order to ensure that its many and varied tasks can be carried out by the appropriate person. Without this flexibility there would be some very significant costs to both the Authority and to the Australian taxpayer. I am concerned, however, that the delegation of the very broad-ranging powers of the Authority is so unrestricted.
If we consider the powers contained in clause 10 of the Bill we can see that the Authority has the power:
(a) to enter into contracts; and
(b) to acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal property; and
(c) to join in the formation of companies; and
(d) to enter partnerships; and
(e) to let on hire plant, machinery, equipment or goods of the Authority not immediately required by the Authority; and
(f) to invest money not immediately required for the purposes of the Authority in any manner that is consistent with sound commercial practice; and
(g) to do anything incidental to any of the powers specified in this subsection or otherwise conferred on the Authority.
Given the very broad scope of these powers, I believe an unrestricted delegation allowance is inappropriate.

In trying to draft amendments that would limit the Authority's delegation power, we encountered the same difficulties that the Department of Transport and Communications encountered; that is, that to limit this delegation power without impeding the Authority's flexibility was virtually impossible.

I believe that the revised amendment we have circulated is a satisfactory solution to this problem because it in no way reduces the Authority's flexibility but simply identifies those powers which are clearly inappropriate to delegate and limits their delegation to members or officers of the Authority. For example, clause 40 (1) states that the Authority may borrow money otherwise than from the Commonwealth, clause 42 allows the Authority to give security over the whole or part of its assets and clause 56 states that the Authority may engage such consultants as it thinks necessary. It is clear that the exercising of powers provided for in these clauses should be restricted to the Authority. That is what I believe this amendment achieves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the Opposition supports the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. I wish to raise an issue that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) may be able to give me a couple of answers on.
