In the information I have from the Australian National Maritime Association, there is a forecast new levy, which would come from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA), at a cost to an Australian flag vessel of $8,560.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first question relates to the repeated phraseology in the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill that actions be carried out as soon as practicable after the detainee is detained. That appears in subdivisions A, B and C. I am aware of a letter written to the acting shadow Minister for customs by Mr McInnis from the department dealing with the same point involving the phrase `as soon as practicable'.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that Mr McInnis makes is one that I have no difficulty in accepting at all, but that seems to relate purely to subdivision C, which is the most important subdivision, under which someone may be detained for an internal body search. In the earlier subdivisions, relating to the frisk search and the external search, the same phraseology appears.

The case argued by the Australian Customs Service is that the phrase `as soon as practicable' has a meaning under common law. It certainly means that the Service has to proceed. It gives an example of 48 hours as being the maximum sort of period that would be acceptable as a delay.

I accept that for subdivision C the time in practice would be very much less than that; it would be a matter of hours. My concern relates to subdivision A, which provides for a frisk search, and subdivision B, providing for an external search, where the terminology `as soon as practicable after the detainee is detained' appears in the Bill. Could the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) give the Committee some idea as to what sort of time delay is likely to ensue between a Customs officer's deciding that a frisk search or an external search is required and that search being carried out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly the practice in my home port of Darwin is that this period is very short indeed. The definition of `practicable' or `possible' is not particularly relevant to a court. If there were an inordinate delay in carrying out the search, and if the Customs person involved was not able to give a reasonable explanation of what prevented the search from being carried out, should any action be taken in a court, if it could be clearly demonstrated that it would have been practicable to have done it in a shorter time, the court would deal very harshly with the person concerned. I have had some experience with the question of natural justice, to use that body of law. In fact, it is a rapidly developing area of the law. In my experience courts are inclined to deal very severely indeed with public officers who inconvenience or deal in some other way with a person under an Act where his behaviour is less than professional and where the Act requires him to carry out these procedures with due regard for the person's rights and the person's convenience.

SPEECH.PARA: The wording of that particular phrase `as soon as practicable' means precisely what it says in terms of the simple English meaning of the word; that is the regard that any court in the land would have if there were some delay. If it could be demonstrated in court that it was practicable- that is not a very severe test-for the search to be carried out sooner than it was carried out, the court would deal very firmly indeed with officers who were guilty of not doing so. The answer to the question, in a practical sense, is very soon after a person is detained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I thank the Government. It was remiss of me not to do so when I first spoke on this matter. I regret that I was absent when the second reading was being debated in the Senate; I was overseas at the time. I thank the Government and the Australian Customs Service for accepting some of the amendments I proposed earlier in the year. The requirement that a translator or a card with the text written in the language that is spoken by the detainee be incorporated is a very worthwhile improvement in the first legislation. There are a couple of other minor points.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return to the point that I am seeking clarification on at the moment. I accept what the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is saying about the phrase `as soon as practicable' and going to a court. I am concerned, though, to see that we do not get into a court because if we get into a court we will have an angry passenger. This is not a frequently used procedure, but prevention is the way to go from a departmental point of view and from an administrative point of view. I am sure that would be the wish of the officers of the Australian Customs Service.

I came through Sydney the other morning. I do not know how many officers manned the barriers-every one was manned. I do not know how many gates there are. There might be 38, 48 or 58, but there was a queue coming back from the barrier of thousands of people. Because of the curfew at Sydney Airport there is often the situation where three or four 747s arrive simultaneously between 6 o'clock and 9 o'clock and there is a constant flow of thousands of people who want to get through. In that circumstance, if a passenger is detained for a search, I believe it is quite possible for a Customs officer to argue in good faith that the phrase `as soon as practicable' means as soon as he has finished the immediate task in front of him, which is processing those flows of passengers. If that is not a valid interpretation, I take it that the Minister would be prepared to accept that the phrase `as soon as practicable' could mean forthwith and 'forthwith' would be a directive to the officers to proceed straight away with that examination. The minor search procedures and the maintenance of good relations between the authorities and the passengers or tourists to the country are my points of concern.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 19 July 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to a 'quit smoking' campaign held during the week ended 6 July 1990, which refers to a range of chemicals used in the manufacture of cigarettes and which claims the same chemicals are used in the manufacture of paint stripper, rocket fuel, floor cleaner, automotive batteries and car exhausts, to name a few, how many chemical substances are used in the manufacture of cigarettes.
(2) Are there any controls which make the cigarette manufacturers liable to divulge what they put into their cigarettes.
(3) What type of testing do cigarettes undergo before they are released onto the market.
(4) What safety standards (if any) are in place to protect the public from purchasing cigarettes containing harmful chemicals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information about chemicals added to tobacco during manufacture is not available to me.

The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services is very concerned that the issue of added chemicals in tobacco and cigarettes diverts attention away from the fact that it is chemicals that naturally occur in tobacco which makes cigarette smoking inherently dangerous and which kill 18,000 Australians every year.

The National Health and Medical Research Council has considered the issue of chemical levels, particularly pesticides which remain as residues in tobacco products. The Council had considerable reservations about setting maximum levels of these substances since this might be taken to imply that tobacco products are safe when, in fact, they are unsafe.

(2) The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services is unaware of any current legal requirement by any State or Territory Government, under whose jurisdiction this matter would fall, for cigarette manufacturers to divulge such information.

(3) The Government has put in place the Cigarette Testing Program under a voluntary agreement with cigarette manufacturers. That agreement requires manufacturers to reduce over a period of time the levels of those substances which are considered by health experts to pose the greatest risks to health-namely tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide. Smokers are informed of the levels of these substances on packages of tobacco products and by the Smoke Yield Table which is produced regularly as a result of the ongoing testing under the program.

Tar is the particulate matter contained in the smoke inhaled by the smoker. It contains a large number (about 3000) of organic and inorganic chemicals, some of which are known carcinogens (cancer producing substances).

Nicotine is the potent substance responsible for producing the pharmacological effects of smoking which many smokers find pleasurable and therefore which contribute to the addictive nature of tobacco. It is also implicated in other untoward effects of smoking such as coronary artery disease and reproductive and gastrointestinal disorders.
Carbon monoxide is a gas present in the smoke of cigarettes and is linked with the propensity of cigarette smoking to cause coronary heart disease.

(4) To talk of safety standards in relation to smoking is misleading and dangerous. No level of smoking is safe and this is true irrespective of the levels of added chemicals that might be present in cigarettes. It is for this reason that the Government has engaged in a wide range of activities designed to discourage Australians from smoking.

Through the Cigarette Testing Program mentioned previously, smokers are made aware that smoking exposes them to those chemicals occurring naturally in cigarettes which carry well-established health risks.

In addition, health warnings have been required on all packets of tobacco products since 1987. Following extensive consultations with industry, these warnings were chosen on the basis of their effectiveness in conveying to children and young adults the hazards of smoking.

To assess whether there is additional value in giving information to smokers about the contents of cigarettes over and above that already made available, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has asked the Department of Community Services and Health to commission a survey of community attitudes on this matter.

At the same time, the Minister is seeking detailed technical information from cigarette manufacturers on those chemicals which are contained in tobacco products either as a result of the cultivation and treatment of tobacco crops or as a result of subsequent manufacture of tobacco into finished products.

These measures will assist the Government to determine whether the provision of information to smokers about added chemicals might represent a viable, additional strategy in its campaign to reduce smoking.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of a grave, discovered at Mednoe in the Soviet Union, containing thousands of bodies.
(2) Does the Government know if the bodies are those of the 'Missing' 11,000 Polish officers who were rounded up and killed in 1939.
(3) Has any country accepted responsibility for the killings; if so, is the Australian Government considering any action to condemn the perpetrators of the killings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Government does not know the identity of the bodies discovered in the Mednoe grave. However, Soviet archival material which has recently come to light may help clarify the fate of the more than 15,000 officers of the Polish army and police forces taken prisoner in 1939 by Soviet forces occupying Poland's eastern territories. The prisoners were held in three camps in the Soviet Union, Kozelsk, Starobelsk and Ostashkov.
According to a report by Soviet historian N. Lebedeva based on an analysis of the archives, the material suggests that over April-May 1940:

4,404 men were taken from the Kozelsk camp and handed over to the Smolensk NKVD; the disappearance of the prisoners from Kozelsk and the subsequent discovery in 1943 of over 4,000 bodies in Katyn Wood near Smolensk clearly suggests a linkage.

3,891 men were taken from the Starobelsk camp and handed over to the Kharkov Region NKVD; the recently reported discovery in the outskirts of Kharkov in mid June of graves thought to contain the bodies of Polish officers would, if confirmed, conclusively establish the fate of the prisoners from this camp.

6,287 men were taken from the Ostashkov camp and handed over to the Kalinin Region NKVD; while preliminary reports are scanty, they suggest that the grave discovered at Mednoe, near Kalinin, may contain the bodies of at least some of the Polish prisoners from the Ostashkov camp.
(3) On 13 April this year, the Soviet Union acknowledged its responsibility for the Katyn massacre, which an official statement called ``one of the gravest crimes of Stalinism''.

Following this statement, the Polish Head of State General Jaruzelski visited Katyn Wood to pay tribute to the slain Polish officers. President Gorbachev had earlier handed over to General Jaruzelski copies of archive documents concerning the massacre, and Soviet and Polish historians have since been cooperating in the search for more information, including the location of other graves. While the Australian Government has consistently condemned the Katyn massacre, and the disappearance of the other 11,000 Polish officers, it believes that, in view of the Soviet acceptance of responsibility, and given the willingness of the Polish and Soviet authorities to discuss it openly, the matter is now one for the USSR and Poland to settle, as they are clearly doing.

Accordingly, the Senator may care to approach Doctors Awerbuch and Bouvier directly about access to their submissions and I will provide him with contact details.

Due to the length of the submission, it will not be published in Hansard. However, copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security upon notice, on 23 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the present social security regulations causing hardship and a reduced standard of living for many Australians, particularly those Australians in their late 50s or early 60s.

(2) Under the present regulations, is income received from superannuation funds that are rolled over into capital guaranteed funds regarded as income received even though it is not withdrawn and, as a result, are many prevented from receiving social security benefits.
(3) Is this income normally meant to increase to provide for retirement at age 65.

(4) If the funds are rolled over into market-linked funds, is the income received, but not withdrawn, regarded as income and the retrenched/redundant worker allowed to apply for full unemployment benefits.
(5) Consequently, are retrenched workers forced to roll over their funds into insecure market-linked funds or live below the poverty line on income received from capital guaranteed funds.
(6) Will the Minister confirm that he is aware of the problem alluded to in questions (2) to (5).
(7) Can the Minister give an undertaking that the Government will investigate the problem and remove this anomaly so that the Government's policy of providing for one's own retirement may eventuate.
(8) Will this policy cost the Government more in increased pension benefits when the affected people reach 65 years of age as their superannuation savings will have been eaten away.
(9) Could the Minister give an estimate of the expected increased costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the Honourable Senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Income is generally assessed on capital guaranteed approved deposit funds and deferred annuities on an ongoing basis. If the superannuation benefit is compulsorily preserved, or the rollover was made with a Friendly Society before 1 January 1988, income is assessed for the following twelve months when a withdrawal is made. People are not precluded from receiving Social Security benefits because they have money in a rollover fund. However, the rate of benefit payable is calculated using an income test. Income included from rollover funds can, therefore, affect the rate of benefit paid.

(3) Superannuation is savings for retirement. However, it is often possible to access superannuation money before age 65. Where this occurs these payments are assessed as income for pension and benefit purposes.

(4) Where the rollover into a market-linked fund has been made on or after 9 September 1988, income is assessed on an ongoing basis. Rollovers made before 9 September 1988 are assessed only on withdrawal. People are not precluded from receiving Social Security benefits because they have money in a rollover fund. However, as mentioned in answer (2) above, the rate of benefit payable is calculated using an income test.

(5) No; retrenched workers are not forced to rollover superannuation into market-linked funds. The Government acted in the 1988-89 Budget to assess income from both capital guaranteed and market-linked rollover funds in the same way. This removed any incentive for clients to select market-linked or capital guaranteed funds insofar as treatment for Social Security purposes is concerned.
(6) Following the Government's 1988-89 Budget changes there is no problem-see the answer to Question 5.
(7)-(9) See answer to (6).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 23 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What will be the nature of the review of housing policies which was announced by the Treasurer in the Budget statement 1990-91.
(2) How will the review be carried out and who will be responsible for its co-ordination.
(3) Can the Minister guarantee that a process of full community consultation will be incorporated as part of this review.
(4) When does the Minister expect to receive an interim report in connection with the review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Housing Strategy will undertake a comprehensive examination of Australia's current and projected housing needs into the coming two decades. It will look at innovative financing and other mechanisms that will make quality housing more affordable, particularly for low to moderate income Australians. It will focus on what constitutes appropriate housing with special attention given to those who are currently poorly housed. It will explore links between housing, the labour market and community services. The National Housing Strategy is part of the Government's Social Justice Strategy.

(2) Work on the National Housing Strategy will be undertaken by the Department of Community Services and Health, with the assistance of contracted consultants as and when required. The National Housing Strategy will be co-ordinated by the Consultant Director, Dr Meredith Edwards.

(3) A process of community consultation is scheduled in the National Housing Strategy work plan. This will occur several times over the next two years, following the release of published issues papers.
(4) The National Housing Strategy will present its findings in the form of a series of published papers. The first of these is scheduled to appear in 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What discussions have taken place or are being planned with the New Zealand Government to overcome the disadvantages experienced by Australian companies repatriating profits because of the major differences in the taxation law of both countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The 1983 Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (the CER Agreement) and subsequent arrangements refer to taxation in only a peripheral and technical way. The wider issue of the differences between the respective taxation systems and the effect, if any, these differences might have on trans-Tasman trade has not yet been addressed.

The Minister for Trade Negotiations, Dr Blewett, has been asked by the Prime Minister to bring forward by 31 March 1991, in consultation with his New Zealand counterpart, recommendations on steps worth pursuing in the next major review of the CER Agreement, scheduled for 1992. In this process, the Minister will consult closely with the business community and with the States and Territories. The Australian business community has already proposed that certain specific taxation issues be considered in this context, including taxation measures affecting Australian companies operating in the New Zealand market. This proposal will be evaluated by Dr Blewett during the course of his deliberations on the 1992 CER review agenda.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Was there a permanent body established to replace the Interim Heads of Commonwealth Marine Agencies Group; if so (a) when was it established (b) what are its terms of reference (c) who are its members and (d) how much money was provided for its activities during 1989-90 and in the 1990-91 estimates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, the group has been formally constituted as the Heads of Marine Agencies (HOMA).

(a) The Group operated informally from 1987 to 1988. The Prime Minister's statement``Science and Technology for Australia'' of May 1989 formalised its role, and extended its responsibilities and membership. The first meeting of HOMA under the new arrangements took place on 27 September 1989.
(b) Its Terms of Reference are to:

(i) Take responsibility for Australia's participation in international intergovernmental marine science and technology programs, and assist Australian institutions and companies to participate in overseas markets for research and development services;
(ii) Take initiatives aimed at improving coordination within and between government agencies and industry bodies working in the marine sector;

(iii) Provide appropriate advice to ensure that important areas of marine research and development of national benefits and/or commercial opportunity are funded, directly or in liaison with NBEET, ARC, FIRDC, the IR& Board, NERDDC, CSIRO, or other appropriate bodies; and

(iv) Consult with and seek advice from the Consultative Group on Marine Industries Science and Technology (CMIST). [CMIST is an informal group set up by HOMA and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to assist them in carrying out the responsibilities in marine science and technology assigned by the Prime Minister's statement of May 1989.]

(c) HOMA comprises the Heads of the marine programs of Commonwealth agencies concerned with marine science, namely: the CSIRO Institute of Natural Resources and Environment, the Australian Institute of Marine Science, the Bureau of Mineral Resources Geology and Geophysics, the Bureau of Meteorology, the RAN Hydrographic Service, the Bureau of Rural Resources, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.
As at 6 August 1990, the membership comprised:
Dr R Green (CSIRO), chairman
Dr J Baker (AIMS)
Dr D Falvey (BMR)
Dr J Zillman (BOM)
Cdre J Compton (RAN)
Dr M Williams (BRR)
Mr D Brown (DSTO)
Mr G Kelleher (GBRMPA)
Dr R Jensen (DITAC)
(all ex officio).

(d) No funds were allocated for HOMA as such in either the 1989-90 or the 1990-91 Budget. The costs of each member are met by their agency, except for attendance at IOC meetings of an intergovernmental policy nature some of which ($30,150 in 1989-90) is funded from the allocation for the Marine sub-program of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, as are the secretariat costs ($40,000 in 1989-90). Scientific participation costs are met by the agencies concerned. The 1989-90 allocation to my Department, in accordance with the Prime Minister's statement, included a one-off allocation of $250,000 which was used to set up, on behalf of HOMA, the Australian Marine Science and Technology Project Office; that office, acting under the direction of HOMA, carries out the second part of HOMA's first term of reference.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government established a steering committee for the National Tidal Facility; if so: (a) who are its members; and (b) what are its terms of reference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A Steering Committee for the National Tidal Facility has been established and Secretariat support is provided by the Hydrographic Branch of the Department of Defence. The Members of this Committee are: Commodore J. S. Compton (RAN Hydrographer) as Chairman, Dr D. J. Gauntlett from the Bureau of Meteorology, Mr W. D. Lamond from the Australian Surveying &Land Information Group and Professor G. W. Lennon from Flinders Institute for Atmospheric and Marine Sciences at Flinders University.
At this stage there are no formal terms of reference, but agreement has been made to the following points:
. provide a constructive, facilitating role, with some oversight of operations and guidance in direction;
. to report to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce;
. to inform the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories of activities, particularly relating to the Climate Change Core Research Program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 31 August 1990 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the level of cooperation between Australian carpet manufacturers and carpet wool growers to jointly add value to an Australian raw material and the export potential of the finished carpet.
(2) What potential impact would the imposition of the wool tax have on this positive development for Australia.
(3) What does the Minister plan to do about supporting the exemption sought by Australian carpet wool growers from the wool tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of the cooperative efforts of carpet manufacturers and carpet wool growers and the export success resulting from that cooperation. I understand some manufacturers have recently won tenders to supply carpets to large hotel developments in the Asia Pacific region.

(2) New Zealand is the world's major exporter of carpet wool. The price Australian carpet wool producer cooperatives and the Australian Wool Corporation can offer producers for carpet wool is a reflection of the New Zealand import price. With the increase in the wool tax from 8 per cent in 1989-90 to 18 per cent in 1990-91, and pricing competition from New Zealand imports, producers are not in a position to pass on the cost of the wool tax increase to consumers and will therefore be forced to absorb it in their already slim profit margins. I have been advised that the increased wool tax from 1 July 1990 will result in a contraction in the carpet wool industry as producers make production decisions based on the relative profitability of alternative enterprises. Declining carpet wool production in Australia will be associated with increasing imports of carpet wool.

(3) I am concerned at the situation facing carpet wool growers in Australia. At the meeting of Wool Council of Australia (WCA) in Roma a resolution was passed-``to ask the AWC to consider excluding wool that is suitable for carpet manufacture (i.e. wool with a mean fibre diameter equal to or greater than 32 micron which is used in the production of carpet yarn) from the wool Tax Acts''. In response to the WCA resolution and a number of submissions and delegations from the carpet wool industry, I have written to the AWC and WCA seeking their views on this matter and am currently considering their replies. The issue is a complex one with wider implications for wool statutory marketing arrangements. However, I am actively seeking a resolution that is acceptable to the AWC, WCA and the Carpet Wool Council.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Defence: Investigation of Fraud

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When were Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigators first offered to the Department of Defence to investigate fraud.
(2) When did AFP investigators seconded to Defence commence work in the department.
(3) Is the public servant who first raised the allegations with the department and the AFP still employed by Defence and/or the Public Service.
(4) On what date were this officer's allegations made to the Department of Defence.
(5) Was the subject matter of the allegations he raised amongst the matters referred to by the Minister in his press release of 17 July 1990.
(6) Are these matters still being investigated by the AFP.
(7) Is the Government willing to release the audit-in-confidence completed in 1987 which concerned the period between 1980-1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the course of informal discussions between Department of Defence and AFP staff on 14 September 1988, a request was made by departmental staff for criminological assistance with the development of the Defence Fraud Control Plan. This was refused.

The offer to attach two AFP investigators to the Department to review certain Defence contracting procedures was first made in a letter from Senator Tate to the former Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, on 23 November 1988.

While there is no formal Memorandum of Understanding, the AFP made it a condition of the attachment that the AFP officers not be involved in specific fraud investigations, but rather that they familiarise themselves with Defence procurement processes.
(2) Two AFP investigators commenced attachment to the Department on Monday 6 November 1989.

(3) While I cannot be completely certain as to which Public Servant the Senator is referring, I can say that the officer who is most probably at the centre of the Senator's question, did resign from employment in the Department of Defence. I am unable to say whether he has been re-employed elsewhere in the Australian Public Service.

(4) The Public Servant did not make his allegations to the Department of Defence. He made his allegations to Mr Beazley in a letter dated 7 June 1987. The allegations were then passed to the Department.
(6) Yes.

(7) I am not sure as to which documents the Senator is referring. Many departmental audits were completed in 1987 and many of them would have reference to the period 1980 to 1985. Audit papers and reports relating to the Senator's questions 3 and 5 have been provided to the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 May 1990 Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked a question without notice as to whether I was aware that ``although several of the related dependant rebates were increased for the 1989-90 financial year, and all are now indexed annually, no provisions were made in the 1989-90 Federal Budget for an increase in zone allowance?'' The Senator went on to ask ``what action has the Government taken, or will it take, to reverse the diminished value of the zone allowance?''

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

Zone rebates are set at a fixed dollar amount plus a percentage of any dependant rebates to which the taxpayer is entitled, plus notional rebates for children. As from the 1990-91 income year, three separate rates will apply. These are:
Zone A: $270 + 50% of dependant rebates;
Zone B: $45 + 20% of dependant rebates; and
Special Zone A and Special Zone B: $938 + 50% of dependant rebates.

As the zone rebates are linked to dependant rebates, for taxpayers with dependants the amount of the zone rebate increases with increases in dependant rebates which, commencing in the 1990-91 income year, are indexed annually.
The level of the base rebates themselves will continue to be monitored as part of the normal budgetary practice.
An extension of the remote area zone rebate arrangements was announced in the 1990-91 Budget; details are given in Budget Statement 4.
The zone rebate arrangements provided an estimated $125 million in tax relief in 1989-90 to Australians residing in remote areas.
